DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 30 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill continues the historic process that began with the High Court's Mabo decision. The government moved quickly to respond to that decision. Last year parliament passed the Native Title Act, giving legislative effect to the court's rejection of the doctrine of terra nullius and its recognition of native title to land.

PARA.TAB: There is enormous symbolic value in the Mabo decision and the subsequent legislation. For the first time in our history, the inherent rights of indigenous Australians have been recognised and given statutory protection. These developments indicate that as a nation we have had the collective courage and wisdom to acknowledge the violence and destruction done to indigenous Australians and their culture since European occupation. They signal that as a nation we are willing to accept our responsibility to work towards a new relationship. Much has been achieved, but justice has not yet been done.

Justice has not been done because the majority of Australia's indigenous people live on the margins of economic, social and cultural life in this country. We may ask how this can be so in a country with one of the highest standards of living in the world, a country which prides itself on giving everyone a fair go. It is so, Mr Acting Speaker, because the vast majority of indigenous Australians have been dispossessed, either in whole or part, of that which is most precious to their sense of history and spirituality, that most essential component of their heritage—their land.

Contemporary Western culture tends to view land as something of a commodity, something which may enrich us, but not something which goes to the essence of our culture. It is difficult for non-indigenous Australians to understand what Australia's indigenous people feel about the loss of their land. It is difficult, therefore, to comprehend the extent of their dispossession. Yet it should not be too difficult for us to comprehend. It should surely not be difficult for Australians who have always placed such a value on owning a bit of Australia, the people who have taken much of their literary and artistic inspiration from the bush and who still find their greatest comfort in the natural landscape of Australia in the great outdoors. The land has a cultural and spiritual significance for all Australians and we all can surely come to an understanding of what total and uncompensated dispossession meant. We must try to comprehend it. Unless we understand the importance of land to indigenous peoples, we cannot come to terms with the extent of the loss.

It is a great ambition of this government to establish a new relationship between indigenous Australians and the wider community. We established the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to guide the nation towards greater understanding and justice, greater unity and universal respect for Australia's indigenous heritage. We introduced native title legislation in recognition that indigenous peoples owned the land before colonisation and to facilitate the formal legal recognition of those native title interests which have never been extinguished.

But the process has only just begun and, significant as the native title legislation is with its profound symbolic significance, it will not and cannot be of benefit to all indigenous peoples simply because most who have been dispossessed have been unable to maintain the continued association upon which proof of native title depends. As a consequence, we are now ready for another historic step; a step represented by this bill which recognises the injustice flowing from dispossession and goes some way towards redressing it by providing a means for indigenous communities to acquire, manage and maintain land. The facility of the bill and the high order of the funding provided under it will give indigenous Australians a significant and recurring opportunity to re-establish their relationship with the land.

The land fund will be the centrepiece of the social justice measures to be undertaken by the government and represents the major financial element of those proposals. The further measures will be the subject of advice to the government by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and ATSIC later this year. These measures will form part of the social justice package I announced when introducing the native title legislation, and which will be directed towards removing structural and institutional barriers to full participation in Australian economic life by its indigenous peoples, and safeguarding and developing indigenous culture.

This legislation by its nature is an important and necessary complement to the native title legislation and, like that act, the bill before the House is the product of wide-ranging consultation. We sought the views of peak indigenous, farming, environmental, industry and church groups. I have had meetings with Aboriginal representatives and a measure of consensus has been reached on the main features of the bill. I have sought the views of premiers and chief ministers, and of our colleagues on the other side of the House, as well as the Democrat and Green senators.

Our colleagues on the other side have expressed their opposition to the concept of the land fund, saying there are higher priorities in Aboriginal affairs. There are indeed many other things to be done, but we maintain that land ownership is fundamental to the wellbeing of the indigenous community and should be addressed as a matter of priority. The benefits flowing from re-establishing indigenous attachment to the land will not only be cultural and social, but will lead to improved economic wellbeing. I hope the opposition will be swayed in the interests of justice and equity, in the cause of righting historic wrongs, to let the Aboriginal and Islander community have the bill with bipartisan support and, in the end, not be left to describe the third reading in negative terms, as happened with the native title legislation.

I am told that the opposition intends moving amendments relating to health, housing and other matters of welfare to Aboriginal and Islander people. The government will, of course, consider all amendments, but will maintain the primary view that the fund must be about land and that other social problems best be addressed with functional appropriations. In the event, the veracity of the opposition's recent claims of concern for indigenous people will be tested by two events—the vote on the second reading in the House of Representatives and the same vote in the Senate. For the sake of the indigenous people I hope that both events are marked with bipartisan approval.

Let me now turn to key aspects of the legislation. The bill establishes the land fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation, with the purpose of enabling indigenous people to acquire land and to manage and maintain it in a sustainable way to provide economic, social and cultural benefits for future generations. The Indigenous Land Corporation will be a new, independent and commercially oriented statutory body. The government has adopted this structure because such a corporation will ensure a dedicated focus on land matters and will have specialised expertise in land management, land use assessment and environmental issues.

In summary, the land fund will receive an allocation from consolidated revenue, pay to the Indigenous Land Corporation a specified amount each year for land acquisition and management, and invest the remainder. After 10 years, it is intended that the investments made by the land fund will provide sufficient income to cover the allocations to the corporation, and Commonwealth contributions will cease.

The first instalment was allocated in this year's budget—$200 million into the fund, with $25 million to be paid to the corporation and the remainder to be invested. The government will commit $1.1 billion in 1994-95 dollars to the fund over a decade, but with maintenance in real terms the commitment will be substantially greater.

The fund will be set up as a trust account under the public account and will be subject to the provisions of part IX of the Audit Act. To make for a smooth transition, for the first three years ATSIC will continue with its land acquisition and management programs and will receive its annual allocation from the land fund. After this period, ATSIC's financial allocation will transfer to the Indigenous Land Corporation. Using the moneys paid to it by the land fund, the corporation will be responsible for acquiring land and transferring it to indigenous communities. It may also make grants to indigenous organisations for the purpose of acquiring land.

I would like it made clear that the government is very much aware of the need for land to be managed in an effective manner. The corporation will therefore carry out an equally important function of promoting and supporting the sustainable management of indigenous held land. It will do this mainly by entering into agreements with the land-holders about the use and management of land. The corporation will have the flexibility to be able to take a direct role in the management of indigenous lands to the extent set down in the agreements. On occasions it may also provide direct grants to land-holders for land management purposes.

While the government accepts that not all indigenous people will seek to make profits from their ownership of land, we are concerned that they receive sufficient assistance and encouragement to manage their land in a sustainable way. The operations of the Indigenous Land Corporation will be governed by a number of principles. It is to adopt a strategic approach and, where it operates on a commercial basis, it will do so in line with sound business principles.

In addition, in carrying out its functions, the corporation must have regard to maximising the employment of indigenous people and utilising indigenous enterprises. The corporation will be required to prepare national and regional land strategies covering three- to five-year periods and dealing with land acquisition, management and environmental issues. Copies of the document setting out these strategies will be available on request.

Regional bodies, including ATSIC regional councils, will also be involved in planning for acquisitions at the local level. The corporation will be able to establish subsidiaries to carry out its functions allowing for direct participation by local indigenous representatives in land management activities in their area.

The legislation is designed to meet the aspirations of indigenous people and they must therefore have control over decisions made by the corporation. This is reflected in the structure of the board of directors administering the corporation. At least five of the members must be Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders and the chairperson of ATSIC will be included as an ex officio member. In recognition of ATSIC's role as a vehicle for indigenous self-determination, at least one other member must be an ATSIC commissioner. All the directors must have experience in land or environmental management, business or financial management, or in indigenous community life.

The corporation will have significant powers to conduct its business in the interest of self-determination, including significant commercial functions. The minister also has a power to request and obtain information about the activities of the corporation in line with his or her portfolio responsibilities. As well, the minister makes the appointments to the board of directors but will do so in consultation with ATSIC and the Minister for Finance.

On another point, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has expressed reservations about the land fund. His concern is that land acquired under land fund provisions and subject to normal title holding rules will be claimed under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, and thus lead to an inappropriate increase in land held under inalienable title. This will not result from the legislation before the House today. We have included in the legislation a clause prohibiting claims under the Land Rights Act being made in relation to land acquired by the Indigenous Land Corporation.

In terms of implementation, the Native Title Act provides for the establishment of the land fund under section 201. However, it does not provide enough scope for the establishment and operations of the Indigenous Land Corporation in the way we consider essential for an effective response to the need for land. That is why this bill was necessary.

As an interim measure, the fund will be set up by regulations under the Native Title Act. We plan that the corporation begin operations on 1 January 1995 when this legislation comes into force and section 201 of the Native Title Act, which sets up the fund, will then be repealed. There is a need for the interim arrangement as moneys have already been allocated and will have to be invested pending the establishment of the Indigenous Land Corporation under this bill. ATSIC, as the body with primary responsibility for the management of indigenous affairs, will from 1 January undertake the day-to-day administrative arrangements for the fund.

Let me conclude on these points. Through millennia the indigenous people of this continent have demonstrated extraordinary strength and resilience and never more so than in the past 200 years. Since European settlement they have survived the alienation of their land, the destruction of their culture, brutality and disease, the heartbreaking severance of family and community bonds. They have survived, but the losses have been immeasurable and proof of the damage remains all too plainly to be seen.

With the native title legislation, Australia took an historic step by finally acknowledging the truth that Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders were the original owners of the continent. In the legislation before the House today, we are giving the spirit of that legislation more tangible expression. We are creating the means by which land may be returned to Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders and, with the foundation of their traditions and identity thus partially restored, we trust that they may be able to protect and revitalise their communities, their culture and their heritage. Mr Acting Speaker, I commend this bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition has carefully considered its position on this legislation since the introduction of the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill on 30 June because it attempts to address an issue of critical importance to this country—namely, the systematic disadvantage of Australia's indigenous people. It is, however, the firm belief of the coalition that this bill does not address in an adequate way the unacceptable deprivation of Aboriginal people in Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is time to test the government's bona fides. Is it serious about reconciliation and bipartisanship or are these words merely idle talk for political advantage? Are they phrases simply trundled out to hide the need for genuine debate and reform or do they have substance? Is the government serious about the things that matter—including health, education and housing—or does it just have a part-time conscience? I challenge the government to embrace our amendments to this bill. These are amendments which go to the heart of Aboriginal economic and social disadvantage. Now we will see whether the government is truly concerned with the welfare of Australia's indigenous people or whether it is simply playing for political advantage.

Before explaining why I believe this bill is inadequate and in need of reform, I feel it is appropriate to take some time to outline the nature and extent of Aboriginal disadvantage. It is important to do this because, to have a clear understanding of the problem and to have any hope of finding a solution, we must understand the heart of the problem. Land is an important aspect of Aboriginal health. The concept of Aboriginal health is a holistic one which encompasses the special and unique relationship that Aboriginal people have with the land. It is for these reasons that I support the various state mechanisms for purchasing or otherwise acquiring land for Aboriginal people.

Land is important, but to focus on land to the exclusion of other pressing issues is to ignore the facts and simply re-run previously failed policies. Land alone is no panacea for Aboriginal health, education and social problems. Health workers estimate that up to 60 per cent of Aboriginal children in the Northern Territory have hearing deficiencies as a result of infectious ear conditions. The resultant hearing loss has a very serious impact on the educational opportunities of these children.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the CLP—your party?
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

—The interventions of the member for the Northern Territory prove the point that all he wants to do is make offensive political points and not discuss the issue seriously. I think that is a very sad reflection—not only on him but on the party that endorses him. The death rate from respiratory disease—you might be interested to hear this—is 7.3 times the national average for men and 7.9 times for women.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very sad that they feel that, while the Leader of the Opposition explains some of the severe health problems of Aboriginal people, it is a matter for constant interjection and amusement. It says a great deal about the sincerity of the Australian Labor Party on all of these issues that, given half an opportunity, you will play politics. I think that is a very sad thing for Australia. If ever there was a party that made the process of reconciliation difficult, it was the Labor Party. The mortality rate of Aboriginal men and women—
—Why did you want to cut their budget by $70 million?
—You might be interested to know something about the mortality rate of Aboriginal men and women.

PARA.TAB: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister for Finance will cease interjecting.

—I rest my case. The mortality rate of Aboriginal men and women from infectious and parasitic diseases is 12.2 and 13.4 times the national average, respectively. Hepatitis B, eye infection and chronic skin infection are all common features of Aboriginal ill health and disease.

PARA.TAB: The reality of Aboriginal education is also disturbing. The proportion of Aboriginal people in the 15 to 24 age group still attending an educational institution is much lower than the national average: 23 per cent compared to 39 per cent. In this age group the proportion of indigenous Australians attending universities or colleges of advanced education is only seven per cent, compared with 18 per cent for the wider community.

In a modern industrial democracy the link between skill level, education and economic independence is undeniable. We should never forget that the first Aboriginal man to graduate from a university in this country, Charles Perkins, did so in 1965—not even 30 years ago. Compare this to the first Maori who graduated from the University of Canterbury in 1893. When I visited Central Australia recently, I saw first-hand many of the problems confronting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not seen the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), though. The chance to talk to community members and leaders was an invaluable opportunity to learn about the issues of importance to those people and communities. Time and again I saw and heard about inadequate housing, poor roads and lack of infrastructure. In every community I visited, the lack of economic opportunity was apparent, and so too was the impact of poor environmental health conditions. I chose to visit a number of remote Aboriginal communities because I am determined that a future coalition government will put in place informed and practical policies to help Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We will do this because it is intolerable to allow such appalling living conditions to remain unchallenged.

PARA.TAB: Mr O'Keefe interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Burke!

—You have been in power for 11 years. I have just read out a record of the state of Aboriginal health and education. You have had 11 years to do something about that and now you unctuously interject because we do not agree with everything you say about the handling of Aboriginal affairs. After 11 years, your record is nothing to be proud of. It is a shameful record.

PARA.TAB: We will address these issues, as I said, because we think it is intolerable to allow these things to go unchallenged. Any attempt to address seriously the disadvantage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people must begin with candid recognition of the root cause of the problem and a determination to address it. I, as most Australians do, accept that the systematic disadvantage suffered by indigenous Australians is a direct consequence of dispossession endured over the past 200 years, and that land has been an important element in that dispossession.

In that context, the matters we are attempting to address are too important to be used for political advantage. Yet this is precisely what the government has attempted to do. The argument of the government and some of its camp followers is that not to adopt their solution is to undermine the process of national reconciliation. I say that reconciliation is a process, a dynamic process, that requires the input and goodwill of all participants irrespective of race—and you might find this hard to believe—and irrespective of political persuasion.

Those who represent Australians who do not support the Australian Labor Party are entitled to be full participants in this process and they are entitled to be heard. Calling people bigots or friends of bigots because they do not support everything the Australian Labor Party proposes is, I believe, destructive to the process of reconciliation and is nationally divisive. I think that, as a country, we ought to be able to do better than that. What I am doing today is, with the best will in the world, offering the government an opportunity for a more bipartisan position. I am offering a chance—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is trickery.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I would like this on the record. The minister, who has not even seen our amendments, will sit in this parliament—and I heard him on the radio earlier this morning—and simply dismiss it all as trickery. That is how sincere you are. You are one of the most unctuous, self-righteous people I have come across. You are always preaching across that dispatch box as though to say that people who do not agree with everything you say are somehow racist, bigoted and immoral.
—I have never said that, never.
—We will not put up with that. It is the clear implication of everything you say.
—Order! The minister will cease interjecting and the Leader of the Opposition will address his remarks through the chair.
—We have put up with this for long enough, and you will not even hear our amendments. You are determined to reject them straight out.

—Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is one of the few points of order I have ever taken. The words used by the Leader of the Opposition were in breach of the standing orders. I have never used those words to describe the coalition. They were in breach of the standing orders and I ask that they be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order. The minister is making a personal explanation of sorts at an inappropriate time.

—What I am doing today is offering the government an opportunity for a more bipartisan approach. I agree with the Prime Minister that, if we can achieve a unified front in this parliament, that is for the good. But bipartisanship is not one side simply proposing a structure and expecting the other side to accept it without scrutiny or amendment. If the government accepts our challenge, we will happily give our support to the bill. We will lend our support because the fund will then truly offer not just land but scope for sustainable economic development for all indigenous people. The record of the coalition with regard to the process of national reconciliation is a proud one.
—It is appalling.

—You probably would have opposed this, I suppose, but the Fraser government passed hallmark legislation in the areas of land rights, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander economic development, and housing.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the early years of Labor's current period in office were marred by a divisive and self-serving approach to these issues. Who can forget Susan Ryan's wild boast that the problem of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander housing would be solved within a few years? The government's inept attempts to develop a national approach to land rights, which were foiled by Brian Burke and his state Labor government, is another example of Labor raising Aboriginal people's expectations to a point where they were cruelly crushed.

The period between 1990 and 1993 witnessed a genuine effort to create a more bipartisan approach to indigenous affairs and saw legislation for the establishment of the Aboriginal reconciliation council being passed with the unanimous support of the federal parliament. Similarly, there was joint acceptance of the Aboriginal deaths in custody royal commission findings. Regrettably, the period since 1993 has witnessed a return to the earlier divisive period.

The government, and more particularly the Prime Minister, must accept responsibility for undermining the process of reconciliation by seeking to use it to divide and to give advantage to themselves. The coalition whole-heartedly supports reconciliation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You unprincipled humbug.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Sit down!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister will resume his seat.

—I can see that it hurts, because the Prime Minister knows how divisive he is. He will be divisive on any issue. He is even divisive on this sensitive issue. You either agree with the government or you are bigoted. I do not think that is a mature way to conduct a debate like this.

PARA.TAB: We whole-heartedly support reconciliation, but that does not mean that we will accept this bill without improvement. Our amendments will ensure that the money from the land fund will be used to address the issues of health, housing, education and economic independence in addition to helping in the purchase of land.

The purpose of these amendments is to enhance economic independence for all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders in a variety of ways, including, as I have said, the purchase of land. The critical linkage between health, housing, education and economic independence must be acknowledged if the deprivation of indigenous Australians is to be addressed meaningfully. At present, the government's proposed land fund does not reflect an acknowledgment of this linkage and, therefore, does not provide an adequate solution to the problem.

Does the government seriously believe that, by simply purchasing more land, the health, education and economic independence of indigenous Australians will be significantly improved? Is it not the case that, where significant areas of land are in Aboriginal hands, the ill health and economic dependency of those people still remain unsatisfactory? The government has failed to address these key issues and has not explained how land alone will redress these basic problems.

As Prime Minister, I will develop a cooperative approach with the states. This will not be able to be used as an excuse for inaction by the states. It is simply a recognition that the current impasse is born of the government's failure to realise that no national scheme for the granting of indigenous land rights will be sustainable and viable without the agreement of all parties.

We cannot afford failure in this venture. To accept failure is to accept the premature death, imprisonment and impoverishment of a proud and ancient people. To accept failure is to accept the destruction of a rich and diverse culture. To accept failure is to accept the unacceptable. The price of failure is far too high.
I ask the House to accept our amendments in the spirit in which they are offered—a genuine and valid contribution to the process of reconciliation in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trickery.

—It is terribly sad that, after all the ministers of substance that we have had in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs portfolio over many years, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) should be reduced to playing politics in that way. I think it is very sad. I do not think we should in any case lose this opportunity to forge a national solution to this most pressing of national problems.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the bill itself, I want to say that the coalition will support it subject to the government accepting our amendments. Three principles govern our amendments. Firstly, the land fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation must be structured in such a way as to give priority to Aboriginal health, education and wellbeing overall. The critical element in any decision regarding the grant must be the advancement of the people as a whole. This means that the potential for economic improvement and the attainment of self-sufficiency cannot be ignored in the administration of the fund. The value and utility of the grant must be considered. To do otherwise is to abrogate our responsibility in search of a quick fix.

Secondly, we recognise that at present much of the land held by indigenous people is underused. The land management section of the bill must be strengthened and enhanced so as to give priority to the development of land which is underutilised. The failure to date of new land grants to guarantee improvements in Aboriginal health demands that resources be channelled into giving indigenous people the chance to build and develop their existing homes and communities.

Thirdly, a $1.5 billion fund must be subject to scrupulous accountability. It must be accountable to its intended beneficiaries—the indigenous people of Australia—and it must be accountable to the Australian taxpayer.

The shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), will detail to the House the amendments upon which coalition support for the bill will rest and which we trust the government will accept in good faith. Those amendments are based upon the concerns that I have outlined in this speech and upon the principles I have identified for consideration of the bill.

The House has before it an unparalleled opportunity. It is an opportunity that I give the government for bipartisan reconciliation. It is an opportunity that I believe former Labor leaders would have grasped. People like John Curtin, Ben Chifley, Arthur Calwell and Gough Whitlam would have seized the opportunity to work together with the other side of politics rather than just make cheap political points. In the course of making this speech today, which I make on behalf of the coalition and with goodwill, I can only say how disappointed I am at the response of the Prime Minister, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and some of the backbenchers.

We believe that the bill is flawed. Nevertheless, with the amendments we propose, a great step forward can be taken in the process of reconciliation. There has never been a greater chance. We now lay that chance squarely at the feet of the government. We challenge the government to put partisan politics aside and to accept our amendments. When the time comes then we can truly say that Australia has reached its maturity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear from the comments that have been made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) in addressing the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill that he is attempting to perpetrate a huge confidence trick on the people of Australia, particularly the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The Leader of the Opposition is cloaking his words seeking bipartisan support for this bill. He is really saying that, unless the government is prepared to totally overlook the purpose of this bill, totally distort what this bill is all about and fully accept all the amendments proposed by the opposition, the opposition will not support it.

PARA.TAB: That action shows that the opposition has absolutely no understanding or knowledge of what this bill is seeking to achieve nor of the importance of land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The opposition has completely lost the plot. It does not understand the fundamental tenets of this proposition. It has no commitment to a bipartisan position on Aboriginal affairs and that is to its very great shame and is a very great disappointment to us on this side of the House.

Throughout the last four years that I have been in this place, I have witnessed many efforts by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to achieve a bipartisan position on Aboriginal affairs. There was one occasion in this House when that was achieved, and that was on the passage of the legislation to establish the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. But on most other occasions the opposition has failed to accept its responsibilities in Aboriginal affairs and to take up the challenge of having a unified position in the interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That was clearly demonstrated last year by the position of opposition members on the native title legislation, and I think most of them now realise that theirs was a foolish position to adopt which marginalised them from the debate.

Unfortunately, it appears that opposition members are going to engage in that same hopeless, useless process on this legislation. What they have outlined to us today through the address of the Leader of the Opposition is that, unless this government totally changes and distorts the purpose of the land acquisition fund, they will not support it. So all the statements they have made in the last two days about now supporting the land acquisition fund have been false. It is an attempt at a confidence trick on the people of Australia and particularly the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We do not have a position where those decent people on the other side of the House, those who claim to be called the moderates, have actually had any sort of victory. Nothing could be further from the truth. Once more, we have the opposition totally controlled by the far Right, by the ideologues. That is the essence of the position that the opposition leader has just outlined to us on this legislation.

It is clear that opposition members have no understanding of the essential point of this bill, and that is the importance of land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. All of us in this House want to do something to address the appalling health situation, education situation and unemployment situation of Aboriginal people. But what members of the opposition fail to understand is that, unless we heal the spirit of the Aboriginal people, we are not going to heal the body. To heal the spirit we must address the question of land. That is the first and most essential component of our actions. The opposition 20 years ago recognised this because it established the first form of a land acquisition fund—which in recent years ATSIC has been administering—but it was just small bickies at that time.

In fact, with this legislation we are now building substantially on the initiative taken 20 years ago by the much more progressive coalition parties, which were in power at that time. I take this opportunity to try to instil into this debate some sense and understanding about what land means. I will start by quoting Mick Dodson, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner:

To fully understand why land rights are so important to indigenous peoples, you have to move out of the paradigm that sees land as purely a commodity to be exploited. . . For us, land has a spiritual, cultural, political and economic value. It supports our identity, our spirit, our social relations, our integrity and our survival. Land is the source of our physical and spiritual sustenance. Removed from our land we are literally removed from ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: To understand the importance and significance of this legislation we are debating today and its contribution to the wellbeing of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, non-Aboriginal Australians have to throw off their European cultural and economic values and open their eyes, their hearts and their minds to what it is to be an Aboriginal person.

PARA.TAB: There is an enormous body of evidence and argument, stretching back over more than 100 years, which explains the importance of land to Aboriginal people. Yet, despite this overwhelming evidence, despite the fact that the right to land has been the unifying campaign of Aboriginal people for more than 30 years in this country and despite the recognition of this by our most important legal institution—the High Court—in its Mabo No. 2 decision, we still witness the unedifying spectacle of members of the opposition desperately grappling with this basic tenet. The position of opposition members on this legislation further demonstrates that they still have lost the plot and do not understand.

To set this debate into some context and to try to assist the opposition members to come to grips with the reality rather than their rhetoric that we have just been exposed to from their leader, I would like to spend some time responding to the proposition that the government is wasting the money on land acquisition when the greater priorities are health, housing, et cetera. I would like to quote from the introductory section of the National Aboriginal Health Strategy Report of March 1989:

SPEECH.PARA: "Health" to Aboriginal peoples is a matter of determining all aspects of their life, including control over their physical environment, of dignity, of community self-esteem, and of justice. It is not merely a matter of the provision of doctors, hospitals, medicines or the absence of disease and incapacity.

Traditional Aboriginal social systems include a three-dimensional model that provides a blue-print for living. Such a social system is based on inter-relationships between people and land, people and creator beings, and between people, which ideally stipulates inter-dependence within and between each set of relationships.
ABORIGINAL SPIRITUALITY WAS, AND IS, ESSENTIALLY LAND-CENTRED.

Aboriginal people were totally dependent on the land and on all it could provide. To cope with this, they developed a social organisation that would enable them to use their natural environment successfully.

The Aboriginal health methods practised then are often still prominent in the delivery of health care in many Aboriginal communities today. This is despite the introduction of Western style health systems which are primarily interested in the recognition and treatment of disease. Aboriginal medicine seeks to provide a meaningful explanation for illness and to respond to the personal, family, and community issues surrounding illness. Aboriginal medicine and practices are a complex system closely linked to land based cultural beliefs. For this reason, Aborigines in contemporary Australia see health as a sovereign issue—

a land issue. To understand it from a traditional Aboriginal cultural perspective, I would like to quote Mrs Nellie Camfoo, the Deputy Chairman of the Aboriginal Protection Authority of the Northern Territory:

One thing we have talked about a lot at meetings is the need to explain to. . . (Europeans) about the responsibilities custodians carry under Aboriginal tradition. For my people ceremony is life for us, body for us, culture for us. We are all ceremony people.

In our law if say. . . (the Europeans are) digging and breaking up that ceremony ground and other ceremony leaders know we have been selling out or have done a lot of damage to it we are going to get "sung". That's why we believe that, when say mining people come and dig up a sacred site, we are going to die. If other people don't kill us, we are gonna get sick and die.
When he ruins our "ceremony area" by mining, that's our body he's busted up. He dig that, that's our body, and all that stone that's our culture.

To give another perspective to this concept, I quote from an article by John Avery provided by the Aboriginal Areas Protection Authority in its submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs:

Where Aborigines live in proximity to traditional lands, identification with land, which is substantially through sacred sites, has far reaching implications. The tendency to live close to ancestral territories is a corollary of the tendency to live with relatives: a graph of the relationship between geographical and genealogical distances among Aboriginal people typically would show a relatively smooth decline of genealogical relatedness with distance.

PARA.TAB: In this social order, landedness and kinship combine in a cultural vocabulary which defines where and with whom Aboriginal people live, with whom they marry, their social relationships, the organisation of rites of passage, their roles in sacred ceremonies and a broad spectrum of other rights including the allocation of non-Aboriginal resources and collective or community property.

SPEECH.PARA: The Mabo decision in the government's native title legislation, combined with the Northern Territory land rights act and other acts of state governments, has gone a considerable way towards addressing the land needs of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders living in rural and remote areas or on their traditional lands. However, almost 70 per cent of Australia's 260,000 indigenous people live in cities and towns and have not had their land needs addressed.

PARA.TAB: These are the people and the descendants of people who have been the victims of the colonisation process. They are the dispossessed. It is wrong, however, to consider that they have lost their spiritual connections to land. In the national report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, this point is made very clearly:

The significance of land to Aboriginal people who have moved or been moved to other places as a result of colonisation is one that is perhaps less understood by non-Aboriginal people, yet the population of Aboriginal people who have moved away from traditional lands or experienced a complete transformation of their relationship to land, at least in the economic sphere, is a very significant proportion of the population.

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding this break from specific traditional attachments to land that some Aboriginal groups in the more remote areas of Australia have been able to maintain, Aboriginal people in the settled areas of Australia have continued to maintain the core elements of their spiritual association with land. This association is an assertion of their Aboriginality. Their loss requires redress that is, in essence, the same, even though the form of redress may vary considerably.

In essence, the message is clear: as I said before, we cannot heal the body unless we first heal the spirit of Aboriginal people. The spirit of Aboriginal and Islander people is intertwined and interconnected with land. Access to the land and rights over land are essential to the achievement of better physical, social, economic and cultural outcomes for Aboriginal and Islander people.

PARA.TAB: The other important point that needs to be made is that, for many Aboriginal people, there is at present no security in their occupation of some lands or their current housing. Without securing title and therefore control over their own land, Aboriginal and Islander people cannot secure the necessary funding to provide the infrastructure which will raise their living standards. They need title to the land. They need security in their occupancy. They also need a commitment to build the water supply, the sewerage systems, the garbage disposal systems, the roads and drainage, the recreational facilities, the housing, the educational services and the medical services. As Lois O'Donoghue, Chairperson of ATSIC, said earlier this year:

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot divorce the issue of land from others that will affect our well-being . . . Land will not automatically give Aboriginal people physical health—although spiritual health is another matter. This will only happen when governments . . . put their rhetoric into action and provide their Aboriginal citizens with the basics—housing, sewerage and the other infrastructure. At least if Aboriginal people owned their own land, that's one less excuse for governments to justify their inaction.

A central objective of the land acquisition fund, strongly supported by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, is its focus on greater independence and self-reliance for indigenous people. They do not want to be forever dependent on the government. They wish to build a self-reliant future for themselves and their families. The land fund will contribute to the achievement of that objective. This land fund is consistent with the key recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which recognised dispossession as the root cause of the disempowerment and marginalisation of Aboriginal and Islander people in Australian society.

PARA.TAB: It is totally inappropriate and unacceptable that the Leader of the Opposition says that the opposition wants the funds which the government has allocated to go to the land acquisition fund diverted into what he sees and states are the more important priorities of health, education and housing. There is not a pecking order of priorities. Those things have equal priority. It is clear from the comments made by the Leader of the Opposition today that, unless we support his distortion of the use of those funds in that way and the transference of the money that has been allocated for the purchase of land to those other services, he will not support this bill.

As the Leader of the Opposition well knows, this government has been involved in a number of initiatives to address those other issues. In the budget in which we allocated the first $200 million to the land acquisition fund we also included a substantial increase in the allocation of funds for Aboriginal health. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) achieved a substantial increase in the budget allocation for Aboriginal health. Of course we would all like to see much more, and we will continue to fight for more. As opposition members well know, there is still a social justice package to be completed by the government which will be announced next year and which will contain further increases.

This is not the be-all and end-all of our initiatives for Aboriginal people in this country. It builds upon the national Aboriginal health strategy; it builds upon the Commonwealth's comprehensive response to the recommendations arising from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody; it builds upon the government's establishment of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation; it builds upon the passage of the native title legislation last year; and it will build upon the substantial increase in Aboriginal health expenditure that was contained in this budget. It is one more important plank; it is not the only plank.

There is only one person in this House who has been attempting to distort the purposes of this land acquisition fund to score cheap political points on the Aboriginal funding issue and that is the Leader of the Opposition. His attempt to score cheap political points today by trying to make out that he is opening the arms of a bipartisan position on this, and that it is up to the government to accept or reject it, is a total distortion of the facts.

With no opportunity to understand exactly what the opposition's policy would be, because we have not seen any policy documents from the current Leader of the Opposition, all we can do to reflect upon what the opposition would do if it were in government at this time is look at its last policy manifesto. Let us compare what that contained with the rhetoric we heard just recently from the Leader of the Opposition. It is important to understand that, had this country had the misfortune to elect the coalition in March last year, we would have seen from a coalition government a $90 million a year cut in expenditure on Aboriginal health and housing. That is the reality of the opposition's policy position.

The only ones who have been engaging in political point scoring and rhetoric today have been those opposite. I am disappointed, when I heard that the opposition was in fact going to support this land acquisition fund, that I had been misled. It is clear that that has not been, never has been, and never will be its position. Those opposite have no understanding of the significance of this bill. The challenge is for some reasonable members of the opposition to at least accept their responsibilities and support this bill. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I express my disappointment at the way in which the government dealt with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) today when he was making his speech. I might note that members of the opposition sat in silence while we listened to the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and I would have asked for the same courtesy from those on the government benches, which we did not receive. I think it raises a very important point of how this government has sought to use Aboriginal affairs as a political and divisive issue.

PARA.TAB: I must express my disappointment that the current Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), who is at the table, has allowed himself to be used in this way. May I point out that the minister wrote to churches urging them to come to the coalition to urge us to support the fund. This was a very nice political ploy. He did not write to them in private; he let the press know of his letters. It would have been very good if the minister had actually come to me as the shadow minister and said, `We want to sit down; let's talk.' If we had not had any sort of meeting, he could then have written to the churches. But to have done what he did to gain publicity and then look holier than thou I think is not worthy of the minister at the table. May I say that I felt very disappointed that he had taken that attitude.

The disadvantage faced by Australia's indigenous people is very real. Last century and earlier this century, many were dispossessed from their land. They were denied the full rights of citizenship, and, because of their isolation and because of the prejudice and ignorance of others, their children were denied the equality of opportunity afforded to every other Australian child. The latter half of this century has seen a series of attempts by all governments—Labor and Liberal; state and federal—to address the problems of a century and a half of neglect.

Unlike previous governments, this government has attempted to make a political issue out of addressing the disadvantages faced by Aboriginals. In doing so, it belittles the genuine plight of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. In seeking dramatic and often popular solutions, it fails to address many of the real problems facing Australia's indigenous people. Addressing the problems faced by indigenous Australians requires thoughtful measures that go to the source of the problems.

Despite the government's efforts—many of which I believe are sincere, many of which are misguided and many of which are simply populist—a great deal of its actions have failed to address the real issues. This brings me to the comments of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), who misquoted what the Leader of the Opposition said and accused the opposition of diverting funds from the land fund to other issues. I point out to the honourable member for Moreton, who was not interested in remaining in the House to hear what I have to say, that he has got it wrong. The actions of the honourable member in leaving the House show the real level of interest of those opposite in this debate. I suggest that, if the interest of those opposite matched their rhetoric, their side would not be—as it is now—empty except for those speakers preparing to speak on the bill.

How will this land fund advantage Aboriginal people? Nowhere have I heard this question addressed—not specifically, not generally and not in the second reading speech of the Prime Minister—and that is one of the great absences in the bill. The coalition accepts that land is and always has been central to Aboriginal culture and that alienation from the land suffered by many Aboriginal people has been a cause, but not the total cause, of many of the problems they now face. However, some of the communities suffering from the worst health problems and the poorest education of their children do own their own land. The people in these communities suffer from poor housing, bad water and appalling sanitation conditions. I have seen those conditions, and the minister at the table has seen them. Therefore, land by itself is not enough.

Giving land to people in an Aboriginal community does not in itself improve their health, housing and educational standards. The coalition accepts that for outback Aboriginal people at least it is an important part of the solution to the problem. But, as I have said, we will not accept that land alone is the solution to a host of very real and genuine problems. Consequently, we will be seeking amendments to this bill to ensure that, before land is purchased for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, the Indigenous Land Corporation—which is set up by this bill to purchase land to hand to corporations and, hopefully, to be bought by individuals—must show how that purchase will improve the health, housing or education of that community. This measure is central.

There are dozens of communities in outback Australia in which Aboriginal people are living by Third World standards. We do not want the money from this fund to be used to perpetuate that situation. Where land is bought it must be shown that the condition of the community on that land will improve—their living, economic, housing and health conditions, and everything else that goes to making a healthy community.

We seek demonstrable benefits to Aboriginal communities as a key condition for purchasing land. We will therefore be making that a key amendment at the consideration in detail stage of the bill, along with other key amendments which I will be listing soon.

The bill before us today is so general as to be directionless. It has not addressed the key questions. In setting up the Indigenous Land Corporation it does not give direction as to what are the key purposes for buying land, how purchases will assist either outback or urban Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, who is to be assisted, who is not to be assisted, and how determinations are made between competing claims on the fund. There is no indication whatsoever in the bill.

The Prime Minister originally made claims that led Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians to believe that Aboriginal people would have almost $1.5 billion to spend on land. Technically this may be correct, but the real figure that is available for the purchase of land is $45 million per year indexed, of which $21 million is already available through the ATSIC land fund. Therefore, the only new money available for the purchase of land by Aboriginal people is $24 million per year indexed. This $24 million will not go totally to the purchase of land. Some of it will go on administration and some will go on the upgrading of newly bought land and existing Aboriginal properties.

The latter use of the fund is supported by the coalition, as there is a need to provide funds to return Aboriginal owned stations to productivity. One of the problems we have faced is that many of the stations that are owned by Aboriginal people are not productive. The funds have not been available to allow them to upgrade—to provide fences, to provide capital equipment. They have been taken out of the stock of Australia's wealth. That has not assisted Aboriginal people and it has not assisted the economic status of Australia.

What has happened in this bill is a long way from the Prime Minister's original rhetoric. With the exception of Tasmania and Victoria, the states already provide mechanisms for acquiring land for Aboriginal people. As there is a danger of a plethora of land funds competing with each other and of lacking coordination, we do not see the need for a separate land fund in ATSIC and the Indigenous Land Corporation. We will therefore be moving that these two funds be combined into one as soon as the ILC is operational so that the ILC will retain $45 million per annum instead of $24 million.

The bill makes reference to national and regional land strategies. However, it is extraordinarily vague. There is no real requirement for the ILC to produce strategies that stand up to scrutiny that would be expected of similar organisations, nor is there a requirement that the strategies be in place before land is purchased. We will therefore be moving in the detail stage of this bill that the national land strategy be a disallowable instrument in both houses of parliament. The minister will be required to table in the parliament the national indigenous land strategy and the ILC will be able to commence its land purchases only after the strategy has sat on the table for 15 days.

This in no way lessens the powers of the ILC; it is asking for a level of detail and accountability that would be expected from any organisation which has a budget of $45 million a year. As the strategy is a disallowable instrument, the parliament will not be able to change it but only send it back to the ILC if the parliament believes the ILC has not provided a strategy that properly fulfils its brief or if the strategy in some way contravenes the legislation.

I referred before to the land programs of the states. As it is important that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land fund and the land acquisition programs of the states not be in conflict and do not overlap, we will be moving an amendment that ensures the regional land strategies be implemented in concert with the states and territories.

We also want to address the composition of the board. The coalition would like to see the qualification requirements tightened as at present a situation could arise where no board member has experience in the areas of either business and commerce or land management. The coalition also believes that the states should have a nominee on the board to ensure that the land acquisition and management functions of the board are coordinated with the states.

I would now like to speak specifically to some of the amendments that we will be raising. At this stage they are in general form only. We will be moving them in their specific form in the consideration in detail stage of this bill. First and foremost, as I foreshadowed earlier in my speech, we wish to change the focus of the bill so that when the ILC purchases land it must show there will be an improvement in health, housing and the economic situation of the Aboriginal community for which the land is purchased.

I have already mentioned that we wish the national land strategy to be a disallowable instrument, and that no land be purchased by the ILC until that land strategy has sat on the table for 15 days to allow the scrutiny of parliament. This does not mean that the parliament can amend the strategy; it simply means that the parliament can return it to the ILC if it finds it deficient, as would be the case with any similar organisation. I have also foreshadowed that the regional land strategy must be drawn up in consultation with the states and through the states with local government.

The board of the ILC should be appointed on the basis of skill and experience in investment. Land acquisition and management and other significant roles required in the corporation are not limited to only five Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. There are many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders with skills, and their talents should be used in the corporation. It is paternalism indeed to expect that Aboriginal people would not have these skills, and to suggest that the board could not comprise only Aboriginal people who have such skills.

In purchasing land, priority must go to those areas where Aboriginal people cannot claim native title. You will remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, that native title was the reason for this bill in the first place. All the rhetoric of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs said that we need to provide land for people who cannot benefit from the Native Title Bill, yet there is nothing in this bill that addresses that issue whatsoever—and it must be addressed in this bill.

We will be moving that the upgrading of Aboriginal and pastoral properties be given priority in those areas where there is already a substantial land-holding for Aboriginal people. It is important that Aboriginal people on those properties be able to use them as viable economic concerns. We will also be moving that the money from ATSIC be incorporated into the ILC so that there is only one land fund and not two.

They will be amendments that we will be moving in the House of Representatives, but that is not the full comprehensive list of amendments. There will be a series of other amendments that we will be moving in the Senate because we will be asking that this bill be passed to a Senate committee for consideration. There are many weaknesses in this bill that I, as an individual, am not competent to address, and neither is this parliament, without input from those people whom the bill affects. For that reason, we will be moving in the Senate that it goes to a Senate committee to be properly and thoroughly examined.

However, at this stage, I want to clearly foreshadow some of the amendments we will be moving in the Senate so there can be no doubt as to where we stand on this bill. We wish to exclude the possibility of native title on land purchases. We do this because we believe that Aboriginal people, like other Australians, have the right, as do other Australians, to have land able to be dealt with by future generations unencumbered by special title. Therefore, land purchased is to keep the title of freehold or leasehold under which it is purchased with no special additions or deductions. To do otherwise is to treat Aboriginal people as if they were different or inadequate in the area of land ownership.

We will also be moving that the fund include individual ownership of land. We note this bill allows the ownership of land only by corporations. We believe there are families, individuals, trusts and Aboriginal partnerships that should benefit from this fund and should be able to use moneys from the fund in a wide variety of ways to set up businesses—which could include ecotourism businesses but would not be limited to them; there is a whole range of possible businesses. As I have said, there is no reason why, with Aboriginal people, legislation should not include individuals and families, but always a corporation, and why Aboriginal people should differ in this from other Australians.

We will be exploring ways to identify land that has an ILC interest for those innocent third parties who might be caught up. That is a detail of the bill that we will be going through further. States should have a nominee on the ILC board and a suitable mechanism should be available. This is an important amendment. I would have preferred to have been able to move it in the House of Representatives. I am not doing so because obviously a mechanism has to be found to do this and, as the in detail stage will be tomorrow, there is simply not the time for us to negotiate what sort of mechanism might be available. That is why that will be moved in the Senate. (Extension of time granted)

I thank the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your indulgence in granting me an extension of time. I also thank the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) for seeking that extension.

TALK.START.PARA: —And those of us who voted for it.

—And those who voted for it. Assistance for the economic development of land should include the possibility of assistance to minority Aboriginal interests. As the bill stands at the moment, there has to be a 50 per cent interest of Aboriginal people for a group to be considered as an Aboriginal corporation under the bill. We can envisage the situation where there would be fewer Aboriginal people, perhaps 25 per cent, involved in a business interest. We believe that assistance should be able to go to that minority group which does not have a 50 per cent interest. Again, we will be looking at this in the Senate to find an appropriate way of wording such an amendment.

PARA.TAB: We would also wish to move that the land subject to native title should not be able to be purchased. A provision to ensure that a non-claimant application is lodged to give notice to potential native title claimants prior to any contract being entered into for the purchase of land is a potential safeguard for native title claimants themselves.

I have flagged a number of amendments that we will be making in the Senate. We are not limiting ourselves to these amendments alone. We are very serious about these amendments, but we will be extending them in the Senate after this bill hopefully goes to a Senate committee and we hear evidence and submissions from people who will be affected by this bill.

In conclusion, the coalition is very sincere in its efforts to be part of the Aboriginal reconciliation in this country. We acknowledge the genuine and real problems facing Aboriginal people today. We acknowledge that in the past what has been done has often been done with goodwill but, in the end, it has not served the interests of Aboriginal people. I would ask the minister to have dialogue with the opposition.

I reiterate the words of the Leader of the Opposition that bipartisanship does not mean the opposition simply saying yes to the government. It means that the government must come to the opposition, sit down and negotiate to reach a solution that is acceptable to both sides. If the government is prepared to do that, the opposition is more than willing to do that, but we will not simply say yes in the interests of bipartisanship. We will fight hard for what we believe are the correct ways to address the real and genuine issues of Aboriginal disadvantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill this afternoon. Firstly, I want to make a few remarks about the previous speakers this afternoon, particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), my colleague the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and the opposition spokesperson on Aboriginal and Islander affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), who has just completed her contribution.

PARA.TAB: I think we have seen a clear distinction here today between the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. The Prime Minister's contribution showed his very caring approach to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and showed the commitment of this Labor government to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The attack today by the Leader of the Opposition on the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), who is at the table and who is now the longest serving minister in that portfolio, was frivolous and unfounded.

The Leader of the Opposition should have withdrawn his remarks earlier today, because they were certainly not correct. Both the Prime Minister and the minister have been trying to work towards a bipartisan position on the plight of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this country. We are very proud of this, particularly the efforts that the minister has made in this area.

Some of the attacks made by the Leader of the Opposition today are frivolous and should be considered as such. It is the opposition, certainly not honourable members on this side of the House, which is trying to turn this bill into a political issue. We have worked collectively with the whole community and have tried to include the opposition in that process, but it has another agenda. The Leader of the Opposition certainly has an agenda and I think it is his survival as Leader of the Opposition. That is what he has been on about over recent weeks.

Earlier in the debate when the Prime Minister was speaking I looked up to the galleries at the young children from the various schools that visit parliament. In years to come those children will look back and say, `Yes, I was there when the Prime Minister spoke on that land acquisition bill.' It must have been a proud occasion for those children to see the great commitment by our Prime Minister to the process of reconciliation with the Aboriginal people, as distinct from that of the Leader of the Opposition. I am sure that all his colleagues opposite must be feeling somewhat wounded by his miserable contribution here today and his miserable efforts as the Leader of the Opposition in the reconciliation process since he has been the Leader of the Opposition.

It is indeed a great pleasure to have this opportunity to support one of the most important pieces of legislation that this House has debated in the interests of this nation, as it was with the Native Title Bill at the end of last year. It is quite appropriate that we are discussing the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill at this time, coming as it does so soon after Cathy Freeman's wonderful display of pride in the heritage of her people at the Commonwealth Games last week and over the weekend. I know that some honourable members do not agree with that but they should understand that pride, essentially, is at the centre of this bill—Aborigines' and Torres Strait Islanders' pride in their present day selves, pride in their past and hope for their future.

There can be no such pride when people are continually reminded on a daily basis that they have been denied social justice. The main purpose of this bill is to bring an end to that feeling by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land fund to provide for the acquisition of land for Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders who are unable to benefit from native title. I make that point because, clearly, the opposition spokesperson on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs does not understand that and nor does the Leader of the Opposition. So the opposition's other speakers might like to correct the ignorance of their colleagues who have already spoken on this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know better than that.
—And the honourable member for Maranoa knows it too, so when he makes his contribution he might be able to correct his leader and the honourable member for Hindmarsh who are dead-set wrong.

PARA.TAB: The bill also establishes an Indigenous Land Corporation to manage the acquisition of land and to provide for the management of indigenous held land. On 3 June 1992 the High Court handed down its historic Mabo decision in recognising the existence of native title in Australia: native title survived only if the traditional owners had maintained their connection with the land, and if no inconsistent title over the land had been granted to someone else. As most Aboriginal people would not benefit from native title, having previously been dispossessed of their traditional lands, the government announced that it would establish a land fund to allow the acquisition of land for these groups.

The Prime Minister, in his second reading speech on that most historic piece of legislation, the Native Title Bill 1993, observed that the Mabo decision gives little more than a sense of justice to those Aboriginal communities whose native title has been extinguished or lost. He went on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: While these communities remain dispossessed of land their economic marginalisation and their sense of injury continues. As a first step, we are establishing a land fund. It will enable indigenous people to acquire land and to manage and maintain it in a substantial way in order to provide economic, social and cultural benefits for future generations.

I would like to add some telling statistics to that statement to illustrate the position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders whose desperate social situation is still misunderstood by many Australians.

PARA.TAB: The following figures are taken from the June 1994 edition of the Aboriginal and Islander Health Worker Journal. It says that ATSI peoples' death rates are three times that of the general population; their infant and perinatal mortality rates are three times that of the general population; life expectancy is 15 to 20 years less than non-ATSI people; 33 per cent of Aboriginal men live to their 65th birthday, whereas 75 per cent of non-Aboriginal men live to 65; and 50 per cent of Aboriginal women live till their 65th birthday but 90 per cent of non-Aboriginal women live to 65.

To quote Mick Dodson, these are the figures of death. And such conditions are not accidental—they are related to the social standing of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who, because of two centuries of neglect, suffer endemic poverty and have little control over the only resource they have: land.

This legislation seeks to attack the social conditions that follow upon dispossession. The government's specific objectives in establishing the land fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation are to enable indigenous people to acquire land and to manage it in a sustainable way, and to provide self-generating economic, social and cultural benefits. The establishment of a self-sustaining capital fund will provide a secure and ongoing source of funds for the Indigenous Land Corporation to spend on land acquisition and management. This will provide Aboriginal and Islander groups with the vital increments which are so necessary for a well-planned, long-term strategy to raise their socioeconomic standing.

I said before that few Australians have a real understanding of Aboriginal and Islander issues—of course, that is specifically the case with members of the opposition. This lack of real understanding is not necessarily anyone's fault; rather, it is a result of a lack of education of indigenous issues in past generations. For instance, how many average Australians know that the majority of ATSI people live in major and smaller urban areas as opposed to rural areas? You would think those opposite believe that the country is the only place where they live. Yet the idea persists in some sections of the community that the only legitimate Aborigines are those living a traditional lifestyle. It points out how much further as a nation we have to go in the reconciliation process.

The provisions of this bill are aimed at those people who can no longer live on their traditional lands. Figures released earlier this year by the Centre for Aboriginal Economic Policy Research in its discussion paper titled The Relative Economic Status of Indigenous People in Queensland 1986-91 showed that a large majority of indigenous people live in urban areas. Between 1986 and 1991, the number of Aborigines living in cities and major urban areas went from 9,695 to 13,922—a 43.6 per cent change—representing more than a quarter of the Queensland Aboriginal population. A similar trend emerged in smaller urban areas. In 1986 there were 21,218 Aboriginal people living in these areas; by 1991 the figure had increased to 24,000—a 13 per cent change. That 24,000 represented 43 per cent of the Aboriginal population at the time.

However, the paper reveals a different story in rural and outback areas—supposedly the domain of Aboriginal people. In 1986 there were 17,185 Aboriginal people living in the Queensland country. By 1991 this figure had hardly moved—there was an increase of 420 persons to 17,605, a two per cent change. This group represented 31 per cent of the total Aboriginal population in Queensland—only six per cent more than the number in cities and 12 per cent less than in smaller urban areas.

A similar story emerges with Torres Strait Islanders. Between 1986 and 1991, the number living in cities increased by 95.4 per cent, giving a total of 2,730—or 19 per cent of the total Islander population. There was a slight decline in numbers in smaller urban areas, but a 28 per cent increase in rural areas was an early indicator that the drift away from the Torres Strait in the 1980s—which in 1986 saw 62 per cent of the Torres Strait Islander population of Queensland living in areas located away from the Strait—may be reversing.

It is unfortunate that several members opposite, when given a chance to show bipartisan support for the promise of this bill, have chosen to make some questionable comments. Those members range from the Leader of the Opposition—whose contribution to the process prior to last night's announcement was to repeal the act—to the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), whose outburst over Cathy Freeman last week has, I would suggest, given greater impetus to the debate about our national identity than just about anything else that has occurred. The member for Groom probably would not agree with me, but I think he knows that the majority of Australians were on Cathy's side when he made those comments. He was not interested in appealing to the majority of Australians; I would suggest that he was only interested in the extreme Right in his own electorate. It is unfortunate that he is not here to take part in this debate—he is overseas at the moment. But I, along with everyone else here, would have been very interested in his comments on this legislation.

It is interesting to note the remarks made by the former leader of the opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who said on radio over the weekend—after being so shabbily treated by his current leader—that he fears for the future of the Liberal Party. He is not the only one. He said that the Liberal Party is in danger of being taken over by the hard Right.
