This man is the architect of Fightback, which proposed cutting off unemployment benefits after nine months, reducing industrial protection for workers, introducing below award wages, slashing social security and other government spending, and destroying the public health system. And he says that he is worried about the hard Right taking over! I am glad that we had a caring, sharing opposition when he was around.

I wonder whether we saw the first sign of that takeover when the current Leader of the Opposition said in Western Australia four weeks ago that he would repeal the Native Title Act if the opposition won government. That statement astonished me—and, I am sure, millions of other Australians. It certainly was a disappointing shock for indigenous people in this country. After the last few years of the community and government coming together on this issue in order to forward the cause of the reconciliation process, we now hear that sort of remark from the party that aspires to lead the country.

Repealing the Native Title Act would be a slap in the face of true progress and justice in Australia and would constitute a threat to the sense of unified nationhood achieved with the passing of the native title legislation last year in the International Year of the World's Indigenous People. Having had the opportunity to see quite a few Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities first-hand as a member of the House of Representative Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, I can say that we still have a long way to go in the reconciliation process. The last thing we need is comments like those from the Leader of the Opposition made to a room full of miners and the Western Australian tory government.

What we need from members in this place is leadership. We have that leadership from the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, who is at the table. Members on this side of the chamber are prepared to show that leadership in this place and to show our community that we really do have a commitment to reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I put it to those opposite that they should find a little bit of goodwill amongst their people to do something about aiding the true reconciliation process with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. There is no indication of that happening now. We, as elected representatives in this place, must show that leadership. There is no leadership in the Liberal Party or the National Party at the present time that is anything like what is needed. They really do not have any commitment to the reconciliation process and now is the time for them to change their attitude and I challenge them to do so.

Nevertheless, I must give credit where credit is due. We all welcome the announcement by the opposition that it will support this land fund bill. However, that is undermined by the amendments proposed by the opposition as conditions of that support. That is certainly some sort of Clayton's support. I would have liked to comment on some of those amendments but I will have to leave it until we consider them in detail later in this debate. They are not available to me and they are not available to the minister; I asked him about that before. How do those opposite expect us to respond to some of the comments they made earlier today? Of course, we cannot respond. Those opposite certainly do not want to debate the frivolous amendments that they will put forward.

I must say that I was unaware of the Leader of the Opposition's newspaper column until the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) brought it to my attention in question time yesterday. I listened to the quote she took from that column where the Leader of the Opposition wrote that he recognised the link between the issue of land and the health of indigenous Australians. I am encouraged by this statement but, given his recent public comments and his further comments here today, it tends to confuse anyone trying to ascertain the opposition's stance on the issue.

I think everyone in this place—and, I would venture to say, most fair-minded Australians—would acknowledge that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders are still the most disadvantaged group in the country. With regard to housing, health, education and employment, there is still a lot of room for improvement. We on this side of the chamber acknowledge that and that is why we are debating this issue today.

At the core of their social position is the issue of land. My colleague the member for Moreton said earlier that the problems in housing and the other areas can all be traced back to indigenous peoples being dispossessed of their traditional lands. For indigenous people, the connection with the land is essential for their spiritual wellbeing. The cutting of this connection has led to a deep feeling of loss which makes it difficult for many of them to participate fully in contemporary Australian society.

The figures I mentioned before illustrate the fact that the majority of indigenous people do not maintain traditional links with their lands, and so they will find no benefit in the Native Title Act. The government set out to provide other social justice measures, of which the land fund is the most significant, as part of an integrated package to benefit as many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as possible. A recognition and understanding by the wider community of indigenous people's connections to the land and sea was one of the eight key issues for reconciliation identified by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in its Review of key issue papers 1-8: addressing the key issues for reconciliation.

If enacted, this bill will establish a new land fund to be called the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land fund, or the land fund, which will take over the money allocated to the land fund established by the Native Title Act. One of the reasons for setting up a new land fund was that the fund established by section 201 restricted the money to be spent on land management to those properties acquired under the fund.

The new land fund allows money to be spent on land management for any indigenous held properties regardless of whether they are acquired under the land fund or through the native title process. The new land fund is also placed within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 rather than the Native Title Act, and its detail is provided for in legislation rather than regulations.

An important issue in this debate is that this new land fund process cannot be accused—as some sections of the community continually do—of giving handouts. After 10 years, the land fund will have significant capital to be able to make payments to the Indigenous Land Corporation from the interest generated by its investments. The land fund is to remain the property of the Commonwealth.

The bill will also establish the Indigenous Land Corporation, or ILC, which will receive an indexed amount from the land fund each year. Until the 1997-98 financial year, the ILC will receive an annual indexed sum of only $24 million because ATSIC will continue to receive the $21 million it currently uses for land acquisition and management.

I wish to raise a few more points about the bill, but I think time will beat me. We can probably come back to those points at a later stage when this bill is dealt with in detail. There is a wide scope for further debate on this bill, and I hope that we can have that. One could speak for a long time on the various aspects of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs and how the land fund and the ILC will benefit those people. However, I wish to make a few more points. There can be no doubt that reconciliation in this country is perhaps the biggest issue we face both now and in the future. The future will condemn us if we do not get it right now.

This bill, together with the Native Title Act, gives us as a nation the opportunity to address these important issues in a practical way. Our nation will be brought together when all groups in this country can come forward to take their rightful places in this society. We all knew and loved Oodgeroo Noonuccal, who recognised the importance of future generations in the reconciliation process. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three years ago, I reached across the table in this House and shook the hand of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). That was the one and only time that has happened in this House, and I am not sure whether it happened in the old House. Let me tell you how it came about.

PARA.TAB: In 1990, the then Prime Minister wrote to the then Leader of the Opposition and asked whether there was a possibility of a more bipartisan approach to Aboriginal affairs. We in the opposition discussed that in opposition committees, in the shadow cabinet and in the party room. The Leader of the Opposition wrote back to the Prime Minister.

Some months later, the Prime Minister again wrote to the Leader of the Opposition to see whether there might be any possibility of supporting a council for Aboriginal reconciliation. Again, we debated that within the party. I was the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs at the time. I went around the country and discussed the issue with every state and territory leader of the coalition in Australia. We had some concerns and the Leader of the Opposition wrote back to the Prime Minister.

During the six months that this took place, the minister and I talked and expressed our concerns. I drank his whiskey and he drank my red wine. We got some draft legislation. In fact, the coalition saw it before it came into the House. It never leaked or became public. We told the government of the areas with which we had difficulty. As shadow minister, I took that legislation around the country. Again, I discussed it with every state and territory leader in the country.

Major legislation was introduced. We still had some minor concerns, although the minister had already addressed a lot of them. In the end, when this debate came into the House, we did not get everything we wanted and the government did not get everything it wanted. But we were able to have this legislation passed with the unanimous support of the parliament after nine months of work between government and opposition. That has relevance today as I think we can learn something about the process that occurred back then. It tells us how we might go forward in the debate of helping Australia's Aboriginal people.

I heard the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) say the opposition has never had any commitment to bipartisanship in Aboriginal affairs beyond the council for reconciliation. I would remind him of the response to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I would remind him of the response and approach to the national Aboriginal health strategy. I would remind him that for the first three years ATSIC was able to establish itself in a constructive environment, in an environment where criticism was meant to help not hinder and an environment where ATSIC may not exist today had that not occurred.

In the last 18 months, the Aboriginal affairs debate in this country has not been an easy one and at times it has been personally distressing to me. I can remember the Chairperson of ATSIC, Lois O'Donoghue, coming to the coalition and asking for a generosity of spirit. In the political debate we are having here, that generosity of spirit is perhaps the most important thing we could find, and it is the ingredient that is missing at the moment. Without that generosity of spirit, I do not think we are going to achieve very much.

I admit we have not been 100 per cent correct, but I do not accept we have been 100 per cent wrong either. Last year when debating the native title legislation in this parliament I talked about how the debate on Aboriginal affairs is essentially one of false choices—a debate where things are portrayed as black and white, where things are portrayed as extremes and where it is portrayed as, `You are either for me or against me; you support this legislation or you do not care about the welfare or advancement of Aboriginal people.' That debate was destructive.

I finished my speech by saying I hoped we could put this debate behind us. We have yet to do that. But there is the possibility of doing that, and I think that possibility exists here. This legislation is a turning point. I believe in the future people will look back and make an assessment whether that opportunity was seized or wasted. The start is not terribly good.

This morning on the radio the minister said he was hoping that we were not going to have political trickery. The Chairperson of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, the member for Moreton, was in this House a few minutes ago accusing us of a massive fraud. I would ask them for a little generosity of spirit too, to perhaps try to take this debate away from party politics.

This bill goes to the very heart of Aboriginal disadvantage and, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) has said, dispossession is the root cause of Aboriginal disadvantage. Anyone who has spent significant time with Aboriginal people can find that easy to understand. You just have to go to Cape York and look at the difference between the cape, where they have been dispossessed, and the islands, where they have not; at the difference between the people; and at what a process of dispossession did to an indigenous people.

Land is important, and this bill is important, but that does not mean it is infallible and that we do not have the right to have concerns and have those concerns heard and addressed. Our concerns fall into two main areas. The first area is the focus of the bill and the second area is the accountability of the bill. I will talk about them both in turn.

The honourable member for Moreton accused us of wanting to totally change the bill, making it impossible to purchase land, and to divert all the funds into health, housing and education. That is not true; that is completely at odds with the speech that the Leader of the Opposition gave. What we would want to see does not preclude purchase of sizeable amounts of land for the benefit of Aboriginal people. But let us be honest with ourselves and not kid ourselves that land alone will fix the problem. Let us be honest that this is not an easy task. If it were easy, it would have been done already.

In this chamber there are people with enormous experience in Aboriginal affairs. I would like to talk about part of mine, because it colours my approach to this bill. I have spent a lot of time in Central Australia. At one stage I spent one week as a doctor working in a remote Aboriginal community. That community was one of the first to receive land under land rights in 1976 because it was on an existing Aboriginal reserve. So the people in this community have had access to a sizeable area of land for a very long time.

The people in this community have a health clinic that has detailed health records going back to 1945. For every five-year period, the life expectancy of an adult Aboriginal male in that community has decreased. Today, if you are a male in this community, your life expectancy is less than that of an adult male in Sierra Leone, which has the lowest life expectancy of any country in the world. At any point in time, that same Aboriginal community has an incidence rate of sexually transmitted diseases which is somewhere between 25 and 30 per cent of adult people—a factor that will have enormous implications when the HIV-AIDS virus gets into that community, as it will.

Obviously, land is important to Aboriginal self-esteem, and it is an ingredient. But unless there is some focus to that land—unless there is some purpose; unless we say at the same time how we are going to best utilise it; unless we put it in terms of a package of providing some sort of economic base for the people who are purchasing it; unless we provide the training; and unless we provide the ongoing assistance to upgrade it—we will not get very far. We want to see much more of an overall package that will have a direct impact on the wellbeing of Aboriginal people. It does not preclude the purchase of land; it means that that land has some hope of making a difference for the better.

The second major area of concern is, broadly, accountability. Accountability is important. If Aboriginal people are going to be able to get full benefit, it has to be at least with the acquiescence, if not the support, of the broad community. The community will only accept the $1 1/2 billion land fund if it thinks it is getting value for money. We have a number of specific concerns. I will raise some of them. They are not major issues, but collectively they help to give the bill focus and make sure that Aboriginal people will get some value for money and the taxpayer will be protected.

Under the bill there is a strategy that at the moment goes to the minister only on request. It should go as a matter of course. There is no requirement in the bill that money be used for the purpose as granted. There should be. There is no requirement that the strategy plan be laid before both houses of parliament. That is quite different from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation strategy plan. The system of laying it before both houses of parliament works. The provisions of the bill are framed in a way that assumes that the Minister for Finance will delegate his or her authority to ATSIC. That should not be assumed. The audit by the Office of Evaluation and Audit is at the request of the minister. With a fund of this size, it should not be at the minister's request; it should be regularly audited—for the protection of Aboriginal people as well as the Australian taxpayer.

So these are issues of accountability. In one sense, they are not issues of great moment, but they are in another sense. Unless we demand value for money and demand that Aboriginal people get some benefit out of this, the Australian public will not tolerate continuing failure. So these are things on which we must start a dialogue. These are things which the coalition thinks will improve the bill and they are things on which I hope we can take a more bipartisan approach.

I have sat through two days of debate on this bill by my party. I have listened to every person. They have all said, in one way or another, pretty similar things. They have said that they want to see something done to help address Aboriginal disadvantage that will succeed. They do not want more promises that are not achieved. They do not want expectations to be raised and then to be dashed, and they do not want more failure. Let us be honest: there is failure in this area all the time. It is not easy. If it were, it would have been fixed ages ago.

Let us be honest. When the national Aboriginal health strategy came in in 1990, there were going to be measurable benchmarks for the improvement in Aboriginal health. Over four years later, where are the benchmarks and where is the improvement? When the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill came into this parliament three years ago, there were going to be benchmarks for addressing Aboriginal disadvantage. Where are those benchmarks? They are important. This is not some obscure economic concept. We have to know whether things are getting better or worse and whether what we are doing is making a difference for the better. It is not axiomatic that that will happen. If things are not getting better, let us at least be honest with ourselves and say that we should perhaps try something else.

This is an emotional debate. I understand the emotion and why those on the other side get emotional, because I, too, can get emotional about this. I had three years as shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. I had the privilege of moving freely throughout Aboriginal society around Australia. As I mentioned, at one stage I worked as a doctor in a community. In other communities, I have watched mothers with infant children fill bottles out of dirty water and feed them to their kids. I have evacuated sick kids with diarrhoea. I have seen success and I have seen failure. But emotion in itself is no good. We will not be remembered for our emotion or our good intentions. People will remember whether we actually did something constructive to address Aboriginal disadvantage.

What can we learn from the process that we went through in getting a more bipartisan approach to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation—an approach that has stood the test of time and allows the council to still operate in a pretty constructive environment? We learnt, firstly, that it takes time; secondly, that it takes a degree of trust; and, thirdly, that one side of politics is not always right about everything.

Some in the Labor Party would paint themselves as being purer than the driven snow. I find that a bit tough, because when trying to take a constructive approach on matters relating to Aboriginal affairs as Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I was subjected to the National Media Liaison Service taking the most minute nuances in every one of my statements and attempting to turn them into party political advantage. I was also subjected to being asked to a dinner at ATSIC to celebrate its three-year anniversary. The office of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) rang up and demanded that my invitation be withdrawn, purely for party political purposes. Let us be honest: there is politics on both sides of the House and it is getting us nowhere.

Let us look at these three things in turn. It takes time to discuss and argue backwards and forwards to get to understand where the other side is coming from. Bipartisanship is not throwing something up and saying, `Take it or leave it.' It is having a dialogue. That has not occurred, and it is going to make it hard here.

It also takes trust. That is a difficult thing in politics but it is possible when this parliament decides that it is time to do something. The other element of trust is at least recognising that there is a different point of view, recognising that there might be some goodwill from the other side, that there may not necessarily be political advantage in trying to manipulate that, and recognising that there might be things that could make this work a bit better.

I said earlier that I thought this legislation would be a turning point. I think that is correct. Either we can now address this issue seriously with a degree of goodwill or the Australian public has every right to believe that we are no more than just a bunch of politicians talking about something that has no relevance to you, me or anyone else in this country. There is an opportunity here to establish a dialogue; to try to work for something that both sides of politics may be able to support. We may not succeed. In the end we may not be able to support this legislation but we at least have to try. We have to have a degree of generosity of spirit that perhaps has not been there in recent times. We have to accept that no-one has 100 per cent of the

SPEECH.PARA: answers on this and, above all, we have to seize this opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be involved in the debate this afternoon and to support the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. Before the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) leaves the House, if that is what he is intending to do at the present, I have to say that, in terms of generosity of spirit, I take what he said in the way I think he intended it. If I may, I pay him a compliment. It is probably the end of him, as he rightly pointed out, but I have to say that the time he was the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs was the most productive I have seen in terms of the relationship between the government and the opposition on the issue of Aboriginal affairs. So I give what he says the credibility it deserves.

PARA.TAB: But I say to him—as I say to some other members of the opposition—that, whilst he has that generosity of spirit, there are those around him who do not. In terms of today's debate, the contribution by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) was testimony to that fact. I will go into more detail on that later, but again I say that I know there are people in the opposition with goodwill in relation to this issue and the honourable member for Chisholm is one of those. I understand also that the parliamentary secretary at the table, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne), has similar views to those of the honourable member for Chisholm. I wonder how long he will last as a parliamentary secretary.

We have already heard this afternoon that land is of importance to Aboriginal people. I will not go into that subject in great detail apart from saying that land is a source of being for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and land is what makes the law for Aboriginal people, which in itself provides a religious, legal, social and economic code for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Pat Dodson once said that land is the generation point of existence.

Land also, of course, is important psychologically, and perhaps there is no better way of saying that than what was said by a Noonkanbah elder speaking to an Amex mining official who was about to enforce drilling rights on Aboriginal land at Noonkanbah. He said, `Can't you see you are killing our minds?' The importance of this relationship to land has been reflected in various reports to parliaments over the years and by judicial inquiries, and I will refer to the Woodward royal commission later in my speech. The 1980 report of the New South Wales parliamentary select committee on Aborigines stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the Committee's considered opinion that unless the question of land rights is satisfactorily settled there will be little progress made in the many other areas of Aboriginal socio-economic deprivation, or in the broader fields of race relations . . .
It stated further:
. . . the land remains the key to Aboriginal spiritual and physical survival . . .

Quite simply, if Aborigines are going to benefit from health, welfare, education or any other programs, then they need the mental, spiritual and physical sustenance and support of being on their own land.

In the context of this government's commitment to the Mabo legislation and to issues involved with social justice, and as rightly and properly pointed out by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during his speech this afternoon, this is landmark legislation—of that there can be no doubt. I am sure that even those opponents on the opposition benches regard it as being landmark legislation, again testified to by the approach adopted by the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: The establishment of the land fund recognises the dispossession and the right to land of Aboriginal people whose economic marginalisation represents the effect of that dispossession. The land fund will be accessible to all Aboriginal people and in particular will provide access to land for those—the great majority—who would otherwise not have benefited directly from the Mabo decision. It will allow Aboriginal communities to purchase land and to develop sustainable economic programs. It will allow the development of multiple and mixed land uses, such as cattle stations, parks, Aboriginal cottage industries and cultural and land related activities on both native title land and other Aboriginal held land. The land fund will promote the incorporation of traditional Aboriginal land management practices. It will provide funds for the acquisition of land and conversion of land to native title. I think that is of fundamental importance.

The funds available will be used in the acquisition and management of land. There will not be any diversion of funds through various tiers of government or government agencies. That is also important. I will come later to the approach adopted by the opposition in relation to those issues.

The decisions on the development of regional and national strategies will be based on the aspirations and needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and made by them, as will the decisions on the disbursements of the land fund. Yet the opposition's proposals would effectively give state and local governments a veto over how land funds would be used. I ask any reasonable and fair minded person: if we are actually talking about social justice—justice for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians—why would we embark on such a course? Again, I am sure that will become clear when I highlight the comments made by the Northern Territory Chief Minister in relation to Aboriginal land rights and the land fund.

The land fund will not be used—and nor should it be used—as a slush bucket by the government to substitute for the provision of services and infrastructure that are the responsibility of all governments to provide to an acceptable level for all their citizens. This government should not support the diversion of land funds to cover the abrogation of responsibilities by state and territory governments in the provision of essential services. I point to the victory of our friends, the so-called moderates in the opposition, in the coalition's policy on the land fund. The policy still anticipates and condones the trade-off or siphoning off of funds from land to other services. This should be seen exactly for what it is—a backdoor way of emasculating the land fund.

I listened very carefully to the words of the Leader of the Opposition when he referred to the land fund helping in the purchase of land—not purchasing land, but helping in the purchase of land. He alluded to state mechanisms for the purchase of land. What state mechanisms, pray tell, was he talking about? Was he talking about state mechanisms in Western Australia, funded by the Western Australian Treasury, or in the Northern Territory, funded by the Northern Territory Treasury? Let him highlight them to us. No steps have been put in place by either of those two governments for the purchase of land by Aboriginal Australians. In fact, on every occasion that there has been a land claim under the Northern Territory land rights legislation, the Northern Territory government has opposed it.

The Northern Territory government has sought at every turn to frustrate attempts by Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory to secure land for their benefit. Any amendments to this bill that seek to divert the land fund for use in the provision of mainstream services should be seen for what they are—blatantly political and hypocritical attempts to subvert the purpose of this legislation.

I note importantly in the Prime Minister's speech the continued support of the Prime Minister and the government for the ATSIC program for the acquisition and management of land during the initial period of the establishment of the Indigenous Land Corporation and of the way in which the land fund should be used to purchase land in the Northern Territory. It is important also when acknowledging those remarks for ATSIC to clearly recognise its responsibilities in relation to meeting the special land needs of Aboriginal territorians in the initial period. The Prime Minister has properly and adequately canvassed what is entailed in this legislation.

I now turn to the contribution of the Leader of the Opposition. To say that his contribution was appalling is an understatement. To say that it demonstrated gross hypocrisy is also an understatement. To say that he was unctuous is also an understatement. This is the man who said just some weeks ago that the opposition could not support a land fund. In trying to say as he did in his speech—it was not well put—that this bill should be about the provision of health, education, housing and economic opportunity for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, he totally and purposely missed the point.

I was at Utopia on the day that the Leader of the Opposition and his shadow spokesperson arrived. I did not hear his introduction, but I am told that he did not bother to introduce his shadow spokesperson. When he first arrived, he got involved in a media scrum and had to be pulled away by an Aboriginal person who pointed out to him that the purpose of his visit was to talk to Aboriginal people.

It is no wonder that the opposition leader shows very little understanding of the issues facing Aboriginal people. It is no wonder that he failed to heed comprehensively what was said to him by Aboriginal people in Central Australia. Did he listen to the views of Aboriginal people or those of the doctor at the Utopia health service? An article by Mike Seccombe referring to the trip of the Leader of the Opposition states:

Later, he flew to Utopia station, about 280 kilometres north-east of Alice Springs, to visit an Aboriginal health centre, where medical staff told him that without secure land title, Aborigines suffered significant health problems.

The doctor at Utopia, Dr Karmananda Saraswati, said assessments of the relative health of Aborigines had proved that secure access to land and, particularly, the return to more traditional outstation lifestyles, brought major health benefits.

He said the cost of evacuations and in-patient treatment at Utopia was less than 50 per cent of that at other communities. The people ate more healthily from traditional food sources and alcohol and substance abuse was negligible.
"If you take away land rights—once you cut off their spiritual link—you may just as well be machine-gunning people down," Dr Saraswati said.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what this legislation is all about: providing those Aboriginal Australians who do not have access to land with an opportunity to acquire it. Hopefully, they will get back some of their traditional country and secure a native title claim over it for future generations.

PARA.TAB: I am not surprised at the way Aboriginal people in Central Australia perceived the visit by the Leader of the Opposition. I am sure that what he said here today will reinforce their view. One Aboriginal man said the opposition leader was `like a snake'. He further said:

SPEECH.PARA: He's over here then we turn around and he's over there, another place.

That is him. Yesterday and the day before he was with the hard Right in Tasmania. Today, he is seeking to woo the moderates in his own party as a result of his sacking the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson)—a crude political stunt, and it will be seen as a crude political stunt. Aboriginal people are not going to be fooled by him, and nor should they be. But he is not alone.

PARA.TAB: This tome of amendments is being proposed by members of the opposition, and if we the government do not accept them they will not support the bill. Is the Leader of the Opposition joking? Is he serious? He seems to be. But that again shows the political purpose of his approach. But, as I say, he is not alone.

In these amendments he is saying that we ought to allow the states and local government to play a role in determining the program for the land fund. How would you like to be an Aboriginal person in the Northern Territory or Western Australia having Richard Court or Marshall Perron looking after your interests in relation to land, or indeed social justice?

Earlier this year on ABC radio the Northern Territory Chief Minister commented on social justice as part of a total social justice package. The interviewer quoted the Northern Territory Chief Minister as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Social justice . . . would result in a levelling down of society rather than a levelling up.
Then the Chief Minister said:
To me, Tony, it's a frightening term. It's a term that the democratic socialists used to justify all of those, let me say, non-wealth creating, non-job creating issues.
Is he serious? Then in reference to social justice he said:
It's certainly given us the sorts of things that have infuriated our society about how some sections of the community are entitled to taxpayer funded benefits that others aren't entitled to.
I quote from the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly Hansard of 11 May, when he referred to the land fund:

We will never fix the problems of Aboriginals or people who call themselves Aboriginals—in Redfern of course—by limiting this to the rural environment. I am sure that, whether they earn more or less than $100,000, every Aboriginal in this country will have their hands out for a share of this taxpayers' slice of social justice.

An entirely progressive view, no doubt one which is shared by many people in the opposition—but I note not all. In relation to the land fund, when asked by a reporter on ABC radio what does it matter if the federal government wants to make $1 billion available to Aboriginal people and put them in a position, therefore, of being property buyers like everybody else in the community, the Northern Territory Chief Minister said:

PARA.TAB: Well, it matters a great deal. The principle is you're using taxpayers' funds to satisfy those Aborigines who do not have access to land under Native Title or Land Rights legislation. In the Northern Territory we have nearly 50% of the NT already Aboriginal land or under claim. The balance of the Territory is largely pastoral property. If you provided another 2-3 million dollars in the NT situation you could probably buy 90% of the NT and that would mean that 25% of the Territory's population would own nearly all of the NT.

SPEECH.PARA: They have no problems selling it off to the Sultan of Brunei or to any overseas interest, but woe betide any Aboriginal person who seeks to purchase any additional land. I wonder if he realises that one commercial commentator has indicated that around 60 per cent of all pastoral leases in the Northern Territory are up for sale and leaseholders are jumping over themselves to sell to Aboriginal interests. That is the market—but of course the free market does not prevail.

PARA.TAB: The hypocrisy of the opposition's position could not be better highlighted than by this simple fact: the Leader of the Opposition said to us here this afternoon that we ought to be using this land fund for the purposes of health, education, housing and such like. This bloke has been in parliament for some time. One would have thought that he would have been a bit of an observer and have some understanding of issues of importance to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. One would have thought that the whole of his party would have shown some semblance of understanding of the key responsibilities of state and territory governments, yet they have failed miserably to support the interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.

One would have thought that those opposite would understand why the health status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders is so bad and why the infrastructure is lacking. Why then did they go to the last election proposing cuts of $90 million in the budget for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people? They cannot have it both ways. The Leader of the Opposition is like a snake—turn around and he will go another way. He acts like a snake. He should be seen for what he is—a snake.

The words of that Aboriginal person in Central Australia could not have been more prophetic. I am sure those members of the opposition who in their heart of hearts support the government's legislation know that, in the way he is dealing with them, he is treating them contemptuously. That is what this is all about: the contemptuous approach by the Leader of the Opposition to an issue which ought to receive the bipartisan support of this parliament. It should be supported because we know it will be supported by the people of the country, but it will not be supported by the opposition. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be more inclined to take the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), more seriously if I thought there was some sincerity about them. I find it difficult to believe that there is when I know that he is a member of the left wing who opposes Aborigines earning royalties from uranium mining. They earn something like $15 million to $20 million a year in royalties from the Ranger uranium mine in Kakadu, but they could be earning far more if, for example, Koongarra was allowed to open.

PARA.TAB: That honourable member has no concern at all for the Aboriginal people when it comes to that issue. He just has his ideological blinkers on—somehow we can mine uranium here and cannot mine uranium there. If he were fair dinkum, he would listen to what the local Aboriginal people are saying, including the land council Aboriginal people in that part of the world, and allow that mine to open at Koongarra so that the Aborigines in that area could benefit, as they wish to do, from the many millions of dollars that would flow through in royalties. I think the Ranger mine alone has already paid out something in excess of $260 million since about 1980.

In discussing the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill, it is important to understand from the outset why the government has found it necessary to introduce it into the House. It all stems originally from the Mabo or native title legislation. There was an admission from the government that when this legislation was brought down there would only be five per cent of mainland Aborigines that would actually benefit from the Mabo legislation. Out of that five per cent, the great concentration would lie to the west of this country, primarily in Western Australia. Very few Aborigines in eastern Australia would benefit at all.

By definition, the native title legislation was discriminatory in a sense. Therefore, further measures had to be taken. The land acquisition fund legislation that we are debating here today is one of those. I believe that in the new year the government will also be bringing down a social justice package which will particularly concentrate on urban Aborigines. That is the situation as far as that goes.

We all appreciate the plight of Aboriginal people. I think it is fair to say that honourable members debating this bill on both sides of the House have highlighted that. It is a plight that frustrates all of us because we have seen precious little to show for the $10 billion or so that has been spent over the last decade on Aboriginal people, and that is only in specific grants. Aborigines quite rightly have access to other grants that are available to all of us, such as the old age pension, et cetera.

No-one pretends it is easy to overcome the difficulties or the plight that Aboriginals find themselves in. In the time that we have had in this country, with the resources we have utilised and the money we have spent, I do not think it is improper to question why we have very little to show for this effort. We do not even have proper benchmarks in place to measure the success, or the lack of it, of all the programs we have. The situation is very complicated indeed. Even in the area of land, apart from the so-called ordinary land that any Australian, including Aboriginal Australians, can purchase, we have land rights land, we now have Mabo land, ATSIC land and we will soon have land acquisition fund land—and so it goes on. It is quite a complicated position.

If I asked any one of a number of Aborigines I might bump into in any street in my electorate to explain the situation, I doubt whether any of them could. It is something that seems to get more and more bureaucratic and hidden in the Aboriginal industry area. The benefits which are supposedly intended for the Aboriginal race never seem to flow through. I venture to say that this bill being presented today is nothing more nor less than another cruel deception for the Aboriginal people. An expectation that seems to be built up every time programs are introduced or bills are brought into this House is that somehow Aborigines will benefit substantially. The reality is that they end up getting very little every time.

In my electorate of north-west New South Wales, which would take in more Aborigines than anywhere else in New South Wales, the main problem is centred around the dignity of the Aboriginal people. The fact that they cannot get a job and cannot get proper housing and their health, due to alcohol and substance abuse, are big problems. There are massive problems with domestic violence, particularly amongst the Aboriginal women, and education programs all too often do not seem to cater specifically for the Aboriginal people. What we put in place for the rest of Australia seems to be thrust upon them and is not relevant to them. I think more work has to go into that area.

No-one seems to go out to consult with the true Aboriginal people. At best, there seems to be some sort of superficial consultation with the Aboriginal industry. I get little complaints and grumbles in my office, and when I run into people around the traps from time to time I am told none of the benefits of these programs seem to get through to them. They have programs imposed on them and money thrust at them, but there is no true consultation, no real training, no proper supervision and no accountability processes. Nobody ever seems to follow through and evaluate the programs that have already been put in place and no discipline ever seems to go with these programs. The only thing there seems to be a lot of is paternalism towards Aboriginal problems.

We have a sad mess and a tragedy in this country. A few Aboriginal people are doing very well, but a section of them are running around with chips on their shoulders and are bitter for what has gone on in the past. The great bulk of the Aboriginal people feel very neglected. They feel that they are missing out on everything that is being spent by the government and they are in a state of despair.

This bill is nothing more nor less than another cruel deception. Originally, the Aboriginal people were told that over 10 years something like $1,500 million would be spent out of the budget buying land for them. We now find that the bill has been constructed in such a way that only an extra $24 million a year will be spent on purchasing land, on upgrading the land they already have and on the management of that land; only a fraction of it will be spent purchasing land. There will be nothing like $1,500 million spent over a 10-year period for the benefit of the Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the minister inform the House of the effect of the recent decision to introduce a better system for payment of higher education contributions?

—I thank the member for his question. As part of the budget this year the government introduced a measure by which contributions under the higher education contribution scheme, which after all are a debt owed to the Commonwealth, could be collected on the same basis as tax is collected—that is, through a PAYE system.

PARA.TAB: There was no intent to change the level; there was no intent to alter the threshold. Yet this measure is now being blocked by the opposition in the other house. Apart from the hypocrisy associated with that, given that those opposite come in here and talk about fiscal discipline but will not allow through a measure that produces savings to the government, it is also based on misleading information put out by my shadow counterpart, Senator Robert Hill, in defence of this position.

In justifying the coalition's bid to block this savings measure, Senator Robert Hill said `the federal opposition will move to protect students from government plans to lower the HECS repayment threshold'. Let me just say categorically that, by this budget measure, we are not either lowering the threshold or increasing the amount. To the extent to which there are some legitimate concerns that students may have, either because of hardship or because of circumstances in which they may not earn for the whole year, there is provision in the measures to allow exemptions.

Not only do we have a misleading justification thrust upon us from the other side—we have taken account of the special circumstances—we also have absolute hypocrisy on the part of the coalition in opposing this measure. Those opposite talk about the importance of fiscal discipline, but they wimp out at every opportunity of giving effect to it. They cannot be taken seriously, and that is why they are failing so badly in the polls at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources aware that Australian Bureau of Statistics' data shows that the total value of Australian uranium exports since 1980 is $4.2 billion and that over 1,000 jobs are generated annually from uranium production? With the closure of the Nabarlek mine and the impending exhaustion of the Ranger mine, is the minister happy to see these jobs and export income decline because of Labor's totally illogical policy, preventing the development of any other mine? Further, does the minister agree that Canadians, and not Australians, have been the major beneficiaries of Labor's three mines policy?

—As I said to the shadow minister last Thursday in the MPI on this issue, the current demand for uranium does not necessitate any expansion of the industry. ALP policy does not preclude additional exports from the current mines. As we said in the debate last Thursday, Olympic Dam is the largest uranium mine in the world. If the shadow minister has visited it, as I have, he will know that a large amount of uranium stockpile cannot be sold. If the situation changes, then that is something for the ALP to decide at its conference in September.
—Can the Minister for Human Services and Health tell the House what action is being taken to prevent the closure of the health clinic on Bathurst Island?

—I thank the honourable member for his question because a very important issue is at stake here. The clinic on Bathurst Island offers the only health and medical services to the 1,200 people who live on that island.

—Unfortunately, this vital work is clearly under threat.I would not have thought the fact that 1,200 people are threatened with the closure of their health clinic was a matter for hilarity. We heard today some pious words from those on the other side of the House. Let us see the colour of their rhetoric change into action.

PARA.TAB: The clinic is in very real danger of closure. It should not surprise members in this House to learn that this is occurring because of a failure by the Northern Territory government, which has been in government for 20 years, to provide adequate funding for that service. It is not fulfilling its obligation to its Aboriginal constituents, and that should be a matter of concern to all members of this House.

What happened in this case was that the Bathurst Island community was asked to take over responsibility for the clinic from the Catholic church. The funding it received from the territory government to take over the clinic was completely inadequate, which is something that the territory government has actually acknowledged. By its own subsequent admission, the territory government has under-funded that clinic to the tune of $180,000 per year. It is not getting sufficient money to run the clinic for the needs of the 1,200 people who cannot get health and medical services anywhere else.

The government, by its own admission, has failed to take account of the fact that when the church was in charge a lot of that work was done by volunteers, principally the nuns. The clinic has now been handed over, with no training being given to the management committee and with no assistance with the full-time work that needs to be undertaken. As a result, we now see that shortfall.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just using pious words.
—Order! The honourable member for Sturt.

—Money that should be used for medicines, for supplies, is currently being used to fund salaries. The effect will be that within a week or two the good people of Bathurst Island will have no medical service. They will have neither the money to pay for staff nor consumables. The people there have been sold a pup. They have been asked to be self-determining but have not been given enough money to do it. It will find no support from this government in this House. The Northern Territory government should have responded by now to the calls from these people. They should put pressure on the Northern Territory government, which has a history of doing this sort of thing to Aboriginal communities under the banner of self-determination, to hand over adequate funds to provide those facilities.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate the opposition on taking the stand it has, apparently, to support the land fund. I hope that support is genuine and I hope we are not going to see amendments snuck into the other place that seriously undermine the purpose of that land fund. It would be very cynical indeed if this fund were an image thing, a vision thing. When it came to a clear opportunity such as this one to put pressure on the Northern Territory government to properly fund communities, like some of the ones visited by the Leader of the Opposition, all we heard were words. We have had enough of that from the opposition; we want some action.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Tourism. Could the minister please outline for the information of honourable members the progress to date in the effort by the federal government to achieve a more coordinated national approach to marketing Australian tourism internationally?

—In January this year the Australian Tourist Commission established a joint marketing venture with the states and territories known as Partnership Australia. This unified approach to international marketing is much more effective than what traditionally has been in place. I would have hoped that honourable members opposite, such as the honourable member for Ballarat, who is trying to interject, would have a bit more interest in the tourism industry, given the number of international visitors in his own electorate at the moment and the opportunities for his own electorate to take advantage of a new program such as Partnership Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is certainly true that, if we can market Australia cooperatively, with the Australian Tourist Commission and each of the state and territory tourist commissions working together, they will do a much better job than if they were each trying to market Australia separately. It is hard enough for Australians to understand federalism, let alone for international visitors to understand our federal system. Partnership Australia certainly provides new opportunities for us to market Australia internationally.

Partnership Australia can help us distribute information, fund cooperative marketing and answer questions from travel agents and consumers. One example of how many people are calling in on our hotlines is that the ATC's helplines handled over 152,000 queries between January and June this year. My favourite call to the hotline was the person who rang and asked, `When it is December in the United States, what month is it in Australia?' December is always a good time to visit the central coast, as a few people in the gallery can tell you, and it is certainly a good time to visit Australia.

I am pleased to say that all the states and territories have got right behind Partnership Australia. We have never had as much cooperation as we have today in marketing Australia overseas. The states have demonstrated their confidence in this new federal program by putting up over $9 1/2 million in this financial year as part of the Partnership Australia program.

The ATC also puts together marketing programs—not just with the states and territories, but also with the private sector. A number of people involved in the tourism industry have put up money for marketing ventures with the ATC. Qantas is the largest private industry contributor to our overseas marketing. With the Prime Minister welcoming Ansett's new 747 yesterday, we can expect that with Ansett's new ventures into Asia we will see an increase not only in the seat capacity on our routes to Asia but also in competition and additional marketing of the Australian tourism industry in Asia. That has to be a good thing.

It has been under this government that we have had the aviation reforms implemented. There were various false attempts to get some aviation reforms up and running when the Liberals were in power, although we were never able to persuade the Fraser government that it should reform the aviation industry. We have already seen the results of our reforms. In domestic tourism we have prices down 25 per cent and a 50 per cent increase in domestic passenger movements. That has provided a massive boost to the Australian tourism industry.

Today we have had the latest figures come through on international arrivals. There has been a further 13 per cent increase on the number of international visitors to Australia in June 1994 compared with June 1993. There have been dramatic increases of 50 to 70 per cent in the number of travellers from countries such as Korea, Indonesia and Taiwan. That has to be a good thing for employment in the Australian tourism industry.

Earlier today we had a question about the 1,000 people who work in the uranium industry in Australia. In the Australian tourism industry today, it is not 1,000 people who have jobs; 500,000 people have jobs—and we are expecting a further 200,000 jobs by the year 2000. How does the opposition help that industry? This Leader of the Opposition demotes the shadow minister outside the shadow cabinet.

—Can the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel inform the House on the representation of women in the Australian Defence Force, the roles they undertake and what the government is doing to further the role of women in the armed forces?

—I thank the honourable member for Macquarie for her question and her interest in this matter. To put the question in its context, honourable members will be aware that in the Senate last week a report into sexual harassment in the armed forces was tabled. It is a very good report. It is constructive and it is a very sober assessment of where we are at in the ADF on this issue. I have already commenced discussions with the services with a view to a quick and decisive response.

PARA.TAB: Having said that and to answer the honourable member, I note that some 87 per cent of positions in the Defence Force are open to women, following the government's decision in 1992 to open up more combat positions. This compares favourably with, for example, the period around 1988-89, when the percentage was around 41 per cent.

Women currently comprise 13 per cent of our armed forces. I am very pleased to say—I am sure the honourable member will be pleased to hear this—that, on average, amongst new recruits that percentage is climbing to 25 per cent. I should say for the information of honourable members—I am sure that a number will be most interested in this—that the quality of women recruits is very high. Over the past eight years, women have won 12 of the 40 major prizes at the academy, including three times as dux. That is an excellent record.

However, despite this obvious very high level of quality amongst women joining the ADF, it is clear that they are not reaching senior ranks in the proportions in which they should. Sadly, less than three per cent of women make up positions at lieutenant colonel level or equivalent.

Last Thursday, with this in mind, I announced four initiatives which are designed to ensure that women in the ADF have the maximum opportunity to compete with their male colleagues for career progression. Those four initiatives include, firstly, the establishment of a defence advisory forum on discrimination, which hopefully will act as a very pertinent exchange of information mechanism with the defence forces on appropriate strategies and approaches for generally handling discrimination issues that are adopted in the community at large.

Secondly, there will be a study on cultural and institutional barriers to career progression for women in the defence forces. I call this the glass ceiling survey. I think we all know that those glass ceilings exist. It is another thing to identify them and do something about them, and that is what the government wants to do. Thirdly, we will be studying why more women are not making the Defence Force a longer term career option for themselves. That is, in the old traditional human resource study vernacular, we will be doing a separation study on women.

Fourthly, and I think most importantly, I have reached agreement with the defence chiefs that there will be a set of performance indicators installed to monitor the achievement of women in the Defence Force, particularly to measure their career progression against normal male service expectations. These performance indicators very importantly go to the heart of the matter because they will address the selection for promotion, training programs and various staff colleges. Those issues are fundamental to career progression for anyone in the armed forces.

In conclusion, let me reiterate again what my predecessor, Senator Faulkner, said: the defence of this country is too important to be left to only a proportion of the population. All Australians must have the opportunity to join the defence forces, given the requirements on health and so forth, and as far as women in the ADF are concerned that is very much the government's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel in his position as representing the Minister for Defence. In answer to a question on notice, the Minister for Defence has revealed that in the last three years nearly 500 cases of fraud were unveiled in the Department of Defence. Of these 500 cases, 219 cases were successfully prosecuted and this resulted in only 19 dismissals. In his answer of 22 March, the minister could not say whether any of those sacked or convicted are still employed by the Australian Public Service. Is the minister now in a position to answer this and, if not, why not, and how many of those found guilty of fraud are still employed by the Department of Defence?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. There has been some newspaper discussion about fraud in recent times as well, and I am aware of the question on notice. Let me say that the Department of Defence is a little different from other departments in that it has within it its own inspector-general, whose responsibilities include the whole issue of fraud. Amongst other things, he investigates the cases and, of course, there is the appropriate level of communication and transfer of responsibilities with civil authorities.

PARA.TAB: There are various avenues of penalty in the armed forces. I am sure that a number of honourable members opposite would be aware of what they are. They range from censures through to court martials in the armed forces for uniformed people and, in the case of civilian public servants, there are various means of penalty under the Public Service Act. As of 17 August, there were 33 matters under investigation within the defence organisation. Eight were under investigation by the Federal Police and one was under investigation by another authority. I am not aware of how many of the people the honourable member is referring to are still employed as such by the Department of Defence, but I will attempt to get that answer from Senator Ray and provide it to him as shortly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Did the Minister for Finance see an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review entitled, `Why selling assets will not pay'? Has he had the opportunity, if he saw the article yesterday, to give consideration to it, receive any advice about it or have any discussions about it, and can the minister advise the House whether the details advanced in that article are likely to encourage the government to change its position as far as asset sales are concerned?

—Not a whole heck of a lot is the answer to the last part of the question. I have seen Professor Quiggin's article and it has these three strands of logic in it as its basis: firstly, that an asset owned by the government provides that government with a stream of earnings into the future; secondly, the present value of the stream of earnings is the value of the asset to the government if it is retained in government ownership; and, thirdly, the government will not be able to get a better price for the asset than that figure for its value if retained in government ownership. If the three-step argument were valid and if Professor Quiggin's logic were to hold, it would never be responsible to sell anything.

PARA.TAB: We can look back over the history of this country in terms of public ownership—particularly at the state level—of various facilities and enterprises. Take the example of my home state under the Scaddan government which, in a period of about five years, brought under state ownership various tourist resorts, a state sawmill, a state dairy, state butcher shops in Perth and Fremantle, state fish shops in Fremantle and Midland junction, a state brick works, a state implement works, a state meatworks at Wyndham, state quarries and state abattoirs. Of course, Western Australia was not alone at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a state hotel in Queensland.

—I understand that in the home state of the honourable member who just interjected there was a state tobacconist. Most of those other butcher shops and the like, in Queensland too, did produce, from time to time, a level of state ownership. The logic of Professor Quiggin's argument is that they all ought to be in government ownership today. What Professor Quiggin overlooks is that there is the possibility of a mutually beneficial transfer of ownership of an asset. His logic would apply not just to the government sector but also to the private sector. If every asset had the same present value to every possible owner, there would be no point in transferring any asset to anybody. Of course, that situation does not apply. Every asset has to be looked at on a case by case basis.

PARA.TAB: There were quite valid reasons for some of those state assets to emerge in this country. These reasons went to the fact that, in some instances, no alternative supply source was available. It was necessary for competition. Indeed, I think one of the Liberal Premiers—at least his family, the Forrest family—had an absolute lock on all meat supplies in Western Australia. The setting up of butcher shops and state meatworks was to introduce an element of competition to what was then a private monopoly. Honourable members would find that there were a lot of reasons like that to proceed down the line.

The point was that it has been the case over the last decade that, at the state level and from time to time at the Commonwealth level, assets have transferred in and out of the public sector, generally speaking, at that point in time when there is clearly no requirement on the government to continue to supply the service, product or whatever it happens to be. The circumstances of each case can change over time.

Also, as I said, Professor Quiggin's argument ignores the fact that a potential owner may value an asset more highly than the asset in the hands of another owner—in this case, specifically the government—because it may believe it will have efficiencies or be able to effect other economies which will enable it to earn a better profit stream, in which case the price it is prepared to pay will be greater than the value of that asset in continuation in government hands.

Whilst Professor Quiggin's article was a noble attempt to persuade us in another direction, it is not an article which would stand up to any form of historical analysis. It could indeed produce a nonsense if looked at in the light of practice in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training inform the House what the government is doing to assist the transition of all young Australians from school to further education or to the work force?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. It is a particularly important question, given that the government's target of 75 per cent of students finishing school by 1996 has already been met. That target was met a couple of years ago, and the rate is now climbing towards 80 per cent. Although the government has provided 3,400 new places for universities this year, it needs to be remembered that 60 per cent of year 12 school leavers do not go on to university. For this reason, the government has put in place a number of important measures.

PARA.TAB: Three measures are of particular importance at this time. Firstly, the government has committed additional growth funding of $1.1 billion to ANTA, the Australian National Training Authority, for training from 1993 to 1996. In this year alone that growth money will provide for an additional 265,000 places in TAFE. Secondly, around 10 days ago the Prime Minister launched the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation, which will provide $38 million over four years to help link the world of school to the world of work, industry based pathways in our schools and a more relevant curriculum stream for those 60 per cent of students. Thirdly, the government is piloting the AVC, the Australian vocational certificate. There are now over 150 institution and industry based pilots in place to test this new system for combining work and training and to extend training to all those young people who do not have the opportunity to participate. The results are already showing. The numbers of young people commencing an apprenticeship or a traineeship are up from 50,000 two years ago to 67,000 this year—an increase of 35 per cent. Initiatives contained in the white paper for an additional 50,000 entry level training places will see those figures climb significantly in the future.

By way of contrast, it is appropriate to look at the record of the opposition. I remind the House that, when the government took office in 1983, retention rates in our schools were 36 per cent; around one student in three completed year 12; and we were at the bottom end of the OECD countries. It is instructive at this time to think of what became of those early school leavers of the early 1980s. Eleven years on, those school leavers are now in their late 20s. It is instructive to look at the pattern of long-term unemployment and to discover that those people in their late 20s comprise the single largest group of long-term unemployed.

In other words, those early school leavers of the early 1980s—those youngsters abandoned by the coalition when in office; the forgotten youth of the early 1980s—have become the long-term unemployed of the early 1990s. But for the policies of this government they would be facing the prospect of permanent dislocation from society.

In contrast with those opposite, who apparently are incapable of agreeing on the most fundamental of policies, this is a government that has not and never will give up on Australia's young people. Australia's young people are Australia's future and this government will continue to provide them with the opportunities that are rightfully theirs.

TALK.START.PARA: —This government and its Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) have got themselves in a terrible mess over industrial relations reforms. Their knickers are really in a knot. They have been trying to implement coalition policy for the reform of the industrial relations system in order to implement enterprise bargaining—but they know not how. Even if they had any idea how to do it, the ACTU is still pulling the strings.

PARA.TAB: The central issue today relates to the national wage case before the Industrial Relations Commission. The issue is how to get real enterprise bargaining when the unions are determined to retain the award as the centralised core and they are determined to retain their power and their control over the wages and conditions system.

Last week, in the national wage case hearings before the AIRC, the government proposed to eliminate compulsory arbitration. This is a coalition proposal that was well and truly taken to the last election. The government forgot to tell itself so in the legislation which the minister brought down and which finally became law on 30 March this year. An article in the Australian on 24 August confirmed the government's new approach. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Federal Government yesterday told a Full Bench hearing that the IRC should not be able to arbitrate generally on any claims above a set of conditions contained in the award safety net.

PARA.TAB: The Government said the IRC should identify a national set of core minimum standards to be inserted in awards. While industry standards could also be inserted, all other provisions would be negotiated at an enterprise level.
Justice O'Connor questioned whether the Industrial Relations Reform Act allowed the IRC to be prevented from this arbitration.
She also raised the prospect that the commission would have difficulty in defining the level and precise nature of the core provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the minister has not been willing to appear, to debate this issue, and is apparently so comfortable with his position, perhaps we will tell a bedtime story. Once upon a time there was a Prime Minister, known by sections of the press as the master blaster, who thought to himself, `How will I get myself re-elected and reform the economy so that the Australian people will trust me once again?' One night, he said to himself, `Ha, ha! I will steal the coalition's policy.' It is a typical master blaster operating technique—to steal the coalition's colours and take its clothes, which he well and truly did.

PARA.TAB: On 21 April 1993, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) gave a speech to the Institute of Company Directors in Melbourne. In that speech, he proposed major changes to the industrial relations system in Australia. He really got employers quite excited. The employers thought, `At last, we actually have a Labor government that understands the issues and will be prepared to take the necessary actions to free up the system. Let us negotiate with our employees at the workplace and get on with reforming the economy which will make our businesses grow, make us more competitive, allow us to produce more in Australia and increase our exports.'
In that speech, the Prime Minister made a few important statements. In describing a new model of industrial relations that he was working towards, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a model which places primary emphasis on bargaining at the workplace level within a framework of minimum standards provided by arbitration tribunals.
It is a model under which compulsorily arbitrated awards and arbitrated wage increases would be there only as a safety net.
He then went on to say:
. . . we have laws which give the AIRC a role and powers that are not well suited to the present system we are trying to create.

That, my colleagues, is the essence of the problem. The problem is that we now have a reformed Industrial Relations Act which does not have the powers that the government is currently arguing in the national wage case before the Industrial Relations Commission. Last year, after the Prime Minister gave his speech, Laurie Brereton was given his marching orders, and around the country he trotted trying to figure out—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The honourable member will refer to the minister by his appropriate title.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations marched around the country trying to figure out how to live up to the Prime Minister's expectations and the community's expectations with respect to his commitment to the Institute of Company Directors. In his discussions, the Minister for Industrial Relations neglected to talk to employers. In fact, he neglected to talk to the unions. He simply sat down and did what the master blaster had told him to do: he came up with a new set of laws.

PARA.TAB: When the Minister for Industrial Relations went off to the September ACTU congress, he got well and truly booed. He will not come in here and debate this issue, but we know that, when he went to the ACTU congress, he was as nervous as billyo and he was booed off the platform. Why? It was because what he had come up with was unacceptable to the union movement. In fact, what he finally came up with was as a result of overt union pressure. Jennie George put it well. It was an absolute sell-out to the industrial arm of the Labor Party. It gave us no chance to reform the act in the manner to which the master blaster had referred in his 21 April speech.

You can picture it: the linen tablecloth, the sterling silver and the good china. After they were there for some time, they would have been on the fourth bottle of wine.

—Order!
