PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that there is no inconsistency among the Industrial Relations Reform Act, the government's submission to the Industrial Relations Commission and what the government is doing in terms of its policies. The government position which was outlined in the Industrial Relations Reform Bill is for the maintenance of a strong award system. What we did in the bill that went through this House at the end of last year was put in some extra guarantees to strengthen the award system. We guaranteed a fair minimum wage, equal pay, 12 months unpaid parental leave and protection against unfair dismissal. Every one of those fundamental rights has been opposed by those sitting opposite us. But were any of them mentioned in the debate today? Of course they were not.

With the bill that was introduced into this House last year, we simultaneously brought in a series of provisions which would enable this country to establish, on top of the award system, a system of enterprise bargaining. The bill which we brought in was designed to accelerate the spread of enterprise agreements within the federal system of industrial relations. And spread they have since that bill was introduced. They have spread not only in the federal system but in the state system in Queensland, where they have been replicated in state legislation.

This twin approach—that is, the platform of a strong award system, strengthened by those minimum ILO conventions, plus enterprise bargaining—goes to the heart of our approach, which is bitterly opposed by the opposition. It does not want flexibility upwards, building on a strengthened award system; it wants flexibility downwards. It does not want workers to get together and negotiate collectively; it wants workers to negotiate individually.

If you go through the submission that we have made to the Industrial Relations Commission, you will get to the heart of why this government is in touch with the work force, why it has passionate discussions with the union movement and why those opposite are so absolutely irrelevant to the needs of the Australian people. At the heart of that submission is the accord agreement with the trade unions. We are seeking a widening of access to the $8 safety net wage adjustment to those workers who have not yet received it. That is a very important part of our submission. There are workers who have not been able to access the $8 increase. The government is also supporting a further $8 increase at the conclusion of the current case and a further $8 increase from 1 July 1995.

For some workers, that means three increases of $8 over three years. Have you ever heard the Liberal and National parties come into this House and support a wage increase? Has anyone ever heard them come in and talk about a wage increase in our community, particularly when we consider that real unit labour costs in this country have dropped around 10 per cent—that is, real wages have fallen?

This country has become 30 per cent more competitive in the last decade and we owe an enormous amount to the sacrifice of the work force over recent years. But does anyone opposite ever thank the workers of Australia, who have accepted lower real wages over the last decade in the interests of making us more internationally competitive, generating more long-term sustainable jobs in the private sector and ensuring that their children will have not only sustainable, well-paid jobs but jobs with careers? Does anyone ever acknowledge what the work force has done over the last decade to make sure that we export more, that we grow by five per cent per year and that we have had four per cent employment growth? This is being done not solely, but certainly largely, on the back of wage restraint from the Australian work force.

Why do we not get support from the other side when we go into the Industrial Relations Commission and ask for three $8 increases for the work force that has made those sacrifices? We do not get support from the other side because its only solution to economic problems in the country is to slash wages. It does not regard labour as an element of the work force; it regards it as something akin to a nut and bolt or just another factor of introduction which has to be pumped into the computer to produce these mythical outcomes. But we understand that we need a very strong safety net in this country. Those three $8 increases are a very important part of the government strategy. They are completely absent from any approach taken by those opposite.

The second part of our submission to the Industrial Relations Commission relates to looking at what constitutes the foundation provisions of awards. Our approach is entirely consistent with the approach taken in the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993, and the government has asked the Industrial Relations Commission to identify what constitutes the fundamental or foundation elements of the award safety net. When we are talking about the foundation or fundamental elements of the award safety net, we are talking about things like minimum wage rates, loadings, key leave entitlements, hours of work, termination and redundancy provisions, superannuation, public holidays and so on. It is entirely appropriate that these matters should be looked at if we are going to build on top of our award safety net a system of enterprise bargaining which works.

But the approach that we favour, with a strengthened award safety net and, on top of that, flexibility built in through enterprise bargaining, can be contrasted with the approach once again of those opposite, when they are game to admit it. They do not favour all of those entitlements being the core elements of awards; they have a very weak commitment to one or two minimum sets of conditions and nothing more. That is consistent with their view that all of the problems in the economy stem from the wage system.

The third element of our submission is that the section 150A review process will provide the opportunity to modernise our award system and to provide a less prescriptive award system. This simply relates to rewriting and simplifying current awards, particularly in their use of language. It also involves the removal of a lot of unnecessary detail from awards and the more extensive use of enterprise flexibility clauses and facilitative provisions.

Everything the government has said in its submission to the IRC is consistent not only with the bill that passed through this House last year but also with the strategies outlined in the employment white paper brought down earlier this year. Working Nation is essentially saying that in this country we want to have a future built on growth, on being internationally competitive, on exporting more and, particularly, on a fair share of jobs in the community. The most fundamental factor affecting the redistribution of wealth in a community is the distribution of jobs and, if we do not do something about long-term unemployment, there will be an unfair distribution of jobs and an unfair distribution of wealth. But we are not only concerned about more jobs; we are concerned about better paid jobs and jobs with careers. The beauty of Working Nation is that it encompasses the policy of growth plus: that is, long-term sustainable jobs come in the private sector and to get those jobs we have to be competitive—we have to export more and import less.

That is a strategy which is absolutely opposed to what those opposite believe in their heart of hearts. In their heart of hearts, they are what I call economic fundamentalists—they simply believe that to solve unemployment you must slash wages, cut the deficit and so on. That view was completely buried in our white paper. Our moral, social and economic stance says that people are entitled to a fair standard of living through the economy. The most fundamental form of welfare is a job, but not a job on any conditions, not a job on any wages, not a job without training. We are committed to jobs which have careers, training and a fair level of remuneration—all of those things which are absent from the approach of those opposite.

We have through the accord and through the white paper set ourselves the task of creating more jobs and better paid jobs—not low paid jobs. We are not going down the American road that those opposite advocate. What you would love to see in this country is the army of the working poor. You would love to see wages go down so low that everyone would be working for starvation wages. You know from the work of people like Professor Bob Gregory that, if you were to make any significant impact outside of growth on unemployment through pure wage cuts, you would have to slash wages in this community by 30 per cent because that is the only economic strategy you know.

The government has got a much more sophisticated approach to growth, a much more sophisticated approach to the creation of jobs, and a much more sophisticated approach to the living standards of working people in this country. Through the accord, we have been committed not only to the strength of the award system, with enterprise bargaining and flexibility upwards, but also to giving the work force tax relief.

When we brought in the tax cuts last year, they were attacked constantly and incessantly by those opposite. When we dropped the marginal rate of tax from 39c in the dollar to 33c in the dollar for someone earning $25,000 a year, those opposite ran around the country saying that was fiscally irresponsible. Once again, those opposite want to take the money out of people's pockets through the tax system and the wage system. When are they going to put any money back into the pay packets of workers in this country? When will they get a policy which will do that—not cut public expenditure and wages?

This parliament has not been well served by the contribution made today by the honourable member for La Trobe. He really demonstrated what is wrong with the current Liberal Party. On radio yesterday morning, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), said that the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) most certainly was not the voice of moderation in the Liberal Party. If he is not the voice of moderation, and the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for La Trobe are to the right of him, God help Australia. God help Australia if they are all to the right of the honourable member for Wentworth. Does that mean we still have the 15 per cent GST hidden away in the cupboard? Does that mean we still have the $3 an hour youth wage hidden away in the cupboard? Does that mean we still have the $10 billion public sector cutbacks hidden away in the cupboard? The Liberal Party does have a policy, but it is a policy that it is not game to talk about in the parliament. (Time expired)

Industrial relations should be about providing appropriate and fair mechanisms so that employers and employees can agree upon the sorts of work arrangements which should apply in their work enterprise. That is not what Labor is interested in. It wants to bias the system so that it overwhelmingly favours its trade union mates to the disadvantage not only of employers but also of workers.

The Labor Party has a close relationship with the union movement—it could be called a subservient relationship. The unions make the rules; the government obeys the orders. If people have any doubts about that, I refer them to the words of Jennie George—a prominent union official—which will certainly echo through history. She lectured the employers after the election and said, `We won the election! It has no concern for the economy, national interest or the ALP's election policy; it is there to collect its rewards after winning the election.

The industrial relations legislation was part of the trade union movement's payback. The press release announcing all of these changes did not come from the cabinet room or from the minister's office, it came from ACTU House, where all the news on these sorts of matters seems to emanate. ACTU House—the Kremlin; the Vatican of union policies—was where it was decided what would go into the Industrial Relations Act. This is the payback for the assistance of the unions in the election campaign. They were not really entitled to a payback because most of the money that they donated to the Labor Party election campaign came from the taxpayers in the first place.

The Labor government during the previous term had provided $25 million-plus in donations to Labor unions. At a Senate estimates committee, a group of 16 unions was identified which received $2.5 million in grants, and those same 16 unions donated $2.2 million to the ALP. In addition, all the union staff, office facilities and paid candidates were turned out to assist the ALP during the election campaign. There was no obligation for any payout. The ALP was being given money provided by the taxpayers. The ALP has set up a gigantic siphoning system to transfer money from the taxpayers to Labor Party funds through the trade union movement.

In spite of the lack of justification, the payback occurred—the industrial relations legislation. The country was inflicted with the new secondary boycott provisions which place unions above laws which apply to all other Australians. Unions are able to ride roughshod over the rights of other Australians. The legislation also contains unfair dismissal rules—rules which terrified business and jammed the courts in only two months. The government had to back off and change the rules. This led to more confusion and more inconsistency. The legislation contains strike provisions, which were described recently by one leading employer as industrial blackmail. Indeed, that is what they are. The unions received this payback because of what they contributed towards the election win.

Someone seemed to forget to tell the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) what was in this payback deal. Just after the election, on 21 April in Melbourne, he turned up to tell employers that he would accept some deregulation of the labour market. He said that there would be some retention of awards with core conditions but that most arrangements of working conditions would be negotiated at an enterprise level. During the election campaign, when the coalition proposed this sort of arrangement, the ALP suggested that it would basically bring an end to civilisation; that it would be the end of the world; that it could not possibly happen. When elected to government, somebody forgot to tell the Prime Minister about the deals and he promised the employers there would be some degree of deregulation in the industrial relations system.

That promise from the Prime Minister is not unreasonable. After all, depending on whether Mr Hawke's $50 book version is believed or the Prime Minister's backroom briefings to journalists, the Prime Minister was the one who believed in the deregulation of the banking system, exchange rates and the marketplace. It is all right for everybody else, so perhaps it is all right for the union movement and industrial relations to be deregulated. If small business has to fend for itself, why can other people in the workplace not fend for themselves? The Prime Minister promised some real reforms.

It is not unusual for the Prime Minister to be confused. In 1991 he described the Industrial Relations Commission as `dredging around trying to find a place for itself in the new economic society of Australia and not knowing what is happening'. Months later he used the same Industrial Relations Commission as a convenient mechanism for his turnaround in setting up a national centralised wage fixing system.

Labor is really there to protect the unions. There are still a few people left who believe that academic union officials and bureaucrats who sit around in Melbourne are better able to decide working conditions than workers and their employers. Reforms to the Industrial Relations Act have been put in place and have entrenched the award system. The government seems to have forgotten that as it goes back to the Industrial Relations Commission and argues the 21 April position of the Prime Minister—another turnaround. Government by confusion.

All this is presided over by Minister Brereton, the man who is bringing his reputation of being accident prone from New South Wales to the federal scene. He is a close member of the royal family. He is in with all of the mates and in on all of the deals. This is the man who did not want the industrial relations job. He desperately tried to get rid of it.

The minister shows his interest in the subject by not even being prepared to come into the chamber today to join in the debate. He cannot explain it and his backbenchers will certainly not be able to explain it. He is too busy trying to sell off the airports under the nose of the Left, presiding over the demise of the Australian National Line, or being caught up in safety administration at the CAA. He is the minister in charge of slashing road funding. He is too busy incompetently administering that side of his department to take any interest in industrial relations. This accident prone minister has failed in industrial relations and should be replaced.

Labor's approach to industrial relations is one of chaos. Its policy is a policy of failure. Everywhere it goes, there is confusion and disorder. No wonder employers cannot understand what is going on. They were invited to pay big money to go to seminars explaining the latest rules; the government itself does not know what is going on. The government is arguing in the Industrial Relations Court against its own legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted for question time and the matter of public importance debate, I was saying how this land acquisition fund for the supposed benefit of the Aboriginal people has been, in many ways, a cruel deception. It was set up following the Mabo legislation for rural Aborigines, particularly in eastern Australia, who will not benefit from native title. Also, I believe a social justice package will be brought down next year for mainland Aborigines who live in urban areas, who will benefit neither from native title nor from the land acquisition fund.

PARA.TAB: When we first heard of the land acquisition fund when it was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), we were led to believe that something upwards of $1,500 million would be set aside. Whether or not one agreed with the fund, one would have to say that was a very significant amount of money. But it appears that this is not to be the case. Some $200 million is to be set aside, through a mechanism which I will explain in a minute, in the first year and then $121 million each year thereafter for the next nine years.

This money is not to be given to anyone; it is only to be transferred from the consolidated revenue fund to the general trust account or land fund. The money in the trust fund will not belong to the Aboriginal people at all. It will form part of the Commonwealth public account and will remain the property of the Commonwealth under the control of the Minister for Finance, who technically could shut it off at any time, if he or she so wished.

In a complicated mechanism—I must admit even I have difficulty understanding it—any return on the land fund investments must go back to consolidated revenue and then a set grant will be given from consolidated revenue to the land fund by way of a standing appropriation, I am told. The land fund will then give an indexed amount each year to the Indigenous Land Corporation, which is another body to be set up under this bill we are discussing today. I believe $45 million, indexed, will be available.

ATSIC already has a land acquisition and management program under way to purchase land now and to manage it. It already receives $21 million a year. Under this legislation, that will be taken over and the $21 million that ATSIC has previously received will come from the land fund. In effect, this means that the money going to the Indigenous Land Corporation will amount to only $24 million, if one can follow all that. In other words, over a 10-year period Aborigines will not be given $1,500 million to purchase land but will be given a quite miserly sum, in comparison. Some $24 million of new money will be given to the Indigenous Land Corporation each year. That will be for the first few years. Then from 1998 onwards the ATSIC fund will cease, its $21 million will be transferred to the Indigenous Land Corporation and it will manage $45 million a year, indexed, thereafter.

An Indigenous Land Corporation board is to be set up. That will have a chairperson who, under the legislation, must be an Aboriginal person. There will be a deputy chairman, the ATSIC chairperson and four ordinary members. Apart from the overall ILC chairperson, four other members of the seven member committee have to be of Aboriginal descent. The purpose of the board will be to purchase land, manage land, draw up a regional and national land strategy—whatever that means—and upgrade land which is already owned.

If this money is going to be spent, I certainly agree that a portion of it should be put towards upgrading land already owned, because many Aboriginal properties that are run now are undercapitalised, resources or potential resources are under-utilised and the properties, in many cases, are run down. I am also pleased to see that money can be used towards hiring agricultural and other expertise to help run those properties in a professional manner. I hope this works out better than it has in the past.

There are many things to be considered and time will allow me to mention only one or two. I notice that the Bills Digest, put out by the Parliamentary Research Service, raises certain things that are not properly covered. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Selling or mortgaging land acquired through the ILC: Where land has been acquired by an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation directly from the ILC, or through a grant of money from the ILC, then the land cannot be sold or charged (e.g. mortgaged) without the consent of the ILC. If the land is sold or charged without ILC consent, the sale or charge is of no effect.

This means that if an innocent third party bought the land, the sale would be of no effect and they would have no legal right to the land. The Bill does not provide any protection for innocent third parties in this position. It does not appear that the ILC would retain an interest in the land which would allow it to place a caveat on the title alerting potential buyers of the problem, nor does the Bill create a public register which would allow people to see if the land they wish to buy is subject to this disability. As an `Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation' may not be immediately identifiable as such (because a company only needs to be controlled by Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders to qualify), the practical consequence of this provision would be that any person intending to buy land from a company anywhere in Australia would have to check with the ILC to ensure that the land was not subject to the disabilities in clause 191S.
I think that is something in this bill that needs careful consideration by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner).

PARA.TAB: One other concern I do have is that all of the land that will be purchased by this fund will be placed in collective ownership. While I do think this is appropriate in some circumstances, for all of the land to be so deemed leads to certain problems. Collective ownership of land has never worked properly anywhere around the world. I would have liked to have seen provision for Aborigines to own some of this land individually. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) has made one suggestion that there should be a soldier settler type scheme set up whereby individual Aborigines could own the land themselves. I see merit in this suggestion, because if it were implemented it would give proper incentives for Aborigines to work and benefit from the land.

I travel around my electorate, which takes up 40 per cent of New South Wales, and around the rest of New South Wales and Australia. I do not actually know of any farming or pastoral properties that Aborigines own except collectively. I believe that is a very sad indictment of both sides of this chamber. If we get on a plane and fly from one city to another, we cover a lot of property and can see it as we look out the window. Every one of those properties which is owned individually is owned by non-Aboriginal people. To think that originally Aboriginals owned this land and do not individually own any of it now is something this parliament should be looking at.

I would like to see a scheme implemented where Aboriginals could own land individually and try to make a go of it themselves. I realise it is very hard to make a go of farming land these days—everybody is struggling in that regard. It would be nice to think that there could be some scheme implemented where Aborigines could own the properties themselves, could buy and sell the land themselves, could keep the profit they make out of the land and could work them in this manner.

Many other things could be said about this bill, but there are many speakers on the list. I will not say any more except to reiterate that this is a very small amount of money that is being given to the Aboriginals. The government is making a big thing out of the $24 million a year that the Aboriginal people will be receiving. If it was genuine about it, the government could have—almost by regulation—added the money to the amount that ATSIC is already receiving for land purchase and management rather than trumpeting out there that Aboriginal people will be getting almost $1 1/2 billion dollars when, in fact, they will be receiving only an extra $24 million a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) say that this is a small amount of money. I will make sure that I quote high and low across the country that the coalition believes this is a small amount of money we are giving to the Aboriginal community. I would tend to agree. It is probably one of the best real estate deals of this century. For only a small amount of money, we have taken away the long-term historical rights of a whole people who once had tenure of the whole of this land.

PARA.TAB: I am glad to hear that the honourable member thinks it is such a small amount. Therefore, the opposition will probably not be too heavy in trying to stop this fund from going ahead. However, it goes on. The honourable member also showed a complete and total lack of understanding of people he purports to represent in his electorate. Having come from the central west of New South Wales, I know the area the honourable member for Parkes talks about. I know the type of people the honourable member represents. Their first statement is usually, `I'm not a racist, but . . . ' They say, `Some of my best friends are Aboriginals'; `I've known an Aboriginal.'

Let us look at what the honourable member was actually saying and pull apart some of the things he said. He maintained that it was a blight on the government that Aboriginals who did own pastoral stations did so collectively. He went on to say that it was a blight on both sides of this House that Aboriginal people did not own land on an individual basis. The honourable member for Parkes falls into one of the most common pitfalls for anyone who tries to adjudge other people. He looks from his own perspective. Unfortunately, he is not able to render himself aloof from his own prejudices and his own way of life. In other words, when he judges, talks, thinks or makes any comment about Aboriginal society, he does so from his own peculiar white perspective. I say `peculiar' because he is, after all, a member of the National Party.

My family has been involved with the Aboriginal community from before my birth. My father was given a number of honours by various Aboriginal communities. The people at Wallaga Lake wanted him to be buried on their land. He has, in fact, been recognised, and I am sure the honourable member for Charlton is aware—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very much aware of it. He deserved every one of those recognitions that he received.

—That is correct. He was recognised for his understanding. In the 1950s, when everyone else—people like the honourable member for Parkes—was telling Aboriginal people what they should be doing my father was in a position to say, `What is it you want? What would you like to do with your community?' Rather than being a great white judge, he actually used those two things on either side of his head to listen rather than to keep his glasses on and keep his hat from falling down over his face.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member should go out there and listen to the Aboriginal people. We have heard a lot of things said in the House, particularly from the people of Western Australia. As a member of the native title committee which recently went over to Western Australia, I would suggest to them that what they should do is go across and listen to their Aboriginal folk. Their Aboriginal folk do have opinions. The days when they needed white folk to articulate their views are well and truly over. What they are now after is a bit of justice.

Why should the honourable member for Parkes be so upset that people choose, in their own cultural way, to be collective by nature? I find it quite intriguing that he sees this as some sort of disgusting and disgraceful thing. I find it intriguing, because I am a member of a community. Many of the things I do, I do collectively as part of a community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you own a house by yourself?

—No, I do not. I own it as part of a family. Collective ownership, the concept of a larger family or community, is not something that one should feel disgraced about. In fact, for the honourable member to make statements that Aboriginal people have to live our style of life—that is, that they have to isolate themselves—I feel would be offensive to many people in the Aboriginal community. My family was an extended family in that grandparents lived with us. I note that with the concept of the nuclear family that is not really the go these days. What you are supposed to do is drop your grannies on the side of the road, stick them in a nursing home or off-load them in some way.

PARA.TAB: The Aboriginal community that I know may be a different Aboriginal community from the one the honourable member knows. Maybe he does not get to know the people in the Aboriginal community because they will not talk to him as they know his views. The people in the Aboriginal community who talk to me tell me about themselves and allow me to enter their homes and lives. They are a very caring community. They are a community that has a stronger sense of interrelationships than many people in the white community. On that basis, I find it quite acceptable that people in the Aboriginal community should be able to collectively own land and hold it in perpetuity for their community, their kids or their grand kids.

One of the things about capitalism is that people are allowed to go broke. We have noticed in monarchies, where an hereditary process is involved, that someone who is a bit scatty or loose in the brains department can make a mess or a meal of a whole family fortune. We have seen this happen again and again. Land held in perpetuity cannot be alienated like that. For instance, are we trying to say that the people who traded Melbourne for beads, trinkets and axes did a good real estate deal and were not in any way used or their naivety abused? I think one could say that they were sold a little short.

There is an old saying in the real estate game, `Never give a mug an even break.' I think this has happened to many indigenous people, not only the Aboriginal community of Australia but also aboriginal indigenous people around the world. The same thing happened in America. Blankets and trifles were given in exchange. There is a glaring example in New Zealand, where a treaty was struck and provisions put in the treaty.

What most of the indigenous people did not fully comprehend was that the deal involved their complete alienation from their land. Further, they really did not fully comprehend that the deal was not going to be reversed. In the case of the Treaty of Waitangi, the indigenous people did not realise that the whites were not going to uphold their part of the bargain. That is one of the things that indigenous people—and the Australian Aborigines are no different—have found. White Australians have made deals with the Aborigines and invariably broken them—again and again. There are countless situations in New South Wales where reserves were put aside, people were told that that was their reserve and that they and their families could live their lives out there. But again and again they have been moved on.

White Australia does not have a good record in terms of honesty and integrity. The land fund acknowledges that we cannot go back; that we must go forward. This generation of Australians is saying, `Without taking on any blame or pointing the finger at any one individual in history or in the present, we are going to do the best we can to try to get a just resolution to what has been a problem for 200 years.'

What is the problem? Quite simply, we stole their land. We only have to look at the basis of terra nullius. My understanding is that George III indicated that we could not claim the land if it was held by indigenous people. The way around that situation was to declare this land an empty land and deny the human rights of the Aboriginal people for 200 years. It was to deny that they were even human. For some people now to stand up here and want to play hard ball on the way the legislation should be implemented suggests to me that they do not understand that. The honourable member for Parkes probably does not concede that we stole anything. He probably does not even concede that, prior to white sightings of this continent, Aborigines actually owned this land. In a way he is correct.

My understanding of Aboriginal culture from the people I have met is that they do not own the land. They are part of the land; the land owns them. That is a very strange concept for many of us to come to grips with. The easiest way to come to grips with this concept—and the way that most of us do it—is to take the example of the recent Commonwealth Games. We are all Australian and we are all proud to be Australian when we see athletes running down the track. We take ownership of the word `Australian' and the endeavours of those people but we really do not physically do anything ourselves. I did not run around the track or do a high jump or anything like that, yet I took ownership of those medals that were won on behalf of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were with them in spirit.

—I was with them in spirit. I think there is an analogy between that situation and the relationship that the Aboriginal people of this country have with their land. They do not have to own the land to be part of it. To be part of something is not to play a dominant role. They do not have the adversarial system of law which we have. Our system of law has two parts—the right one and the wrong one. The process is that one view challenges the other. This parliament is set up on an adversarial basis: those opposite are always wrong and we are always right. It just so happens that that is the way the system is organised and we work hard at it.

PARA.TAB: The point I am trying to make is that it would be beneficial for those in the coalition to stop wobbling their lips and tongues, kick their brains into neutral for a while—out of self-interest—and then change up to empathy. Try to be compassionate. Try to get your brains into that gear which brings with it understanding. To do that, somehow you will have to get out of your white skins. Look at it as if you were theologians looking at the various religions of the world and make assessments, not judgments. Try to come to an understanding. I am sure that some members of the coalition have very good hearts, but I think they have to take some time to actually try to understand the differences in culture.

For example, when I was a young bloke, I thought, as all young blokes do, that I knew everything. When I was a young teacher I camped at Wallaga Lake. I asked the local people for permission to stay on their land and they gave me permission. Some young blokes from out west came and camped nearby. We were sitting around a fire and they started to talk and I could not understand every fifth, 10th or 12th word. Honourable members would understand that, when you are talking, if a pivotal word in a sentence is taken away, it is sometimes very difficult to understand the meaning of what was said.

I was a teacher and I had been through university and had a Diploma of Education, but for the first time in my life I realised that Aboriginals had a language problem because English was their second language. The coalition needs to realise that there are many differences that are not apparent on the surface. Rather than telling the world what their view of Aboriginal culture is and should be, they should shut up and listen. If we were to trawl through the Aboriginal communities in Australia and ask them whether or not they wanted this land fund, I think we would find that the Aboriginal communities would say, `If we are given our view, yes.' But let us look at reality. We are going to decide whether or not the legislation enabling the land fund goes through. Quite frankly, I have not seen too many black faces in here. I have not seen too many people in here who have claimed aboriginality. Again the Aboriginal people are faced with the situation that big brother white man is going to make decisions which are integral to their futures and their lives.

I do not know that there is a way around that problem at this point in time. One can only hope that people at least on this side of the House are listening to the Aboriginal people. I do not think people on the other side of the House want to hear them. They want to listen to people like Richard Court who operate according to their vested interests.

In the end, the message that I would like to give to Australian people is that we did steal the Aboriginals' land, and I admit it. I am not personally responsible. I have never shot an Aborigine; I have never abused one; I have never put any in chains; I have not kicked any heads off babies. However, the point is: even though I personally am not guilty, does that absolve my culture and my civilisation? My answer is no.

I am sure that the Prime Minister of Japan is not guilty of beating and badly handling Australians while they were in prison in New Guinea. Yet he sees a point in going around all Asian nations saying, `We acknowledge the faults of our past and we are sorry. We will do what we can to make sure that in future Japan is a different place.' I think members of the parliament of Australia, via the land fund, the native title legislation and a sincere commitment on behalf of the people on this side of the House, should say from their hearts to the Aboriginal people, `We will do all that we can, knowing that that will be very short of what is required to give a real sense of justice.'

I hope that those opposite can open up their hearts and, more particularly, their ears. You should go out amongst the Aboriginal people and listen. You should keep your mouths shut and just listen. It is their lives; it is their future. If you are so big on individual rights, you will give them the power for self-determination. You will then enact what they choose for themselves. Anything short of that is hypocrisy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will obviously be hard put to combat the intellectual contribution of the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott). I would like to comment on the problem that the honourable member for Gilmore has about guilt and the problem that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has about apologies and apologia. It is not an apologia that I accept or that we have on this side of the House.

PARA.TAB: If you live in New South Wales, I can understand that you might have some apologia. It is my understanding that the state of New South Wales has never produced much legislation for Aborigines or given them much land. In fact, you could add up all the land that New South Wales has ever produced for its Aboriginals and put it into one medium sized, drought stricken sheep station in western New South Wales.

That does not apply universally across Australia. For example, in my state of South Australia, the first reservations for Aborigines were produced in 1842. Even by the 1860s, people like George French Angas were saying that Aboriginals had been very badly treated. I am not saying that that was not true. But, as long as pastoral land acts were enacted in my state, there were always, in every acre and hectare of pastoral land, reservations for Aborigines to hunt in and live on; they could occupy any part of those pastoral lands, with a couple of exceptions near homesteads and waters. That has been the circumstance in South Australia and Western Australia almost all of the time.

Of course, it is not the circumstance in Victoria. Almost no land in Victoria has been provided to Aborigines by any government. It is the same in New South Wales. If you have a guilt and you come from New South Wales, I could understand it. I point out that we do not have quite that level of guilt. The Prime Minister, in his second reading speech, said that contemporary Western culture tends to view land as something of a commodity, something which can enrich us, not something which we must cherish and nurture, which in turn will nurture us. Your contemporary culture might think that, but ours does not. If you think that land is the only thing that is important to all Aborigines, you are wrong. If you think that land is not important to some Europeans or Asians, you are equally wrong. If you think that all Aboriginals want landownership alone, then you are wrong again.

Cathy Freeman is the best example of this in recent times. She has been much quoted in this House not only for her extreme courage in coming from behind several times but also for the extraordinary maturity with which she handled the problems which she faced over there. She has shown us that she is totally involved in an aspect of Australian life. I would like to see Australians given the opportunity—and many have in the past, but not enough—to be involved in any aspect of Australian life, whether it be in the professions, in politics, in business, in tourism or in sport.

I know that `assimilation' is a word that has passed us by and that is not politically correct, but total involvement is correct. This idea which is getting around the place—and it has been raised in some Aboriginal communities and by some Aboriginal spokesmen—that you can separate people and do good for them is something that many people would refute; I certainly do.

The government's fundamental purpose in creating this land fund was to help those who would not benefit from successful claims emanating from the Native Title Act. We remember that the proportion of successful claims was variously estimated by the Prime Minister and others. We heard from some that perhaps 10 per cent of Aboriginals would benefit. Lois O'Donoghue said five per cent would benefit, and Sol Bellear said that maybe as few as three per cent of Aboriginals would benefit. The purpose of this bill was to benefit other people. The preamble to the Native Title Bill reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to recognise that many Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert native title rights and interests and a special land fund needs to be established to help them acquire land.
I presume that this is the land fund. The explanatory memorandum reads:
Recognising that many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will be unable to secure native title and to benefit directly from the High Court decision, the Bill—
that is, the old Native Title Bill, now the act—
establishes a National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund.

In other words, it was to be directed to those people who were not able to get an advantage. Nowhere in this bill does it appear. Of course, it cannot appear. We know why it cannot appear. It is patently obvious that, for years and years to come, nobody will know who will not benefit from native title claims. The native title claims are coming in thick and fast all over Australia. They will go on in this tribunal and that court for years to come. This is notwithstanding the fact that the Native Title Act was to be the act of parliament that would solve all those problems. The Native Title Act was going to save us from the court decisions that emanated out of the High Court Mabo decision which was going to take such a long time to solve in every court of the land.

PARA.TAB: What is happening now? The gentleman who was put in charge of the tribunal, Mr Justice French, is saying that he needs some more court decisions. After the Mabo decision and the Native Title Act, which took so long and had about 200 amendments—it must have been beautifully drafted—suddenly the gentleman who is put in charge of administering the tribunal says that he needs some more court decisions.

The Prime Minister threw in an idea to see whether it floated or whether the fish would take it. He said, `We might have to amend the Native Title Act.' Of course you will have to amend the Native Title Act—or repeal it and start again, which is probably what any sensible person would do. You cannot run a land fund based on your original premise. Your original premise has gone out the window because you cannot get any decisions on native title in a hurry. Everybody who was thinking hard on our side of the House told you that and knew that all through the last two years of debate on this matter.

Let me just touch on the matter of claims. Again in this House the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the Prime Minister said, `Don't worry too much about pastoral leases. Pastoral leases will be okay because the Mabo decision itself will make sure that claims on pastoral leases are unsuccessful.' We do not know about that yet because here we are 2 1/4 years after the Mabo decision and we have not had any decisions that I am aware of emanating out of the Mabo decision.

We have claims for absolutely hundreds of thousands of hectares of one state alone—Western Australia. The latest one hit the deck about 10 days ago claiming nearly all of the Argyle diamond mining area and the future Ord River irrigation area. Is it not an amazing coincidence that all of a sudden these claims are coming in for the extremely and extraordinarily valuable areas of Australia?

I think people are starting to understand, as some of us said some time ago, when you look at maps of Australia that have claim marks all over them—which claims could never be decided in a hurry because the evidence on each one of them will be different—that it is a very great worry for the future investment propositions in this country, and it does not augur well.

Let me expand on that slightly. It is said amongst some of the legal profession who are worried about this matter that the only country that is safe from native title claim will be freehold land where the title was issued prior to 1975. That may be true or it may be an exaggeration. It is also said that freehold land issued after 1975 will probably be safe but that maybe there will be some compensation arrangements.

The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs said, as did the Prime Minister, `Don't worry about pastoral leases; they will be okay.' But I think it is true to say that all pastoral lease in this country at the present time is unsafe; all pastoral lease is probably vulnerable whether it is term lease, perpetual lease, conditional lease or in whatever form of leasehold it comes in whatever state.

Furthermore, it looks to me, as I flagged in this House a year or so ago, that those states that took the trouble back in 1893—in the case of South Australia in the early part of this century and in the case of Western Australia in the 1920s—to make some reservations for Aboriginals, where they could live, walk, hunt and conduct their original affairs on all of the pastoral country just as they had in the past, may be more vulnerable to native title claims on their country than the other states which actually wiped out the possibility of Aboriginals having those sorts of advantages. These matters need to be dealt with very seriously and very urgently. That is why we have proposed a number of amendments to this bill.
The Prime Minister was right to have changed the text of his prepared second reading speech. He changed his prepared text which he put out to the press and everybody else. He added:
I am told that the opposition intends moving amendments relating to health, housing and other matters of welfare to Aboriginal and Islander people—

SPEECH.PARA: which we are. He also added:
The government will, of course, consider all amendments, but will maintain the primary view that the fund must be about land . . .

The Native Title Act has been through the parliament. It enables Aboriginals to claim a bundle of rights up to full possessory rights perhaps in some cases. We then say that we are going to advantage those people who are not advantaged by having a fund—but actually we do not; we change the basis of the fund and have the fund anyway—and we do not address the disadvantages in regard to Aboriginal health, education or any of those things while we are doing it. So we produce some more money for some more land on top of the land that is able to be purchased for Aboriginals by ATSIC and on top of the land that has already been provided by the states and is continuing to be provided by the states. Again, I quote my state of South Australia where 20 per cent of the land is in Aboriginal hands.

PARA.TAB: I refer back to the collective ideology of the honourable member for Gilmore about Aboriginals and say that some of those people who live on the Pitjantjatjara land are now starting to question the fact that, because they own inalienable freehold title, they cannot deal with any individual rights or the commercial realisms and possibilities that they have sitting under that extraordinarily valuable piece of ground.

The life expectancy for an Aboriginal boy was 18 years shorter than his non-Aboriginal counterpart in 1992; the life expectancy for a girl was nearly 20 years shorter; and infant mortality rates were three times the rates for all Australians and so on. Here we have another bill about land which does not deal with these very important issues.

I will now come to the bill itself. The bill deals largely with the mechanics of establishing the Indigenous Land Corporation and the funding arrangements. In the process it amends the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act. It will bring about a statutory corporation with the management vested in the board of directors of seven persons, five of whom must be indigenous people.

Let me just address that matter. The board is to be appointed by the minister. The directors hold office for not more than four years. The board is responsible for the proper and efficient performance of the Indigenous Land Corporation and will determine the policy of the Indigenous Land Corporation with respect to any matter.

It would seem to me that one of the essential requirements of that board is to have business expertise. After all, if it is going to exist, it is going to be a board which will purchase and determine the policy of land worth hundreds of millions of dollars. In fact, the way I read the bill, there will be somewhere in the order of $500 million available, if used, in the first 10 years or so for the purchase of land for collective Aboriginal groups. Leaving all other things in the bill aside, I would have thought the one essential requirement should be that those people should be as expert as you can possibly get. As far as I am concerned, if they are all Aboriginals, that will be great. But it seems to me that the primary requisite must be their expertise. That is the first thing I would like to raise.

There are a number of questions that need to be raised on this matter and I would like to very quickly go through them. The major deficiencies of the bill really fall into four categories. It provides little direction on economic improvements and how they will be delivered to Aboriginal people. I raised that before. There is insufficient distinction concerning land acquisition between the bill and the Native Title Act. I referred to that original intertwining which has now disappeared.

It allows the funds to be directed only through Aboriginal corporations. That is the second important matter I want to raise. Why only Aboriginal corporations? Why not individuals, families or corporations in the legal sense? Why could they not be minority groups, for example? If we are really serious about doing some good for Aboriginal people, why are we not dealing with the sorts of things that will encourage them to get on individually like Miss Freeman and others of her abilities?

The public accountability stipulations are insufficient. I have many questions. Apart from land, what economic benefits can be directed out of this bill to Aboriginal people? They might be there incidentally, but they are not in the bill. What assistance can the ILC give Aboriginal people to establish their own businesses—none or very little—or to facilitate Aboriginal involvement in businesses? Why a 50 per cent limitation? Why is financial assistance limited to Aboriginal corporations? Why discount the possibility of Aborigines holding minority interests?

Where is the ILC directed to create job opportunities? It is not. Where is the ILC directed to provide surety of loans other than the connection with land purchase? Why does the bill exclude land claimable under Aboriginal land rights but not land claimable under the Native Title Act? We know why that is; nobody knows who is going to get land under the Native Title Act. Why is the definition of the interest in land wide enough to include native title land?

What proportion of funds does the government expect to go to land acquisitions versus land management? What proportion of funds does the government expect to go to metropolitan based Aborigines versus rural based Aborigines? What proportion of funds does the government expect to be directed to each of the states? What cognisance will be taken of the fact that some of the states have done a lot for their Aborigines? As I said, New South Wales and Victoria have done almost nothing. I probably would have to include Tasmania, although there are not many Aborigines left in Tasmania. What proportion of funds does the government expect will be directed towards housing and infrastructure versus land acquisition? Those are extremely important points.

I think the flexibilities in this bill simply are not great enough. If the government is serious about trying to do good for the Aboriginal cause and for Aboriginals in general, then it will take notice of our proposed amendments and not simply run around accusing us of trying to make the hurdle too high to jump over it. I have been to all of the people who objected to the Native Title Act, as I still do, and all of those people say, `If this bill has the right results, we are all for it.' If the government takes notice of that, it will get some benefit from it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —People like us who are involved in the area of public policy often do not understand or appreciate the very privileged position that we have occupied over recent years, particularly in connection with the changes that have taken place in Australian attitudes, Australian laws, Australian agencies and Australian provisions to attempt to compensate Aboriginal Australians for 200 years of dispossession.

PARA.TAB: I agree with those people who have made the observation that present-day white Australians do not have to feel—and should not feel—guilt about the circumstances of the past. These people have not poisoned Aboriginal waterholes; they have not given Aboriginals poisoned flour; they have not gone out on shooting expeditions against Aboriginals; and they have not forced Aboriginals off land which in contemporary times was legally identified as theirs. That observation is perfectly correct. It is not a matter of feeling guilt; it is simply a matter of recognising the reality of the past.

The Mabo decision by the High Court was an extremely important point in the developments that have taken place. I suppose the first milestone was the 1967 referendum. On previous occasions I have referred to the fact that all of the people who participated in that referendum should continue to feel proud of themselves for the decision they made. I am old enough to have voted in that referendum. I am also old enough to have been able to participate in the campaign for a yes vote.

Another important milestone was the 1975 Aboriginal land rights legislation in the federal parliament. Then we had the establishment of ATSIC, which was designed to give Aboriginal people the right to participate in the development of Aboriginal policy and in the administration of Aboriginal affairs. We also had the establishment of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. Then we had the High Court Mabo decision, which as I said was a decision of monumental importance to dispel forever the concept of terra nullius: that is, the concept that Australia was not occupied before 1788.

The native title legislation enacted by this parliament attempted to interpret for legislative and procedural purposes the nature of the High Court Mabo decision. Now we have the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994, which is another milestone. I believe that for the rest of my days I will be able to look back with considerable pride on the period of my participation in the development and implementation of public policy regarding Aboriginal Australians. I believe that most people on the government benches will be able to do the same. I know that there are also some members on the opposition benches who will be able to do this.

In terms of conscientious commitment and a basic understanding of the issues and objectives that are involved, as well as the purposes that are sought to be achieved, there are many members on the opposition benches who will not be able to look back on these years of policy change and changing circumstances with a great deal of personal pride—for example, if at some time in the future their descendants have some occasion to peruse the Hansard of the debates to see what their ancestors were saying.

These developments were momentous occasions in Australia's history. At the end of 200 years of very significant dispossession, why should they not be? They were long overdue. This legislation is part of the Commonwealth's overall response to the Mabo decision. The Native Title Act was the first significant response that we made. The point has been made that the Mabo decision and the resultant Native Title Act were put into place as a means by which those Aboriginal Australians who today, after 200 years of dispossession, are able to establish a continuing association with the land with which they are currently associated and which they currently occupy can perhaps make a valid claim for that land.

About 30 per cent of the Australian Aboriginal population of about 260,000 presently live on Aboriginal land—that is, the old Aboriginal reserve land. A relatively small proportion of Aboriginal Australians will be able to use the native title legislation to make a valid claim for the land with which they are able to prove some continuing association. That means that 70 per cent of Aboriginal Australians cannot benefit from the native title legislation. The question then arises as to why that should be so. Of course, the reason is that those 70 per cent are the most dispossessed of all Aboriginal Australians. They are the ones who were forced off their land. They are the ones who were tossed off their land. They are the ones for whom circumstances were made impossible. They are the people who have now moved off the land which their forefathers occupied for 60,000 years.

About 14 per cent of the Australian land mass is now owned by Aboriginal Australians, who constitute about three per cent of our population. I have heard members of the opposition say that that proves they own a disproportionate area of the Australian land mass. Everyone knows that that 14 per cent of the Australian continent which Aboriginal Australians own, which they have been able to retain and have had declared as land over which they have title, is probably incapable of even very sparse grazing. If it had been arable, valuable agricultural land or good grazing land, it would not now be theirs. The nature of the 14 per cent of the Australian continent which they own is obvious.

This legislation will establish a fund that will make it possible for 70 per cent of Aboriginal Australians—those who are the most dispossessed—to access funds and, in turn, buy back some of the land. I simply say to members of the National Party in particular that some members of my wider family are still on the land after my great-grandparents took out leases in the last century. In some cases there are now three generations. Those relatives of mine say they have a very strong attachment to the land. They do; they cleared and developed it. They have enjoyed the successes of utilising that land and they have suffered the hardships such as droughts, floods and fires. The good times and the bad times have all been part of their experience. But that is three generations over about 100 years.

Aboriginal Australians occupied that land from which they were dispossessed for possibly 60,000 years. In many cases, the point has been admirably made that the occupation of that land for 60,000 years established a very close and necessary relationship—a fundamental relationship—between Aboriginal Australians and the land. That underpins the type of approach which this government has been taking to this question. It really is not good enough for members of the opposition to say that the land question should, in a sense, be put aside and that we have to concentrate exclusively on housing, health, employment and other types of social and economic conditions. Of course, we have to pay attention to them, but not to the exclusion of land, which is fundamental—in many respects, it is at the core—to Aboriginal concerns and culture.

The purpose of establishing the fund is to make it possible for indigenous Australians to acquire and manage land in a sustainable way to provide economic, social and cultural benefits. It has been very carefully tailored. The way in which the fund will be developed means that, at the end of a 10-year period, there will be about $1.1 billion in it.

Some people have suggested that indicates that all the money being made available will not be immediately available for the purchase of land. Of course it will not. In the first year it will be about $45 million. Over the 10-year period, a progressive cumulative amount is available. The larger proportion of the total allocation each year is put into a fund for investment purposes so that, after 10 years, that $1.1 billion, with estimated interest on the investments at 4.5 per cent, will be providing about $45 million in today's money terms—in real terms—for the progressive purchase of land by Aboriginal Australians to make it possible for them to develop and to re-establish their links with it. It has been carefully tailored. It is a very sensible approach. For all those reasons, I strongly support this proposal.

We have not yet been able to see the detailed amendments. I do not think they have been distributed because they have not yet been moved. Our understanding, on the basis of some of the contributions that have been made by members of the opposition thus far, is that the opposition is concerned that the purposes of the land fund should be broadened to include health, housing and other types of social and economic community benefits for Aboriginals.

The reason for this legislation is to put on top of those other arrangements a specific provision for the most dispossessed Aboriginals to have access to funds which will make it possible for them to purchase land. In other words, it appears to me—I hope that I am not misrepresenting the opposition's position—that a central part of its position is that it is prepared to support the land fund if it is not a land fund. That is just too cute. At the same time opposition members say, `What we are concerned about is making sure that additional funds will go into housing, community services, employment, health and education.'

Prior to the last election all members of the opposition endorsed a package called Fightback. They all defended and promoted it. It was their manifesto for the last election. Fightback involved a cut in the funding of ATSIC of $90 million. We retained that level of funding. In fact, there has been an increase in it. The funding for ATSIC and all those other programs has remained intact. This is new funding. The total amount of new funding over that 10-year period is something in excess of $1.2 billion for this specific purpose. I despair at the position which has been adopted by opposition members when, as I say, in that very politically cute way they say, `We will support the land fund if you change it so that it is not a land fund.' We have specific purposes in introducing this measure. I believe that the amendments will be considered genuinely, as they should be, because that commitment has been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). I do not think there is any chance in the world that this government will allow those possible amendments to destroy the purpose of this legislation, and nor should it.

I do not think people should be fooled by the attitude which the opposition has adopted. Everyone needs to remember that the opposition was dragged screaming by the forces of public opinion in connection with this issue. Very serious divisions exist within the opposition concerning this question and the general question of Aboriginal affairs. Its whole philosophy, sentiment and inclination is against the land fund.

This might be an attempt to paint a moderate face for the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), who describes himself as a progressive conservative. What in heaven's name is a progressive conservative? Does a progressive conservative remain in the same place by moving forward, or does he move forward by remaining in the same place? We have the Left, Right and Centre in the Labor Party and the non-aligned or independents. We have some right in the centre of the non-aligned. But I understand that the two major groups in the opposition are the conservatives and the progressives. So what would those who want to straddle both groups and seek elevation to leadership call themselves?

PARA.TAB: Some of the particular amendments that will apparently be proposed by opposition members stem to a very large extent from some of the concerns that they have expressed before. TALK.START.PARA: —Before the previous speaker, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), spoke in this debate, I privately said to him that he should endeavour to be accurate in what he was going to say because I would be careful to pick up any points that were not quite correct. I will pick up a couple of his points. He said that this side of the House was going to put land issues aside and concentrate on health, housing, education and so on at the expense of land issues. He also said that the coalition is prepared to support the land fund if it is not a land fund. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) made a similar statement earlier in the day. It is important to understand that coalition members actually said that in the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill we are not seeking to replace the fundamental principles of land; with our amendments we wish to extend and improve the legislation but not take out the things that are there in terms of its intent.

PARA.TAB: I say to government members today—and I think it is important that they get this message loud and clear—that we have in fact quite significantly moved our position on this subject in the last few weeks. We have sought to come to this place with a new and different position from that which we previously adopted publicly, and we have put some amendments on the table. If, as we so often hear, government members are sincere in their protestations about trying to take a constructive and bipartisan approach to some of those issues, I urge them to demonstrate some of the generosity of spirit they so often talk about and try to respond to some of those amendments in a constructive and sensible way. Do not spurn the opportunity that is there.

TALK.START.PARA: —What arrogance!
—It is not a question of arrogance.
—It is arrogance.
—I suggest to you that the arrogance has come from the government, which has said, `This is our legislation. Take it or leave it.' We have come along to this place—

—You are the one who has the arrogance to suggest that we do not talk to Aboriginal people.
