PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Order! The member for Leichhardt will cease interjecting. The member for Aston might help if he were to address his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will endeavour to do so. I think it is sad that, when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) indicated that we would look to support this bill, provided that there were some amendments, before those amendments were even mentioned or put on the table in any shape or form we had an instantaneous reaction from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), talking about confidence tricks and so on. This clearly demonstrated that the government is not sincere about taking a bipartisan approach. As I have said in this place before, this is a re-run of what happened in the Mabo debate, where on two separate occasions we approached the government to see whether we could sit down and talk about establishing some common ground. Specifically, the Prime Minister and the minister were not interested in trying to establish common ground with the opposition on these matters.

PARA.TAB: It is not comfortable for government members to be reminded of these occasions because they like to pontificate about taking a bipartisan position, but they want a bipartisan position only when we are going to do everything they want. They do not accept that there can be sincerely held views on this side of the chamber that are well motivated and absolutely genuine, and that perhaps we ought to sit down and talk about some of those issues.

It has been very noticeable that that attitude has developed in this parliament. In the previous parliament we talked about setting up the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, and those discussions could and did take place with a very fruitful outcome. But, since we have had this Prime Minister, that has unfortunately not been possible. It is important that that is understood from the outset. Government members talk about there being people of goodwill on this side of the House so, when people on this side of the House who might have some common views with those on the other side seek to get that cooperative response, I believe that there is a responsibility on the government to show that generosity of spirit that I mentioned.

I have recently travelled around this country a lot on Aboriginal affairs matters. I did it as a shadow minister, I have done it as a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and I have done it with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island Affairs over the last four years or so. My position on the land fund has been on record for some time as being very much in support in principle. But it is also important to recognise that land alone is not going to solve all of the problems of the indigenous people of this country.

We need a holistic approach and that holistic approach has to include the subject of land. We have to recognise that Aboriginal people around the country have a very strong and quite sincere belief in the significance of land and they have an almost spiritual attachment to land. Certainly the rural community and the non-Aboriginal community will say that they also have a special attachment to land. I have talked to farmers and Aboriginal people around this country and there are strongly held views about this by both communities, but quite clearly what comes across is that indigenous people do feel a particular attraction for the land that cannot be articulated in the way that the Western culture would have it.

I think that, regardless of whether we understand it or like it, the reality is that land is very important for Aboriginal people. Therefore, we should be supporting this bill if we possibly can because it seems to me that it is part of that holistic approach. There are those who will argue that land in itself really will not do any particular good for Aboriginal people, and many statistics show that Aboriginal people who own their land are not necessarily in a particularly better condition than those who do not. But I do not think that that is the fundamental point. The ownership of land philosophically should be an important motivator in any other remedies that we try to put in place to improve the lot of indigenous people. The Australian experience has shown that owning land per se has not done a great deal.

On a recent overseas trip I looked at indigenous issues in Canada and the United States. Whilst there are areas in Canada and the States where indigenous people own their land, their wellbeing in health, housing and education has not necessarily significantly improved. Having said that, the land issue should form part of a holistic approach and not just be put on one side. If we want to deal with health, housing, education and the like, we also have to deal with the land, because it is such a fundamental aspect of this issue. It seems to me that the state governments have accepted that for many years. However imperfect some of those state governments may have been in land issues for Aboriginal people, programs of one sort or another have been in place for some time. For the last four-odd years, ATSIC's program has had bipartisan support.

This legislation deals with land, land management and the upgrading of land. All those things are important. The coalition has suggested that, in addition to those functions—not instead of—we perhaps need to give some more emphasis to economic development and that, where purchases are made, there should be some demonstration of Aboriginal wellbeing—part of that holistic approach. The amounts of money involved are relatively small. By the time we take into account the money that ATSIC already spends in this area, we are talking about only another $24 million a year—not a huge amount.

We have suggested some amendments to extend the scope and so on of the legislation and to make some accountability improvements. Some of those amendments go to the sorts of things that the government itself talked about putting in place when it first mentioned this legislation, but it has not actually put them in the detail of the legislation. It would help everybody concerned if we could sit down and look at some of those amendments more calmly and slowly, rather than hurl epithets across the chamber. The amendments can make the legislation better. The accountability will help provide more effective management and direction, and that is so necessary to break the welfare dependency that unfortunately has grown up in so many Aboriginal communities. I do not want to stand here and catalogue the many disadvantages in the Aboriginal communities, but it is important to remember that we are talking about trying to take a multifaceted approach to this issue. Land is an integral part of that approach, and we have to deal with the health issues.

I was very saddened by the comments made earlier this afternoon by the honourable member for Moreton—with whom I have always got along very well—on spending in the area of health. A lot of the alleged extra health money announced by the government this year was effectively a continuation of the national Aboriginal health strategy that is already in place but was about to expire. Let us not play games with money and let us not play games with health. Health is important. We need to do things in the field of health from the bottom up. Health is important in improving the lot of Aboriginal people; without proper health, those other things will not happen.

I have stood in this place and told stories of experiences I have had in Aboriginal communities around this country where there are 25, sometimes 30, people living in a house. No human being should be expected to live in those conditions. There is obviously much to be done in the area of housing.

If people do not get education, they do not get jobs. If they do not get jobs, they do not get an income. That means that they do not get a house and that means that their health is not any good. There is much to be done in the area of education. The rates of attendance at and achievement in schooling for Aboriginal people are appalling compared with the rates for the broader community. I do not condemn the Aboriginal community for that; I am saying that it is a fact that we have to deal with. Having had a decade—there is no question about it—of good intention from the government to fix those issues, the reality is that many of those issues have not been fixed. Therefore, we have to look at new ways of trying to deal with some of those issues.

Even in good times, the Aboriginal unemployment rate is so much worse than the unemployment rate for the rest of the community that we have to look at special measures to generate economic activity in the area of employment in indigenous communities. If we do not do those things, if we do not provide some self-esteem and some self-respect, which derive from good housing, good health, good education, employment and ownership of one's own land and one's own property, we get what we have seen so often. With that loss of self-esteem and self-respect, and with people having idle time on their hands, there is substance abuse, crime, over-representation in the legal system and all the terrible problems that come with that.

One thing that saddened me in recent months—I have seen this over several years in Australia—was that, although America and Canada take slightly different approaches than us, the profiles for indigenous people are very similar. Even where they have given land, the profiles are very similar. Therefore, whilst I accept the importance of land to this issue, it is only one facet of the issue and we have to take a holistic approach.

Although ATSIC has not had relatively all that long to make an impact, it has had its share of challenges and difficulties. It is not unreasonable that we make sure that any new body that we set up is set up having learnt the lessons from the past. ATSIC has certainly been overcentralised and it has not always had the experience it has needed in particular areas. In its first three years of operation, its own deputy chairperson has been consistently vocal about the fact that it did not have the expertise to run health, for example. The government has obviously acknowledged that. Therefore, in this area, we have to make sure that management of this ILC has that sort of expertise.

When we talk about involving the states, government members—in some senses, I suppose, understandably—scoff, `What about the states?' In many ways some states have not been as constructive as I would have liked to have seen them be over the years on this issue of Aboriginal affairs. I do not perceive that as necessarily taking a party political complexion. Whichever party is in power in some states, we tend to have some difficulties.

If we are going to make some progress on these issues, where those services are often delivered at a state level, we need to try to involve the states and to get them on side. Therefore, when we talk about amendments that will try to involve the states in the process, it is not to abrogate the responsibility that this parliament picked up in the 1967 referendum. It is to say that the reality is that we need to involve all players in the process. It is important that we try to involve the states, in the same way as it is important that we try to get appropriate skills. I simply reject the notion, as put forward by the honourable member for Moreton earlier today, that it is a confidence trick and that we are distorting the legislation, and so on.

If those opposite sincerely believe that we need to take a bipartisan approach and if they sincerely believe that there are people on this side who are, if you like, the good guys—I think the honourable member for Charlton has paid me that compliment from time to time—I ask them in all seriousness, in all sincerity, to take a constructive look at the amendments. Let us really try to improve the legislation for the sake of the indigenous people and let us get the whole parliament pulling in the same direction. Let those opposite not just say, `We have not agreed with you for months and you do not like our legislation, so we will not accept any of your amendments.' Do not reject them out of hand. Let us have a bipartisan approach. The leader of the coalition has said that he wants to support the legislation subject to those amendments. Let us try to do it. Let us try to work in a sensible way.

I am a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. If we want to see reconciliation work, having an ongoing partisan political split on matters Aboriginal is only going to cause division in our community. It will cause division between black and white within the Aboriginal community and within the non-Aboriginal community.

If we, as the elected leaders of this country, can get together, be constructive, perhaps negotiate some of our differences on these issues and set an example for the rest of the country, it seems to me that reconciliation processes in the rest of the country will have a lot more opportunity to succeed. I certainly urge the government to look at the amendments on their merits and to take Aboriginal affairs out of the party political arena. Let us be constructive for the good of all Australians.

PARA.TAB: The decision of Mabo v. Queensland (No. 2) on 3 June 1992 was a significant event in the history of Australia and for its indigenous peoples. On 10 December 1992, another significant event took place. On that day the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating) made the most significant act of public reconciliation to that date. In his speech in Redfern he talked about the need for the rest of Australia to recognise `that it was we who did the dispossession; that we took the traditional lands and smashed the traditional way of life'. That was tough talking and very appropriate.

Perhaps in urban Australia, and certainly not in the Adelaide Club or the Melbourne Club, it is not recognised how significant this statement was to Australia's indigenous people. When I campaigned as the Labor candidate for Leichhardt in remote communities in the Cape York Peninsula, the Prime Minister's speech was well known, yet information to such remote communities from Canberra is often scarce; such was its significance.

This bill today turns the Prime Minister's words into reality. It is that significant. It is crucial for any reconciliation with Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that those dispossessed indigenous people now receive compensation—I emphasise the word `compensation'. When the Prime Minister said `we' he probably meant those people who came to Australia after European settlement, but `we' must also include those people representing `us'; that is, the government. From the first colonial governments to state and federal governments, there was official support, and complicity in a lot of cases, for what is now recognised as dispossession. A notorious example of this is what happened in my electorate in the late 1950s and early 1960s to the communities of Weipa, Napranum and Mapoon.

The complicity of the government in dispossession culminated in 1963 when the Mapoon community was literally razed to the ground by fire by the Queensland government and people were forced to move to what is now called New Mapoon in the northern peninsula area. The people of Mapoon have led a very courageous fight to retain their land, and that settlement is now booming. People are returning, and with the support of both the Queensland and the federal governments there is a great future for Mapoon. Mapoon has all the problems that have been referred to in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, but I am confident that those people returning to their homeland will find a future.
It is very interesting to see what happened in Weipa. Father Frank Brennan's book, Land Rights Queensland Style, states:

After John Pilger's documentary "The Secret Country" was screened in Australia, Mark Rayner, the managing director of Comalco complained that the review of the film perpetuated "the long discredited claim that the Mapoon Aboriginal mission was closed to make way for Comalco's bauxite mining activities". Rayner was right when he refuted the assertion "that the Mapoon mission was closed to enable Comalco to mine there". But he did paint an incomplete picture. In 1959, Comalco was granted special bauxite mining leases over a large part of the Weipa Aboriginal reserve which is south of Mapoon. To accommodate Comalco's interests, the Queensland government, without compensation, reduced the area of the Weipa reserve from over 354,000 hectares to a mere 124 hectares. The Queensland government continued to misrepresent to parliament the area of the Weipa reserve until November 1982 when the then Minister for Aboriginal and Island Affairs admitted a discrepancy of over 354,000 hectares. Though Comalco had surrendered much of that land back to the crown, it was never regazetted as an Aboriginal reserve.

SPEECH.PARA: In reality, we cannot talk about this bill without talking about the complicity of prior governments. It is not just a matter of guilt, as has been suggested by some previous speakers, but a matter of compensation. This government acts with both compassion and responsibility. We have to compensate those acts of dispossession which cannot be assisted by the native title legislation.

PARA.TAB: In my electorate of Leichhardt, many Aboriginal people miss out under the Native Title Act. The Wik people at Aurukun have a close affiliation with their land. The community of Injinoo in the northern peninsula has a similar affinity. In the same area, there are also the communities of Bamaga and Seisia, which are made up of people mainly from the Torres Strait, mainly from Saibai Island. Most of those people came relatively voluntarily; nevertheless, those communities would not benefit in any way from the native title legislation.

New Mapoon, which is in the northern peninsula, consists of dispossessed people from Mapoon. Umagico, a community in the northern peninsula, consists of people who were resettled—I use `resettled' as a euphemism—from Lockhart River. The community of Lockhart River has been shifted geographically several times. Lockhart itself consists of different language groups. The Yarrabah community, which is south of Cairns, is a very relevant example of the need for this legislation. The Yarrabah community consists of people who have a long affiliation with that land. At one stage Yarrabah was basically a penal colony. People were sent to Yarrabah if they transgressed even minor rules of other reserves and missions. Other people were forcibly moved to Yarrabah from other parts of Far North Queensland. There are other such examples in my electorate.

So Mabo is not enough. We need this legislation. I thought for a while that there was some recognition by the Liberal Party in this regard. But I think the coalition's attitude on this matter is quite confused. On 9 September 1992 the leader of the Liberal Party in the Queensland parliament, Mrs Sheldon—the shadow minister at the table, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), is a Queensland member so no doubt he will be influenced by his own state policy on this matter—was reported as follows in the Courier-Mail:

The Liberals would establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Land Acquisition Fund with an initial $6 million, with $3 million to be added each year, Mrs Sheldon said when launching her party's northern policy in Cairns.
Under the Liberal plan Aboriginal communities would have membership on advisory councils in the management of national parks.

The Liberal leader said they could also advise the appropriate Minister as to any specific funds they needed to buy a business, such as a cattle property or tourist attraction, which they could run themselves and make a profit.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the Liberal Party policy as at 9 September 1992. The honourable member for Aston, who preceded me, came to Normanton in the Far North, at the same time as the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) and a lot of other people, as part of the opposition's consultative process on the Mabo judgment. He said that the local people should see Anne Warner about when land was raised. He said that the Fraser government brought in land rights in the Northern Territory, and he referred to a 7 1/2 per cent land tax which he seemed to favour. He then said that Goss and Warner should look at the same idea. Apparently, on 5 July 1993, the honourable member for Aston agreed with Joan Sheldon.

PARA.TAB: We now come to today, and I really do not know what the opposition's position is. As I said before, if you listen to each opposition speaker you get a different point of view. It seems that the opposition's position is that the money would be better spent on health and education. This very clearly flies in the face of what Australia's indigenous people want. I am not suggesting that they do not want money spent on those areas—of course they do—but it is sheer hypocrisy from a party whose policy at the last election was Fightback. Under Fightback there was to be a 10 per cent reduction in expenditure in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. That was the policy those opposite took to the last election, and at the same time, it seems, they advocated that a land fund was much more important than spending money on health, housing and all those matters, as long as the states did it. They have done a complete backflip.

That is where the honourable member for Aston's argument completely falls down. The point is: those opposite have not consulted with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. There is no Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander person, spokesperson or group who supports their position. If there were, Mr Deputy Speaker, you could bet that the Liberal Party would have them on the television screens of the nation tonight. The Liberal Party would bring someone out who supported its position. But we have not heard anybody because no Aboriginal person with any standing in the Aboriginal community would support its position. The shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), seems very confused about these issues. She said in the Canberra Times on 22 August:

SPEECH.PARA: Aboriginal people themselves say that land is a key to their wellbeing and I think for those Aboriginal people who live in the outback . . . that is very true.

In the same interview she said she had `no illusions that I am going to come up with solutions' to the problem of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. She is very honest, yet I understand that the gist of one of the amendments suggested by the coalition before the House is that before any purchase of land they must show—I do not know who `they' are—how it will improve health, housing and economic needs. Who must show this? Who must they show this to? Who is going to make that judgment? The shadow minister has no illusion that she has solutions. That shows what a farce the opposition's position is.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Aston says that he has consulted throughout the Aboriginal community. I admit that the honourable member for Aston does travel to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities more than most people opposite, but in reality there has been no consultation by the coalition in relation to its position. It has just been cooked up in the last day or two after a party brawl. How can you suggest that is consultation? It is a position that is clearly a factional compromise within the Liberal Party.

In contrast, this government has consulted with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people far and wide. The Special Minister of State (Mr Johns) wrote to all ATSIC regional councils and prescribed organisations under the Native Title Act and peak indigenous industry, farming, mining, environmental and religious organisations on 11 April 1994 seeking the submission of views on the structure and operation of the proposed land fund. Responses, on the whole, were positive and constructive.

The Prime Minister met with representatives of major Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations on 18 April this year. At that meeting, indigenous representatives agreed that the land fund be administered by an independent specialist body with a focus on indigenous land issues. We have the bill before the House. The Prime Minister met again with these representatives on 16 June 1994. Prior to that meeting, representatives were provided with copies of the draft bill. Consensus was reached on the main features of the legislation and a number of changes were made to address the particular concerns raised at the meeting. Contrast that with the coalition's approach: a party brawl and a mishmashed compromised policy to shore up the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer).

However the coalition's position is disguised or dressed up, it will still be recognised by Australia's indigenous people for what it is: a rejection of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's right to compensation for acts that were perpetrated by governments—colonial, federal and state—over the last 200 years. Add that to the 10 per cent cut in Fightback and what do you have? A rejection of Aboriginal people's moral right for their land with which they have a deep spiritual affiliation. In remote areas of Australia, you cannot divorce potential economic independence from land tenure.

I am confident this bill, as part of a trilogy—that is, the native title legislation, this bill and the social justice package—will meet many of the aspirations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people coming out of the High Court native title decision. To this can be added a very important further dimension: the question of housing. It is particularly pertinent for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in regional and urban Australia that we get the question of Aboriginal housing right. I am very pleased that the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe), has had long consultations with ATSIC about this issue. I am very confident that we will get a package in consultation with the states, and I hope that what seems to be the coalition's change of heart over this bill will reflect some more benevolence in relation to Aboriginal housing from the states.

In conclusion, it would be foolish for me, or any other government speaker, to suggest that Australian people are unanimous in their support of the government's approach on this issue. Reconciliation still has a long way to go, but at least the Australian people know where this government stands on this issue. At least the Australian people know where the Prime Minister stands. The people of my electorate know where I stand. As for the coalition, after the mess that came out of today's party room blue, after the Leader of the Opposition's little foray in the Northern Territory, after the 10 per cent cut promised in Fightback and then the complete backflip on health and education, the Australian people would not have a clue where it stands on this issue. In this House, we stand very proud in support of the native title legislation and in support of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd), one has to say that he has followed a memorable list of speakers who have demonstrated beyond any doubt that a bipartisan approach towards Aboriginal policy is about as far from the mind of the Labor Party as it is possible to be. I say that with genuine sadness. I cannot understand how honourable members on all sides of this House have in recent years been able to achieve a considerable degree of bipartisanship on complex national issues such as immigration, but have failed utterly to demonstrate a similar level of bipartisanship when it comes to that component of Australia's indigenous population who, for 200 years, have more need of our support than certainly any other community in this land.

PARA.TAB: It will go down in perpetuity that this government, in the 11 years it has been in power, despite all its rhetoric, has achieved so little. Every attempt has been made in this debate on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill, commencing with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at lunch time, to paint the opposition as a perfidious group of people who cannot be trusted. The Prime Minister was followed by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), who said we were treacherous in our attitude towards this legislation.

I will take the time of the House very briefly to go through the history of Aboriginal policy in recent decades. In 1967, 92 per cent of the Australian people, in a rare successful national referendum to change the constitution, determined that Aboriginal Australians should be given the same opportunities as everyone else. If I could read into that, I would say that they said something else. They told the parliament of Australia and everybody in it, `Don't turn Aborigines into some sort of political football. Fix the problem.' The years have passed into decades and efforts have been made by all sides when in government to do this. I put it simply to the House, in the context of this legislation, that the greatest progress has been made when there was demonstrable bipartisanship, and the least progress has been made when this House has remained divided on fundamental issues.

I speak on this subject as a former shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. I accepted in those years, as I do now as a member of this parliament, that a sacred trust is incumbent on all of us to assist our fellow Australians, especially those original Australians, to give them opportunities similar to those available to everyone else. That is why this legislation has been held up by the opposition to close examination and some criticism.

Land is an essential ingredient in the social as well as the economic and religious background of the Aboriginal people. It must also be remembered that in many respects Aboriginal communities differ as widely as those of any other community in this country. On the one hand, there are the tribal communities, whose affinity with the land is absolute. Most people in this chamber would not doubt that. At the other extreme, there are urbanised communities of Aborigines who have different social and economic problems.

The rationale behind this legislation was simply that the vast majority of Aborigines would not be beneficiaries under the Mabo decision of the High Court and under the Native Title Act. I think that is an established fact, although, as was pointed out by my honourable colleagues earlier, so far very few, if any, have seen any results over the last two years. Nevertheless, the point we are making is that when the government talks about over $1 billion for investment in land it should do so without making a distinction between land investment and the need to face the range of so clearly identified social and economic problems faced by many Aborigines whether or not they will be living on that newly purchased land.

Many people in this chamber—I am one—have had the opportunity in recent years to visit a range of Aboriginal settlements and cattle properties in Queensland, the Northern Territory and elsewhere. Perhaps the most common comment we hear while on those visits is, `Yes, we have the land; there is no dispute about that. But we do not have the capital. We do not have the means. We do not have the knowledge. We do not have access to knowledge to make it possible for us to turn that land into a viable economic capacity to clothe and feed our people and to give them the opportunities they need.'

This legislation gives us an opportunity to address that. The legislation makes the point very validly that it will benefit existing Aboriginal holders of land who previously, as I said, had the problem that they did not have access to capital. On the other hand, it will also benefit future purchasers of land on the same basis. We wholeheartedly support that principle. Unfortunately, there are aspects of the legislation that are not, in our opinion, so satisfactory.

Before I go into the detail of the bill, I will make a wider point about the whole context of Aboriginal policy as seen by the opposition and as seen from the government's side. As I noted earlier, the government has nothing kind to say about our policy. Nevertheless, the fact of history is that the first land rights legislation passed by an Australian parliament was that of the Fraser government in 1975.

The important point I want to emphasise is that during the eight years of the Fraser government we probably achieved a greater degree of bipartisanship on Aboriginal land policy issues and on general issues relating to the need to improve the circumstances of Australia's Aboriginal population than we have seen in recent years. I think that is regrettable. I would like to see that bipartisanship return to this parliament, because I believe that is the best and the only route by which we will be able to address, in a total sense, the very genuine problems faced by our fellow citizens.

The suggestion has been made by the government that we have opposed everything that has ever happened in Aboriginal policy. What rot! Let us see the record. As I mentioned, the first land rights legislation was passed by the Fraser Liberal-National party government. The ATSIC legislation was supported by the opposition. The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation was supported by the opposition, and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) serves as our delegate on that council.

The Mabo decision of the High Court was accepted by the opposition. We had problems with the Native Title Act. We emphasised, through both chambers of this parliament, the problems we saw with that legislation. At least we were honest enough to face them. We pointed out the difficulties the government was going to face. Over two years later, as I have already pointed out, the record is virtually bare. It has achieved so little because of the manifest difficulties with the Native Title Act, which we identified at the time.

Finally, we are here to debate the land fund legislation. We have put forward a range of amendments. They are open to negotiation with the government. We are serious about a bipartisan approach because we believe it is essential that both sides of this parliament take seriously the whole issue of Aboriginal land rights and what can be done to solve many of their problems.

A number of speakers in this debate have emphasised some of the shortcomings of this legislation. One of the issues they have raised, and one of the matters which at some stage in the future should be addressed, is the collective ownership of land on the one side as distinct from individual ownership of land on the other.

There is absolutely no question that, when you are talking about Aboriginal communities in their tribal environments, collective ownership—through land funds and so forth—is an acceptable formula. There is no doubt about that in my opinion. But the point I made earlier has to be addressed: that is, not every Aboriginal belongs to a tribal community and, therefore, not every Aboriginal sees his or her role with the land in that particular context.

I remember when I was the shadow minister going out to the west of New South Wales and time and again meeting young Aboriginal men and women. They would say, `All that land in front of us belongs to our community. But my children and I cannot get a share of it.' You would ask them why, and the answer would be that it came down to the politics of the community. Aboriginal communities are no more free of politics than are white or any other communities. This parliament may presume that we can simply pass laws which will create a pristine and beautiful future for every Aboriginal simply through the virtue of the transference of the ownership of land, but it will not work. All human beings have the capacity to make variations to situations and to use for their own benefit the influence and the power that they may have.

The provision of an individual title to ownership, or variations of title—which is obviously what we need to be looking at—is to take account of those Aboriginal communities, Aboriginal citizens and Aboriginal families, whether they be extended families or otherwise, who want alternatives to simply trying to access land through the collective ownership model, which we have applied in recent years. The point I am making is simply this: it has not worked and it will not work. Therefore, it is incumbent on the government to look far more seriously at that problem than it has done in recent times.

The main purpose of this legislation is to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land fund which provides for the acquisition of land for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who are unable to benefit from native title. I would like to see for myself how the government is going to use this legislation to help the Torres Strait Islanders, most of whom do not live in the Torres Strait and many of whom are in precisely the community situations and individual family situations which I referred to earlier. Their land problems in Queensland, which is where they principally live, are not the same as the land problems found in traditional Aboriginal communities. Nevertheless, this is an area to which the government has made a commitment. But the question is: to what extent is it going to be able to live up to it?

Another issue which we would like to raise relates to a weakness in the legislation as it currently stands. I refer to the relationship between the land councils and the states. Of course, you mention the word `states' in this House and members of the government usually double up in horror and amusement. The fact is that the states were operating in this country before the Commonwealth was, and they have rights and responsibilities.

I would like to give the House the benefit of hearing the experiences of my own state of New South Wales which, over recent years, has had an excellent record of providing land for Aboriginal communities. In 1983 the Aboriginal Land Rights Act was passed, which provided for all reserves held by the Aboriginal land trust to be transferred to Aboriginal people. The act allowed Aboriginal people to both claim and purchase land, creating a system of land councils. It provided for the equivalent of 7.5 per cent of all New South Wales land tax revenue to be paid into a land council account.

Each year the total amount has varied between $31 million and $51 million. Since 1986, the act has required that 50 per cent of annual appropriations and all interest on investments be accumulated in a statutory investment fund until 31 December 1988. In fact, as at 12 July 1993 there was $263,131,712 in the statutory investment account, in the New South Wales Aboriginal land council fund, the freehold land and building fund, the fixed interest fund and the building fund. That money would include accumulated interest. The other 50 per cent of moneys is available to cover administration and most will help some of the 113 local land councils throughout the state.

Most of the states—but not all, regrettably—also have legislation in place for the provision of funds for the purchase of land for Aboriginal Australians. Yet in this legislation there is not a word about that. As far as the government is concerned, it just does not exist. So when we are talking about the transference of funds for the purchase of land, I put on the record that we are not only talking about the just over $1.2 billion which was covered by this legislation over 10 years; consideration also has to be given to the funds provided by the various states.

If we are going to be serious about this, it is clear that a system has to be in place—on a state-by-state and regional basis—where the states are taken into account. After all, we are talking about the same Aboriginal communities—whether they are beneficiaries of federal or state legislation is immaterial. They want the money, access to the land, the opportunity to develop that land and the economic and social independence that access to that land should provide.

We have also raised issues relating to accountability. As I said, dating right back to the referendum of 1967 the Australian people said, `There are problems facing Australian Aborigines. You, the government, are responsible for fixing those problems.' There would not be a member in this House who would not know that on many occasions we have had to face audiences who, with some scepticism, said, `You are now spending 1 1/2 billion-odd dollars a year federally alone—not counting state funds—and you have not solved the problems.'

As was pointed out by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) in his opening speech this morning, the sad fact is that many of those problems are as bad today as they were 11 years ago when this government came into power—in some respects, they are even worse. In that context, the question of accountability is vital. Yes, the Australian people want the problem solved and yes, they are willing to have their taxes in their billions made available to help solve these problems. But there is a degree of cynicism out there. There is a belief that too much of this money goes to white Australians and not to indigenous Australians, and that, whatever the policy direction may be, the realities are that the solutions have not been found.

It is almost bizarre that, in recent years, we have had legislation before this House in which benchmarking has been mentioned. Yes, there will be benchmarking in health, there will be benchmarking in education and there will be benchmarking in various aspects of Aboriginal social activity. But after the initial speech, precious little evidence has been brought before this House to demonstrate whether that benchmarking has had any benefit at all. Indeed, in most cases very little has happened.

The records of health and education, for example, of indigenous Australians compared with statistics for other Australians stand to be seen for what they are. I refer the House to a comparison of indigenous and non-indigenous Australian statistics which is based on the 1991 census, as prepared by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, and seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether we are talking about income, assets, home ownership, employment, education, qualifications, or housing, this evidence clearly demonstrates that there is no area in which the figures for indigenous Australians are in any sense comparable with figures from across the country. For example, only 12 per cent of indigenous Australians own their own homes compared with 43.1 per cent for the remainder of the community. Of indigenous Australians, 18.2 per cent are purchasing homes compared with 28.5 per cent in the rest of the community. Therefore, a total of 30 per cent of indigenous people own—in the wider sense of the term—their own homes compared with 71.6 per cent of the community as a whole. The story is similar in education or anywhere else. It is not an impressive record, considering the time and the money that has been spent over recent decades.

PARA.TAB: My final comment to the House is this: the opposition genuinely wants to see a bipartisan policy in this area. We have come forward with a range of amendments which we believe will strengthen this legislation and make it more effective. But the onus is on the government to demonstrate that its intentions are not just political and that, in fact, it really does have at heart the welfare of the indigenous population of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that self-deception is the greatest treason. There is probably no greater treason in the world than to do the wrong thing for the right reason. The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill is at best a silly bill and at worst very dangerous. Frankly, I am going to vote for this legislation because I am a coward. I cannot be bothered facing up to the hassle of those within the party who would use that against me. I console myself with the fact that my vote will make no difference. The bill will be passed anyway, so to oppose it would in a sense be a futile gesture. I hope the many Aboriginal people in my electorate and throughout Western Australia whom I have discussed this bill with understand and recognise my predicament.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt—I do not know who said it but the truth has been demonstrated today—that the emotion of any argument is inversely proportional to one's knowledge of the subject. Today, we have heard speaker after speaker from both sides of the parliament saying that land is absolutely essential to the wellbeing of Aboriginal people—essential to their health and every aspect of their lives. As always, the truth is that that is sometimes correct. In my electorate I have community people who would, in their off pay week in Derby, probably sell all their land for a corned beef sandwich. That does not mean that there are not others who are very committed to their land.

Let us look at the facts of the matter. If we look at Aboriginal dispossession in those areas of Australia where it has been most complete—Victoria and Tasmania—we see that the average health of Aboriginal people is far better than that of those who are surrounded by land. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) was up at Utopia a few weeks ago making a fool of himself. Utopia is a case in point. People in Utopia have owned their land for 15 years. The condition of the people at Utopia is the same today as when I visited them some years ago. I am not saying that there have not been beneficiaries because of course there have. Overwhelmingly, the beneficiaries have been those employed by the Aboriginal industry and particularly the lawyers and employees of welfare groups. We need to look at the real problem.

The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) talked about the referendum in 1967. He said that the people of Australia voted to give Aboriginals equality. He is wrong. That is what they thought they voted for. That is certainly what I voted for in that legislation. We actually voted to give the government of the day the right to make separate rules for our Aboriginal people. Mr Deputy Speaker, I can tell you that when apartheid comes to this land it is under that heading that it will arrive. That will be the constitutional grounds on which it is established.

With respect to land, this legislation merely perpetuates the mistakes of the past. It has been made clear to me by Aboriginal people that there is no shortage of Aboriginal land. However, there is a gross shortage of ability to use that land. Let us see what actually happens. The member for Braddon talked about bipartisanship and rejoiced in the fact that we have a bipartisan approach in this House to immigration. The people who have been disfranchised in that debate are the people of Australia.

If the people of Australia were asked whether they agreed with the policies of the Labor Party or the Liberal Party they would have renounced them completely because both parties are in thrall to those pressure groups that support high immigration and multiculturalism. That is not the view or the wish of the Australian people. Similarly, the same thing has occurred because of a bipartisan approach to Aboriginals. What we need in Aboriginal affairs is some new thinking. We do not need any more of what we have because what we have does not work.

Gary Foley said the other day that over $3 billion was going into Aboriginal affairs. The only way I can see reaching that total is to include welfare payments which, in my view, should not be included because, if Aboriginal people are eligible, they are as entitled to those payments as anyone else. The money is considerable—over $2 billion. Two billion dollars is enough to give every Aboriginal family in this country a new house every two years. They have not got that because the money never gets there. Do honourable members think that Aboriginal people are fools? Do honourable members think that they do not realise what is going on? Of course they realise it. They are angry about what is happening. They know that this legislation is more of the same. It does not give them any self-determination and it does not give them access to any more power. It gives the power to the Aboriginal industry—the industry that has held them back for all these years.

In my electorate I probably represent more Aboriginals than any other member in this parliament and I listen to them. I know what they say. They do not like what is happening. I listen to Dickie Cox, the chairman of the Yungngora community at Noonkanbah. I have known Mr Cox for many years and he is a very wise person. He has no great education but he has enormous commonsense. He tells me what he thinks the land acquisition fund will end up as. He says that the money will be channelled into land councils that will buy land in the Kimberleys. The Kimberley Land Council does not have the respect or the votes of all the Aboriginal people in the Kimberleys.

Mr Cox says that such councils will buy stations and say to the Aboriginal communities, `You can have the station provided that you apply for land under native title.' He also said, `You people are so silly that you will modify your terms and give it to them anyway.' He says that nothing will be done with the land and then they will blame us and say, `We cannot do anything with the land because of the 200 years of dispossession. We need our own state.'

The Uniting Church in New South Wales has recently decided that it will support the establishment of an independent Aboriginal state in Australia. The United Nations treaty arising from the International Year of the World's Indigenous People calls for full social, political and economic independence. I ask: what is that if it is not a black state? The black state will not be run by Aboriginal people, and they know that. It will be run by the same legions that run the Aboriginal industry today.

I believe there has to be some rethinking on this matter. There is an overwhelming problem with Aboriginal health. The answers are not those that I hear from the so-called experts. I suggest that Aboriginal health is contingent on housing more than on any other single factor. With adequate housing must also come a commitment to teach people how to live in those machines which they are not actually used to. Then we need to tackle health on a community health basis, not on the ad hoc bandaid basis that we use at the moment. Then comes education, then comes training and then comes employment—that vital factor. If any one of these steps is missed out the whole edifice collapses. We have to realise that.

I will look at New South Wales which got some recognition today. The $264 million in the state land fund has been of no benefit to Aboriginal people whatsoever. A few have benefited a lot, but in general there have been no benefits. It would have been of enormous benefit to take industry out to those reserves across New South Wales which are too small in the main to be economically viable for any acceptable industry.

If we were committed and if we were inventive we would have looked around for industries that would fit into those areas. Emu farming is one such industry. If we look at the history of emu farming, we find that there are now over 50 emu farms in Western Australia—two are owned by Aboriginal organisations. All the funding for emu farming in Australia came out of the Aboriginal affairs budget.

Until the advent of Don Wieringa's crocodile farm at Fremantle, it could equally be said that all crocodile farm technology had arisen from research done at Edward River out of the Aboriginal affairs budget. Had we taken emu farming across western New South Wales, we could have created wealth and employment for Aboriginal people. With that wealth and employment would have come a sense of purpose, a sense of dignity and much better health. But it was not done because, at the end of the day, I believe that the Aboriginal industry does not want success. It wants to perpetuate itself and it does not want to seek Aboriginal advancement.

I refer to Aboriginal funding. There are examples where ATSIC or its predecessor bought land across vast areas of my state. I will stick mainly to Western Australia because I know it better than anywhere else. They usually paid top dollar for these stations—much more than the properties were worth. They were set up with five-year plans, which in the main were quite workable and reasonable. But then the problem started. The funding did not arrive on time. The funding did not arrive on 1 July. It arrived halfway through the year.

In order to use that funding, the Aboriginal people have to bring in a contractor. The response from the wider community is, `Look at those lazy black bastards. We give them this money and they call in the gudia.' The reason they call in the white person is that they know that, if they do not use the money, it is rolled over and they will have to apply for it again. If it arrives late the next year, the same thing happens.

Noonkanbah is a station in excellent condition. The improvements by the Aboriginal people are A1; they are as good as you will see done by any contractor. If you go to other places in the Kimberleys, you will see the same sort of thing. What Noonkanbah needs is 4,000 head of breeders. But it will not get them because it would then be self-sufficient. The Aboriginal industry knows that there would no longer be a requirement for it. So we see this industry perpetuate Aboriginal poverty. That is exactly what this bill will do. It simply puts more land, more money and more power into the hands of the same people.

Aboriginal people of this nation are not fools. They know that the governments are listening to people who do not represent them. Let us consider the people who purport to speak for Aboriginals. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that he had in his office 36 of the most high powered Aboriginal people in Australia. It was the greatest collection of Aboriginal power. I pointed out to the Prime Minister that those 36 Aboriginals represented nothing but self-interest. They were not elected.

I knew the six who came from Western Australia well. I said, and I would say again, that I would be prepared to stand against those six in an election in which only Aboriginal people voted. I am confident that I would outvote them because Aboriginal people know and understand. They are not fooled by this. Aboriginal people need a greater participation in the community.

We certainly need improved health. Will this bill give that? The answer is no. Will this bill give greater wealth? The answer is no. It will not benefit Aboriginal people. It may benefit some communities. But, when you look at the structure of these communities, it is very hard to see how this welfare and how these benefits trickle down into the community. For the most part, they do not.

An example of this is the CDP program. I was a great advocate of CDP. I thought it was a great idea. The reality of the CDP program is that, unless you have management, the schemes are a disaster. In most places there is no management. But what does ATSIC do? It invariably intrigues and appoints its nominees. When they fail, it walks away from them. I have had this experience repeatedly in my own electorate. Right now I have a problem with the Nomad's country in the Pilbara. People in ATSIC took the view that Nomad was an anomaly that must be done away with. Nomad was a group in which the tribal elders made community decisions.

It is true that a white man was involved, Don McLeod. He was involved because, in 1954, he was the only friend that these people had. In many ways Don has passed it, but I know that these Aboriginal people will not desert him because they are not like that. They will stay with him and, therefore, ATSIC has a responsibility to deal with that organisation.

What does ATSIC do? It subverts them. It supplies funds and sets up a council of young people who have absolutely no title to that land. The title is all held by the Nomad foundation. It appoints a community adviser, a CDP organiser. This gentleman clearly usurps his power and cuts off the power to the school. He boasts that he will drive out this existing organisation. He is going to change the school. At the moment, it is an Aboriginal community school. He is going to introduce a Catholic school. Unfortunately, he did not tell those people who are involved in Catholic education, and I know that they will not be silly enough to face the same sort of treatment.

ATSIC sits back on its hands and says, `These people have self-management.' Countless crimes are being committed against Aboriginal people in this country under the name of self-management, and we do it again and again. This legislation perpetuates the myths. If an Aboriginal community says, `We require a police station,' that is self-management. The committee makes that decision. Immediately this is done, ATSIC and all of the other organisations rush in and say, `Oh no, you have self-management. You must solve this yourself.' We never say to the wider community—a community much more able to solve things for itself—`You do not need a police station.' We provide the facilities, and so it should be. Aboriginal people say to me over and over again that they want to be mainstream. They want to be part of Australia. They say, `We are Australians.'

I remember a poignant case that I had in Karratha many years ago when a very intelligent Aboriginal woman for whom I have the highest regard approached me and berated me for the situation that was occurring. She said, `Why is it that Greeks can come to this country and their kids are accepted as Australians in the first generation? My kids have to prove it over and over again.' She turned to the police station and said, `Look. That is my flag, isn't it? I am an Australian. Why can't I have that flag? Why do I have this other flag? Where did that come from?'

It is easy to say where the other flag came from. In 1972, Mr Thomas thought it seemed like a good idea to create it, and it was immediately endorsed. But we should not kid ourselves. It would not have got the massive publicity, coverage and exposure that it has had it not been for the bleeding hearts, the social engineers, the white community. We foisted that flag on Aboriginal people, and it is a flag that many of them are beginning to see as a millstone around their necks. Their view is—and I get this repeatedly—`We are Australians. We don't want anything other Australians don't get. We are part of Australia. We want to be proud of our nation.' We keep trying to tell them that this is not quite so, and this is inherent in the change to the constitution which was passed in 1967. We did not give them equality. We gave ourselves the right to make special legislation for them.

I am, in a sense, ashamed that I am going to vote for this bill. I have explained the reasons for it. There is a future and things can be done for Aboriginal people. The problem is not insurmountable, but it does require a fresh approach. We have to massively increase housing, and this too can be done if we say to the communities, `You can build houses with your CDP. We will provide the people to teach you the skills required to build and own your own houses.'

Despite what the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) says, the reality is that even in those communities Aboriginal people are asking for freehold title. When I returned to Noonkanbah, Dickie Cox said, `We said to ATSIC, "Just give us the freehold title, and we will raise the money on the station."' ATSIC said, `Oh no, you can't do that, you poor Aboriginal people. You might lose.' He said,` Yes, we might. We are pretty good at business and, if we lose, it is our fault.'

He was prepared to take that chance, but we were not. We, of course, are determined not to give that equality to Aborigines. We are determined that we are not going to give them the same equality that we have to make mistakes. We know far better than they what their aspirations are! The time has long gone for a bipartisan approach. What we need is some commonsense, and that is not apparent on either side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I rise to speak about an issue which at some stage or another affects just about everyone in our community, and that is the impact of increasing road traffic on our quality of life. I am privileged to represent an area which is on the doorstep of a major city, yet retains its leafy streets, peaceful parks and quiet suburbs. It has been proposed by the state government that a tollway be built through part of my electorate—an area where young families have chosen to raise their children within close proximity to the city, to send their children to school and to enjoy the tranquillity of life.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to see my community pulled apart by this road. This is a close community; it is a supportive community. This road threatens to split it down the middle. The people in my electorate affected by this road are angry, shocked and depressed about this proposal.

This community is a very important part of our city and of our state. Successful communities like those around Kalinga, Wooloowin and Nundah are about the most important resource any government could have, because successful communities such as these are the basis for a successful society. In communities like this we have swimming clubs, scout groups, football teams, playgroups, tuckshops and so on, all working to make the community a better place in which to live.

This community must be consulted about its future by the state government in a genuine way. To this end, since this proposal was published over a month ago, I have played an active role in representing the views of my constituents to the state government on this matter. I have written to some 2,500 households in my electorate which are affected directly or indirectly by the proposed road to explain my views and to outline what I would regard as a genuine consultation process. I have personally lobbied senior government members about this proposal, in particular the Premier. They have assured me that the state government will engage in a full consultation process, including a full social, economic and environmental impact study, prior to any cabinet decision about the future of this road.

I have personally escorted the Premier on a tour of the affected areas and have secured a commitment from the state government that no new road will be included as one of the options for the consultation process. I requested the Deputy Premier, Mr Burns, to attend a protest rally in the area last Sunday, which he did, to hear the views of local people. I have personally spoken to many members of my community about this proposal and passed on their concerns to the state government. I have actively sought the opinions of local residents and have worked closely with the protest committee.

I myself am personally not convinced that the transport department has accurately defined the problem in the northern suburbs, let alone proposed a solution. The aim of the proposed motorway is supposedly to solve airport traffic problems. I do not believe this proposed motorway will do that at all. It will have a limited impact on existing north side traffic congestion and on congestion on Sandgate Road. It does not solve airport access problems, particularly those relating to Kingsford Smith Drive, the Gateway Arterial Road and the old airport site.

The chronic congestion on Sandgate Road is caused by commuting traffic entering and exiting the city from the north. The congestion on Nudgee Road is caused by northern industrial traffic and the congestion on Kingsford Smith Drive is caused by east-west industrial traffic. Most of the airport traffic actually comes from the south over the Gateway Bridge, from the north along Sandgate Road and Nudgee Road and from the west along Kingsford Smith Drive.

The Federal Airports Corporation estimates that only 20 per cent of airport traffic goes to the airport from the city or from the western suburbs. That is 80 per cent of the traffic congestion in the area is to do with problems on the north side of town and will not be solved by a road from the city to the airport.

Furthermore, this proposal does not adequately provide for access to the old airport site, so I cannot see the need for this road. I conveyed these views to the Bugle, a local newspaper, but it has never printed my views on this issue. The Bugle recently issued a press release which purported to chronicle a conversation I had with a shopkeeper about this matter. This press release was inaccurate and was never checked with me. I stand willing to work with the Bugle or any organisation opposed to this road, but I cannot communicate with someone who will not communicate with me, who will not print my views and who does not contact me to test the veracity of statements made about my views.

There is nothing more important to our lives than the quality of the air we breathe. Brisbane's natural ventilation is poor, especially in winter when temperature inversions are common. Brisbane has one of the highest incidences of asthma in Australia, with over 10 per cent of the population suffering from asthma. In my area it is much higher than that, affecting one in four children. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some concerns regarding the implementation of tax in this country and the costs that apply to small businesses. I often listen to government ministers talking about our levels of taxation compared with those of other countries. In some instances our taxes are on a par with those of other countries. But one of the major problems that small businesses have in this country is not the percentage of taxation, but the implementation of the tax and the costs of applying the tax.

PARA.TAB: One needs only to look at the legislation within the tax act, which is a pile about 2 1/2 feet deep when it is stacked on a desk, to see the problems. Most small businesses when they go along to their accountants these days find that the information they can obtain is insufficient to give them the confidence that they should be able to have when applying the tax in their particular business transactions.

This leads to the tax agents going along to specialists in various fields to seek further advice, which is a cost to the business. These are all on-costs that apply and do not get taken into consideration by the government in the implementation of the tax. The fact of the matter is that in many areas the implementation of the tax is not understood by the department itself. In fact, many of the people that I have spoken to recently in my electorate still have the same problem with business transactions that I had. When they phone up or check with the department on the sales tax level on particular products, the figure that is given to them is different from the figure given to somebody else in the industry.

This might not sound significant—we could say that it may be an interpretation—but there are several cases where documentary evidence provided to one company concerning the sales tax that applies is different from documentary evidence provided to another company. This is a major factor to businesses because the business that has the lower rate of tax applied to it has a major advantage over a competitor with a higher level of tax. All of these considerations must be taken into account by the government.

I suggest that, when the government talks about our levels of taxation compared with those of other countries, it looks at the technical presentation of the legislation as well as at the rate of tax. In most countries overseas the way it is presented is far simpler. Businesses understand the implementation and the costs associated with it. The difficulties for small businesses in this country, compared with larger businesses which can afford to have an accountant on staff who can work through some of the areas that are related to them, is that they must go outside to seek the assistance and help. As I said at the start, every time they do, that is an additional cost to that business.

The other significant area associated with this is the varying percentages that are offered—and we talked about it prior to the last election. All of that money in taxation at the retail level sits on the shop shelf. Every business that is buying products to put on the retail shop shelf is sitting government taxation there as a cost.

The 15 to 20 per cent tax on the products sitting on the shop shelves is very significant to most retail businesses. There really is a need for the government to recognise this and to understand the problems that our small businesses have in comparison with their competitors overseas. I urge the government to look closely at this and to address some of those problems to give the necessary relief to these small businesses that are still suffering as a result of the recession we had to have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in this chamber members debated a private member's motion moved by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and seconded, with pleasure, by me. The motion dealt with the price we gain when selling our coal and the commercial corruption that engulfs the coal industry today. Again today the Illawarra Mercury carries an article that the General Manager of the South Bulli Colliery, Mitch Jakeman, has delivered a threat to the workers and the United Mineworkers Union, Southern District. The headline in today's Illawarra Mercury is `Miners told: change or we'll close South Bulli'.

PARA.TAB: The General Manager of South Bulli Colliery has issued a document to all employees and members of the CFMEU. He states in that document, which hangs from a corkboard at the mine, that business is suffering from uncooperative work practices. He gives the workers and the union which represents them a choice. Option one is to operate productively for the next four- or five-year period. Option two is to close the mine. This is industrial relations from the coal mine owners of 1994! No-one—from the workers to the union officials to me—wants to see South Bulli Colliery closed. Such a move would damage the Illawarra and place a great strain on the families of those workers who over the last decade have already undergone the strain of having to shoulder the burden of restructuring a vital industry.

I want to raise briefly some of the issues which go to the heart of the options, which have been presented like a line from a Godfather movie. South Bulli demands that flexible work practices occur, as happens in other mines. Flexible work practices are occurring. Flexibility is available to South Bulli under the work models of the industry, which is an agreed position between the coal owners and the unions. So out the window with that one!

South Bulli refers to overtime restrictions. The pit already works seven hours, plus one hour per day overtime. There is a 14 hours per week limitation in the district. However, when South Bulli has requested that this limit be lifted, the union has agreed to raise the overtime limit to meet the requirements of South Bulli. So there is another one out the window. The other demand is quite interesting. The employees and the unions are asked to accept absentee management. This is a very interesting concept. South Bulli has an award provision to protect it. The union members have the same award protection. So there is another one out the window.

The argument that really provokes the patience of the employees, the union officials and, indeed, me is that there must be a cooperative approach to problem solving. There is no greater joke than a cooperative approach to problem solving from this pit. We have seen the approach in the statements of the General Manager of South Bulli Colliery. He says, `You have two options: you can either do as we say or we will do the really brave thing and close down the pit.' This, like the acceptance of absentee management, must be a new concept. I think all members would agree that this is cooperative problem solving at its very best and that the creativity of the approach is breathtaking.

This is plainly another trade union bashing exercise. Nevertheless, it has very serious overtones which cannot be ignored. South Bulli cannot be closed. The implications for the Illawarra and the families of those miners are too great. I call on the General Manager of South Bulli Colliery, Mitch Jakeman, to make good on his own demand for a cooperative approach to problem solving. It is no good making threats of closing down the mine. It is no good threatening the families of the miners, who do not need this additional worry. It is time the South Bulli Colliery management threw away those old-style industrial relations approaches. It is time for the management to be true to its own word and to be cooperative.

I am sick of the attitude of the management. I am sick of the threats. I am sick of the attacks on the union, its members and officials. I am sick of hearing the yelps for a cooperative approach. I wonder how the miners from Sydney's North Shore, in the electorate of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), who spoke yesterday on the coal mining industry, would respond to these threats.

The mine workers are very interested in the approaches of the coal industry. They have just presented an exhaustive submission to the Australian Coal Industry Council covering a wide range of issues which will be important to the future of the industry and mines such as South Bulli. So the union, through its members and officials, has the runs on the board. The union always rises to the occasion; it has always done so and it always will.

It is now the company's turn to show its concern for the industry by what happens in South Bulli. The essential point is that the company is alone in its union bashing exercise. The employees at the pit have today expressed renewed confidence in their union by an endorsement unanimously carried. This expression of confidence is totally contrary to what management has been saying. South Bulli's management can show its seriousness by withdrawing the threat of closure immediately and bringing its industrial relations policy into the 20th century. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a well-known fact that many students are financially better off in the short term if they enrol for unemployment benefits rather than Austudy. Most students will tell you life is easier on jobsearch; they are certainly paid more than they are on Austudy.

PARA.TAB: This issue has been staring the government in the face for some time, yet nothing has been done to redress it. For the most part, the rates of pay for Austudy and the jobsearch allowance are the same until the individual hits 21. Then an independent student on standard Austudy receives $241.50 a fortnight, while a person on jobsearch receives $294.10. The person on Austudy is obviously $52.60 worse off. It is even worse if the person receiving Austudy is living at home. The student can then receive $159.10 per fortnight while the same young person living at home on jobsearch receives $294.10. The Austudy student receives $135.00 less.

When our students can receive more on the jobsearch allowance than on Austudy, what signals are we sending out? Study is difficult enough as it is, without considering the financial hardship it usually involves. It is a long-term commitment which increasingly involves leaving home.

Let us put ourselves in the shoes of a young person. We have several choices: look for work and receive the jobsearch allowance while we do or further our studies and apply for Austudy. If a person chooses to study and is lucky enough to be eligible for Austudy, he or she can look forward to an annual income of about $6,000 and another three to four years at college, university or TAFE.

After that three to four years of study he or she joins the job market competing with another two million other Australians who would like a job. On top of that, if the student finally gets a job, the government taxes him for his past studies in the form of the higher education contribution scheme. It is a long route to the top.

For a country student the route can be even longer. In 1991, 21 per cent of higher education students were from rural or remote areas. A country student one is more likely to be living away from home, and this means paying rent or board. It also means buying food, organising transport, et cetera.

While new courses are increasingly being offered in country areas—and I am proud to have the only regional campus of the University of South Australia in my electorate in Whyalla—many students are still forced to move to Adelaide to study.

There have been several letters to the editor in my electorate recently outlining students' frustration with the current system. One of the letters was written by Joseph Hay, president of the student association in Whyalla. He writes:
Why should people studying to improve their career choices be subject to live below the poverty line where people waiting to get work on unemployment benefits get much more from the government?
Handouts and charity are no way to get through life. Do we want to go back to the `50s, where only the rich could afford to study and people were forced to live with the fate dealt to them?

SPEECH.PARA: Another Whyalla student, Derek Taylor, stated:

PARA.TAB: The way students are treated by the Federal Government these days is a disgrace. The message comes through very strongly from the government that they want you out of the education system and on the dole.

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, I must agree with his point. This government, over its 11 years in office, has expanded the welfare state and encouraged dependency on benefits. Michael Porter, Executive Director of the Tasman Institute said this earlier this year:

PARA.TAB: The government seems to have given up on full employment and is focussing on welfare systems, welfare payments.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I agree. Working Nation, devised by the government to address our fundamental problem of unemployment, was just a huge political and publicity exercise. It amended a few social security programs, making it easy for people receiving jobsearch to have part-time work, et cetera. However, it did not go to the crux of the matter. The federal government was too weak to take a cold, hard look at itself and address the fundamentals of its taxation or industrial relations systems to see what is really stalling jobs in this country. My final point is this: welfare payments do not create jobs, but encouraging people to study and contribute to the clever country just might.
