TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I pay tribute to the late Colin Fidelis Brown, who passed away suddenly on 22 August at the age of 67 and was buried on Friday. Colin Brown, or `Col' or `Brownie' as he was affectionately known, retired undefeated in March this year as mayor of Gladstone. His 15 years in the role were distinguished by unprecedented progress in the city he served and promoted with such commitment and enthusiasm.

PARA.TAB: A Toowoomba boy by birth, Col Brown was educated at St Laurence's college, South Brisbane. He married Carmel Macfarlane in 1953 and had three children.

By a strange quirk of fate, his many successful occupations prepared him with unique attributes for the task ahead of him. He commenced his career in the magistrates court, where he quickly advanced to clerk of the Court of Petty Sessions. From there he moved to the publishing game and became an accomplished editor of the Gladstone Observer. Finally, prior to moving into almost full-time public life, he ran a successful boat and marine equipment business in the rapidly expanding port of Gladstone. Employees of that firm spoke of the marvellous relationship he had with his staff during that period and as friends for years after. So this rare blending of protocol, justice, due procedure, communications, public relations and an understanding of the local marine environment made him one of the state's best equipped mayors when he came to office, defeating the incumbent mayor in 1978.

There have been a number of phases in the development of Gladstone in its move from a seasonal meatworks town to a bustling, confident powerhouse of industry. This rapid expansion in just 30 years brought with it enormous problems and challenges. A crucial stage was reached in the late 1970s when infrastructure, social welfare and recreation services, to say nothing of image, had reached a crisis level. It was at that stage that Col Brown demonstrated that he was the right man for the right job at the right time.

In 1982 he negotiated with the state government for a visionary $50 million infrastructure package, which provided a new hospital, high school, primary school and preschools, a state government building, sewerage and roads. But his major concern was that the city he loved should shrug off its down-market industrial image. He formed an image committee, which in mid-1983 became the Gladstone and District Development Promotion Bureau. It is now recognised as one of the state's most effective bodies. This, his own council's commitment and the motivation he imparted to community groups turned the image right around, not just in name but very much in deed, as those who have visited this beautiful city will readily attest.

Care of people was another of his many attributes. This was reflected in years in Rotary and a sports foundation, and the development of a heated swimming pool and a transport-for-the-aged bus, in which he played major roles. In short, he had an ethic of service.
In a moving panegyric at his requiem, Father Begg, his parish priest, said that Col was a practical example of Christ's assessment of the truly righteous man:

SPEECH.PARA: For I was hungry and you gave me food; I was thirsty and you gave me drink; I was a stranger and you made me welcome.
In a two-part eulogy, his friends Warren Fellows and Bryan Jordan took up the theme of his long-time service, his humility, his openness to all and his simplicity of living.

PARA.TAB: Gladstone's Star of the Sea church was filled to overflowing as 600 of his friends farewelled his casket, draped in the city's blue, white and gold flag. Streets were lined with a vast array of business people, employees and home folk. Guards of honour of school children marked the route of the cortege. There was scarcely a dry eye in Gladstone last Friday.

To his family Terry and Kate, Stephen, Ken and his grandchildren, and to the city of Gladstone, I offer my sincere sympathy and I am sure that of all this House. Few in local government have offered so much and asked for so little in return. It is a tragedy that a man who retired in March and had his testimonial dinner only two months ago was not spared to enjoy the benefits he so readily and unselfishly sought for others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today a lunch was held at the Canberra Yacht Club to celebrate the anniversary of the advent of our extremely elegant Australian national flag 93 years ago. The flag, as many people would know, was the culmination of a worldwide competition for a flag to mark the unity of the Australian states under the name `Commonwealth of Australia'. It was selected from over 30,000 entries containing a vast range of designs.

PARA.TAB: On 3 September 1901 the designs were displayed in the Exhibition Building in Melbourne and five were selected as being of equal merit. On the day the winners were announced by the then Prime Minister, Edmund Barton, a large flag embodying the designs was flown on the Exhibition Building, Melbourne. Photographs of the day show it as having a design similar to that officially proclaimed later.

In 1908 the government of the day decided that a seven-pointed star, symbolic of the six states plus the territories, should replace the large six-pointed star shown in the original design of the flag which previously represented the states. It also conformed with the star in the crest of the coat of arms granted that year.

It is evident that rational thought processes were put into place by the Australian people and government at that time to produce the present flag. The flag embodies the history of this country and is, as I mentioned before, so attractive and elegant that all Australians should be proud of it, and I am sure that the majority are. However, there are always exceptions, and unfortunately we have one notable exception in this case. I refer of course to Australia's Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who, since taking office, has spent a good deal of his time bagging the national flag and other symbols at home and, what is worse, abroad. His visits to Indonesia and France are the two most recent examples that spring to mind.

I, along with many other Australians, find it curious to say the least, when I hear the Prime Minister verbally portray himself as such a great nationalist, that he is capable of displaying such disloyalty to his own country. One of the Prime Minister's objections to the national flag is that it has what he describes as a `foreign' flag in the corner. At the same time, he mouths phrases to the effect that Australia must be `independent'. This, too, is curious, considering that it was he, first as Treasurer and then as Prime Minister, who has been more responsible than any other single person for putting us into debt to foreign financial institutions to the tune of $161.5 billion—the figure released today.

It is also worth noting that, during the time of the Labor government of the last 11 years, Australia has been a signatory to countless United Nations treaties which have effectively made Australians less independent than they have been at any time since Federation.

Finally, if another eminent Australian and prominent member of the Australian Labor Party is to be believed, and the Prime Minister actually did say that Australia was the `arse end of the world', I would hate to think what design he would favour to replace the present flag. The mind really boggles.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir,

It is my pleasure to write and inform you of a transaction involving the transference of $35,500,000.00 (thirty five million, five hundred thousand U.S. dollars only) into a foreign account for safe keeping pending my arrival with my colleagues for the sharing with whoever owns the account into which the amount is remitted.

I am an accountant with the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) Lagos and this money originated from over-invoiced contract executed for my corporation sometime ago, which I am one of the signatories who signed on the project to the contractors on completion and inspection of this contract, the payment vouchers had been approved and the money made available for payment to the contractors. But as a matter of fact, we are top government officials and we are not liable to come out openly to claim this above amount. This is why we are looking for a competent and honest company or individual abroad whose documents would be tendered by us here in Lagos as one of the contractors that executed the project.

So, after due consultations, you were strongly and reliably recommended to us by a friend of mine who is a president of Nigerian Chambers of Commerce. Although, we have never met or entered into any kind of transaction with you before as to know the extent of your honesty, but based on the recommendation, I personally want to believe that you are honest enough and you would not sit on the money if finally gotten into your account.

The letter goes on. Mr Deputy Speaker, the man to whom this letter was written has received about three or four of them. I cannot work out whether it is $35 million or $35 billion being offered, but it is a lot of spondulicks. This man keeps on getting these letters. Some people are going to give him $50 million and some are going to give him $30 million, which are enormous amounts of money. I think that the people offering this money are actually quite serious because I know of other people who have received serious letters of this nature.

PARA.TAB: The third and final matter I would like to talk about is the home child-care allowance. I defy any member of this House to come in and look you, Mr Deputy Speaker, or me straight in the eye and say that we have not had any problems with it or had any inquiries from our constituents. Quite frankly, it is a classic case of governments going terribly wrong. They use election promises for their own good and then when it comes to the time for the allowance to be implemented, what do we see? Absolutely no planning at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pea and thimble trick.

—It is the pea and thimble trick and it is causing enormous amounts of money to be wasted. The shadow minister for social security, the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), released a press release yesterday which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Minister for Social Security failed to answer a claim by the National Tax and Accountants Association (NTAA) that young families would lose up to $1,500 a year when the Home Child Care Allowance (HCAA) is introduced on September 29.

In a report in the `Herald-Sun' newspaper on the 27th of August, the Association said that families will be slugged with a hefty tax bill of $28 a week because of different rulings in the Social Security Act from those in the Taxation Act.
The President of the NTAA was quoted as saying that "at least 800,000 families would feel the pinch."
The Minister claimed that whilst there would be some people worse off, the amounts involved would only be minimal.
Yet this totally contradicts a statement by his own spokeswoman who told the `Herald-Sun' newspaper that the figure quoted by the National Tax and Accountants Association was technically correct.

This thing has got totally out of hand. It is causing enormous problems for people who do not deserve to be hassled in this way. They are low income families who are struggling to make ends meet and they are extremely concerned about it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue the speech I was giving last night on the Perth Dental School, which to all intents and purposes is an absolute disgrace. I visited that school on 7 July and made an inspection of the accommodation and the condition of the building. I can tell the House that it was disgraceful. I mentioned last night that amongst the various things that I located were structural cracks in the dental library, which is the dental library for the state. It is so small that it is unsafe and is an embarrassment, and I imagine that occupational health and safety experts would have a field day in there. In fact, a cloakroom attached to it has been made into a storeroom to handle the overflow of books because the library is so small.

PARA.TAB: In the main stairway serving the building, there is a broken handgrip. It is so badly broken that they are probably waiting for somebody to fall over because of it. One of the step grips on the steps is broken. There are white ants in the patients' area and white ants have completely eaten through the frame of the ground floor door to the building. The students' common room is an absolutely disgusting room. Rat droppings are continually found on furniture.

The hospital is supposed to be a referral centre for regional dental clinics. The students' prosthetics labs, where dentures and such are made, is like something out of Charles Dickens; and the operative technique labs where students have lectures have a capacity of only 32 students, which is just not enough for the number of people who want to use it. The postgraduate clinic, which is a very important place, as I mentioned earlier, where regional dental clinics refer patients, has an open fluorescent lighting system and rat droppings are often found on the dentist chairs or operating areas. This is, of course, not only unhygienic but a darn nuisance.

Yesterday evening I mentioned the issues paper, the review of the dental school which had been circulated. Tonight I mention some of the responses to it. It has been put to me that any discerning reader would draw from the document—that is, the document that was circulated as part of the review process—the fact that it appears to have a fundamental lack of understanding of the factors dictating the circumstances in which the Perth Dental School now finds itself. There is no positive appraisal of the potential role which a dental school could play in a university and how a dental school could aid its parent university in its relationships with the community within which it exists.

Finally, there does not appear to be any noticeable appreciation of the tangible and fundamental changes which have occurred in this school. The dental school has left behind many of the philosophies which have plagued its relationships at all levels over so many years. In answer to the specific questions raised at the end of the discussion paper mentioned by me last night are the following responses.

In response No. 1, the projected population increase for Western Australia appears to have been underestimated in its terms of real growth. Use of population to dentist ratios appears to also underestimate the community need for dentists. Given these two facts and the revised demographic estimates for Western Australia, on the basis of the arguments raised in the recent review of dental therapy in this state, it would be reasonable to argue for an increase in the undergraduate quota of about five places. Interstate and overseas demand would appear to support an overall undergraduate commencing load approaching 50.

In the second response, as already stated, it would be feasible for an undergraduate intake of close to 50 to be achieved for the school. In accordance with what has happened in Britain and Sweden, geographical and political factors provide a rationale for the school remaining open, even at present undergraduate levels. The school could certainly offer a diploma style course if the staffing facilities were available.

Third, close liaison with the Perth Dental Hospital would enable the school to use hospital facilities which are currently unavailable. These, plus modest additions to provide research and teaching facilities, would provide the capacity to house a greatly expanded school.

There are a number of other responses which time does not permit me to raise. But I would make one point: the national body which oversees dental school and university matters is a committee of deans. This body apparently recently wrote to the federal Minister for Human Services and Health, the honourable member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), to request a meeting. I understand that request was refused. That body says that it met previously with her predecessor on a number of occasions. It meets only twice a year and its members wanted to discuss a review of the DEET funding model which evidently results in a direct relationship between university funding and research.

The WA dental school is caught in a cleft stick. It has neither the staffing levels nor the facilities to undertake the sort of research which would gain it funding. For example, the school is down to a staff strength of nine full-time equivalents in part-time staff who together make up the equivalent of full-timers, where it should have 17 full-time staff. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: Is the Government considering a jobs accord with the private sector to increase the creation of local jobs, local investment and savings and to remove restraints to business.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Government is pursuing a range of policies aimed at increasing employment and investment, including at the local level.

Most importantly, the Government has put in place macroeconomic policies conducive to sustaining strong, low inflation growth over a period of years, recognising that such growth represents the most effective means of reducing unemployment. The success of these policies is demonstrated by the fact that the Australian economy is one of the fastest growing in the OECD, employment (seasonally adjusted) has increased by 376,000 since the trough in employment in April 1993 and the unemployment rate has fallen to 9.5 per cent.

At the microeconomic level the Government has implemented a broad ranging program of reform over a number of years to improve the performance and flexibility of the Australian economy. Most recently, in the Prime Minister's Working Nation statement a comprehensive package of measures covering industry policies, employment and regional development was announced.
The industry measures in Working Nation focus on building competitive firms by enhancing their capacity to invest, innovate and export.

New initiatives for increased innovation include widening access to the 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development, support for technology diffusion, and new schemes to support greater commercialisation of research in small high technology firms.
To assist firms to break into export markets the highly successful programs, Export Market Development Grants and International Trade Enhancement Scheme, will be extended for a number of years.

The development of small and medium sized enterprises has been encouraged by the extension of the management improvement program, the promotion of networking as a form of business organisation, and measures for firms to better access finance.

To better coordinate and deliver the large number of programs designed to improve the performance of small and medium sized businesses, a new agency, AusIndustry, will operate from 1 January 1995 through a mechanism of first stop shops.

The centrepiece of Working Nation is a far reaching set of measures to directly assist the unemployed, particularly the long-term unemployed, to regain employment. These measures include enhanced case management, expanded labour market programs centred around the Job Compact, and increased attention to training. To facilitate business participation in these training and employment initiatives by reducing business costs, Working Nation announced the suspension of the Training Guarantee and the introduction of the training wage.

The Working Nation employment measures are directed particularly at the long-term unemployed, a group which experience indicates is more difficult to re-employ without active labour market programs. By assisting this group back into employment not only will the long-term unemployed be able to share in the benefit of economic recovery but the long term sustainability of economic growth will be enhanced.
